[{'created': '2013-06-12 02:21:10.000000000', 'message': 'python3: Fix unicode strings

Python3 enforces the distinction between byte
strings and text strings more rigorously than
python2. So use six.text_type where approiate.

Change-Id: I46b3f5fe1f990fc1b7a3ee32904d608b070fc4c3
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-06-12 02:21:10.000000000', 'message': 'python3: Fix unicode strings

Python3 enforces the distinction between byte
strings and text strings more rigorously than
python2. So use six.text_type where approiate.

Change-Id: I46b3f5fe1f990fc1b7a3ee32904d608b070fc4c3

'}]
commit_message:
python3: Fix unicode strings

Python3 enforces the distinction between byte
strings and text strings more rigorously than
python2. So use six.text_type where approiate.

Change-Id: I46b3f5fe1f990fc1b7a3ee32904d608b070fc4c3
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 20:16:01.000000000', 'message': 'Make sync_power_state routines use InstanceList

This makes the periodic sync_power_states task use InstanceList
objects instead of querying conductor directly. This also affects
handle_lifecycle_event() as well, which now uses Instance to
fetch the instance for the event.

Note that none of the power state sync code was covered by unit
tests, so this adds that as well to verify the behavior and instance
object usage. Also note that compute_stop is already instance-object-
ready, so passing one to it is okay.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I4e34e0a2b9db77468305aaf1782feb74bcfdccbd

commit_message:
Make sync_power_state routines use InstanceList

This makes the periodic sync_power_states task use InstanceList
objects instead of querying conductor directly. This also affects
handle_lifecycle_event() as well, which now uses Instance to
fetch the instance for the event.

Note that none of the power state sync code was covered by unit
tests, so this adds that as well to verify the behavior and instance
object usage. Also note that compute_stop is already instance-object-
ready, so passing one to it is okay.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I4e34e0a2b9db77468305aaf1782feb74bcfdccbd

[{'created': '2013-06-13 18:12:03.000000000', 'message': "Unit tests: Don't use mox to stub uuid.uuid4()

The wait condition unit tests require a fixed stack ID, but we don't want
to permanently stub out uuid4, since there are other potential uses of
uuids. Instead, just do it for that one operation.

Change-Id: Ib8b7107a5750caf67aa8905377c2755bf405fa3f
"}]
commit_message:
Unit tests: Don't use mox to stub uuid.uuid4()

The wait condition unit tests require a fixed stack ID, but we don't want
to permanently stub out uuid4, since there are other potential uses of
uuids. Instead, just do it for that one operation.

Change-Id: Ib8b7107a5750caf67aa8905377c2755bf405fa3f

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: I70638f239794e78ba049c60d2001190910a89c90

commit_message:
allow overwriting of http_image in tempest.conf

the default http_image variable is an upstream cirros url in
tempest. However, in the gate this can cause flakey failures if
that has connection issues.

Ensure that we can override this from devstack-gate to be
something we are sure is going to work.

Partial fix for bug #1190623

Change-Id: Ie06fc231725c235f5ee8fd17fc87d3305bc845a3

commit_message:
remove unused imports

In the move to make flake8 tests stricter, we need a code
cleanup earlier.
This removes all unused imports and also enables tests to prevent
them for the future.

This patch also includes the checks on __init__.py files.

Change-Id: I34055803f7c4726682ac6fb95cc5b50ba761fec8
Fixes: bug 1188134

(1 inline comment)

Cool, thanks for the update. -1 on the missing bump to the environment_version in run_tests.sh but it looks good otherwise.

What does this new process means for updating requirements from now on? I remember it was agreed we should try and include bug numbers whenever we pin (e.g. for docutils in test-requires -- another lost comment). Does that mean we cannot/shouldn't do that in the future? Where can I find out more information about this besides the github repository? Thank you."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-05-30 17:08:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

For updating requirements, a review request should first be submitted to the requirements repository, and if accepted there, the requirements in horizon should be updated via running update.py ../horizon. As such it is similar to how oslo-incubator works. See https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Requirements for details.

I think the documentation of why a version pinning was changed should be in the commit log for the requirements/ commit. I don't know about a policy for mentioning it as a comment in the requirements file though."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-05-30 19:11:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-30 19:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Merge with OpenStack requirements

This unifies the pip/test-requires with the common requirements
defined in the OpenStack/requirements repository, which simplifies
dependency tracking for packaging purposes. There are small
minimum-required version bumps that most likely make sense for
horizon as well (or are already implicitely required due to transitive
dependencies).

Change-Id: I50d7d72b54a95012eb7a4f350ef0c3ef88047e01

commit_message:
Fix obj_load() in NovaObject base class

The obj_load_attr() method is correctly used in the field getter,
but incorrectly provided in the base class (without the _attr
suffix). Rename that and add a test for the base class that makes
sure this method gets poked appropriately.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I3b010ef727fed2f59fbb3d7173078b1dbc4b81f6

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-13 16:52:28.000000000', 'message': 'Unregister test objects when finished

Since many of the tests use temporary objects of the same name,
which persist in the object registry, we need to clear those out
after we are done with them so that a subsequent test doesn't
fail because it instantiates the wrong object schema.

This was causing tests to "randomly" fail if they were run in a
specific order causing one "Foo" object to be registered before
a different "Foo" in the same testr thread.

Related to unified-object-model

Change-Id: I77d3beebfb963cdc24c49eebb38ca8a768c69503
'}, {'created': '2013-06-13 18:38:22.000000000', 'message': 'Backup and restore object registry for tests

Without this, the object registry can become cluttered with test objects,
which may conflict with each other, depending on the order and pairing
of testr processes.

Related to unified-object-model

Change-Id: I77d3beebfb963cdc24c49eebb38ca8a768c69503
'}]
commit_message:
Backup and restore object registry for tests

Without this, the object registry can become cluttered with test objects,
which may conflict with each other, depending on the order and pairing
of testr processes.

Related to unified-object-model

Change-Id: I77d3beebfb963cdc24c49eebb38ca8a768c69503

commit_message:
Use Python 3.x compatible octal literals

Python 3.x deprecated octal literals in the form
0755. Use 0o755  instead which works at least
with Python 2.6 and newer.

Change-Id: I3474f601dab0e2e1fbed8ef6f7472e3e453b94fb

commit_message:
Add a policy layer for membership APIs

Added a policy layer for the membership APIs of the domain
model.

Added following policies for membership APIs:

v1: 'get_members', 'delete_member' and 'modify_member'.

v2: 'add_member', 'get_member', 'modify_member',
'get_members' and 'delete_member'.

Implements blueprint membership-policy

Change-Id: I0d5782d1d9b7b8a563a689fcb192958ab3fea0f4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-13 20:38:26.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure to remove auto delete ports from OFC in NEC plugin

When deleting a network, dhcp ports are removed automatically
in db_plugin. This causes a failure network deletion since the
corresponding port exists on OFC and the network on OFC cannot
be deleted unless a subnet on the network is deleted explicitly.
This commit gets auto-delete ports and delete the corresponding
ports on the controller before deleting the network.

Fixes bug #1190163

TestNecPluginOfcManager class is borrowed from commit 81ce9890ce
in master branch.

Change-Id: Ifffaa1a28b5fac0b0a98036a926550255cc25c9d
(cherry picked from commit da6816c6c703be68f5a0ce537364bc096ec2bd9d)
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure to remove auto delete ports from OFC in NEC plugin

When deleting a network, dhcp ports are removed automatically
in db_plugin. This causes a failure network deletion since the
corresponding port exists on OFC and the network on OFC cannot
be deleted unless a subnet on the network is deleted explicitly.
This commit gets auto-delete ports and delete the corresponding
ports on the controller before deleting the network.

Fixes bug #1190163

TestNecPluginOfcManager class is borrowed from commit 81ce9890ce
in master branch.

Change-Id: Ifffaa1a28b5fac0b0a98036a926550255cc25c9d
(cherry picked from commit da6816c6c703be68f5a0ce537364bc096ec2bd9d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-13 15:15:55.000000000', 'message': 'Added logging of x-delete-at values

Added logging of the x-delete-at value for object PUTs and POSTs and
made the additional log field generic for other similar use cases.

Logging the x-delete-at is useful because otherwise you might never
know why an object "disappeared" just by looking at saved proxy logs.
You'd see a successful PUT of the object followed some time by a GET
that 404s. If you still have the other logs, you could track down
what happened; but, at least with our clusters, we keep proxy logs
forever but only keep the other logs for a short while.

Change-Id: Ida559abcf8dc5666e2a7eea250a67d1c4b28b1be
'}]
commit_message:
Added logging of x-delete-at values

Added logging of the x-delete-at value for object PUTs and POSTs and
made the additional log field generic for other similar use cases.

Logging the x-delete-at is useful because otherwise you might never
know why an object "disappeared" just by looking at saved proxy logs.
You'd see a successful PUT of the object followed some time by a GET
that 404s. If you still have the other logs, you could track down
what happened; but, at least with our clusters, we keep proxy logs
forever but only keep the other logs for a short while.

Change-Id: Ida559abcf8dc5666e2a7eea250a67d1c4b28b1be

commit_message:
Remove wrong reference to object attribute in nvplib

Plus, added negative tests that were not covering the
exception handling bits.

Fixes bug #1189730

Change-Id: I5df914c6b748a03816217336431c2b0b597481b5

commit_message:
Rename agent_loadbalancer directory to loadbalancer

Rename agent_loadbalancer directory to loadbalancer. and move
plugings/services directory one level up.
Fix tests and imports accordingly

fixes bug 1179276

[{'created': '2013-06-03 21:54:35.000000000', 'message': 'heat api : Update ec2token middleware for v4 signatures

Update ec2token so it can verify v4 signature formats.

Note for v4 signatures to work you need keystone to be using
python-keystoneclient >= 0.2.4, or contain the patch from
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26013/

This change is backwards compatible, as older keystoneclient
versions will simply ignore the additional request keys

Original (havana) bug #1122472
Grizzly stable backport bug #1187165

Note for v4 signatures to work you need keystone to be using
python-keystoneclient >= 0.2.4, or contain the patch from
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26013/

This change is backwards compatible, as older keystoneclient

Change-Id: Iccc6be7913ab5ca5813a2e0c8f66cda0ccd85a0b

commit_message:
heat api : Update ec2token middleware for v4 signatures

Update ec2token so it can verify v4 signature formats.

Note for v4 signatures to work you need keystone to be using
python-keystoneclient >= 0.2.4, or contain the patch from
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26013/

This change is backwards compatible, as older keystoneclient
versions will simply ignore the additional request keys

fixes bug #1122472

Change-Id: Iccc6be7913ab5ca5813a2e0c8f66cda0ccd85a0b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-06 12:13:04.000000000', 'message': "Sending volume IO usage broken

This is my fault, I didn't test the sending of notifications
enough when fixing bug 1182102, when the volume IO usage notifications
were been sent too often. This was merged as part of
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29915

The issue was that the code worked for the first IO usage event (the
one I looked at). Then when constructing the event payload for the second
and following IO usage events the code path ended up comparing a datetime
object from the db with a cached string representation of the last_refreshed
date that was passed into the conductor via the RPC.

Since last_refreshed argument to vol_usage_update in the db layer is
not needed and is causing these issues. I have removed last_refreshed
argument from the db layer and deprecated it from the conduction API.

Change-Id: I2030eb7912c56134ea688a6e8bbfcdeddca28307
"}, {'created': '2013-06-07 16:03:40.000000000', 'message': "Sending volume IO usage broken

The issue was that the code worked for the first IO usage event (the
one I looked at). Then when constructing the event payload for the second
and following IO usage events the code path ended up comparing a datetime
object from the db with a cached string representation of the last_refreshed
date that was passed into the conductor via the RPC.

Since last_refreshed argument to vol_usage_update in the db layer is
not needed and is causing these issues. I have removed last_refreshed
argument from the db layer and deprecated it from the conduction API.

Change-Id: I2030eb7912c56134ea688a6e8bbfcdeddca28307
"}]
commit_message:
Sending volume IO usage broken

This is my fault, I didn't test the sending of notifications
enough when fixing bug 1182102, when the volume IO usage notifications
were been sent too often. This was merged as part of
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29915

The issue was that the code worked for the first IO usage event (the
one I looked at). Then when constructing the event payload for the second
and following IO usage events the code path ended up comparing a datetime
object from the db with a cached string representation of the last_refreshed
date that was passed into the conductor via the RPC.

Since last_refreshed argument to vol_usage_update in the db layer is
not needed and is causing these issues. I have removed last_refreshed
argument from the db layer and deprecated it from the conduction API.

Change-Id: I2030eb7912c56134ea688a6e8bbfcdeddca28307

commit_message:
Replace FLAGS with cfg.CONF in other modules, unless tests

Replace all the FLAGS with cfg.CONF in cinder/
Large commit was split into several parts

Change-Id: Iacd645997a0c50aa47079c856e1b4e33e3001243
Fixes: bug #1182037

commit_message:
Implementation of Vanilla Plugin

* Implemented configure_cluster and start_cluster methods
* Cluster configuring is service:process specific
* Added basic unit tests
* Added basic validation

Implements blueprint vanilla-hadoop-plugin

Change-Id: I51c55557b6bb073a7eae7eefc2f21cc2c2df0385

[{'created': '2013-05-12 05:35:50.000000000', 'message': 'Add glance configuration reference tables

This is the first attempt at automatically generated configuration
tables being added to documentation.
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+spec/autogenerate-config-tables
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Blueprint-autogenerate-config-tables

Work is being conducted out-of-repo at :

https://github.com/fifieldt/autogenerate-config-docs

Glance previously did not have such tables, but submitting these for
review without linking them in to a book yet, because feedback is needed.

Please provide feedback on:
* completeness (is every option and its description present)
* groupings (is every option in the right group)
* potential integrations (can you see where one or more of these
tables could be combined under a nice descriptive paragraph)
* relationships to config files (are these useful as is, or how to
best integrate them with examples)
* anything else you can think of

Change-Id: I01e05dcf2178adfdb75d8559b107b1c2ba0c7060

commit_message:
Add glance configuration reference tables

This is the first attempt at automatically generated configuration
tables being added to documentation.
blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+spec/autogenerate-config-tables">https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+spec/autogenerate-config-tables
Blueprint-autogenerate-config-tables">https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Blueprint-autogenerate-config-tables

Work is being conducted out-of-repo at :

https://github.com/fifieldt/autogenerate-config-docs

Glance previously did not have such tables, but submitting these for
review without linking them in to a book yet, because feedback is needed.

Please provide feedback on:
* completeness (is every option and its description present)
* groupings (is every option in the right group)
* potential integrations (can you see where one or more of these
tables could be combined under a nice descriptive paragraph)
* relationships to config files (are these useful as is, or how to
best integrate them with examples)
* anything else you can think of

patchset 2 fixes spacing with header text and XML escapes
the description strings

patchset 3 links the tables into the compute admin guide

fixes bug 1077555
fixes bug 1156109

Change-Id: I01e05dcf2178adfdb75d8559b107b1c2ba0c7060

I agree that a refactoring should not alter behavior, so this lgtm.

I would like to see this handle Mb vs. MB correctly, but that probably needs a bug of its own too.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:21:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Ben,

Mb and MB is handled perfectly. I tested it out.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:31:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

It will return the same value for both though, right?  If so, that's not correct.  MB is megabytes, where as Mb is megabits.  People tend to use them interchangeably, but they're really not.  8 Mb = 1 MB (if my math holds).

FWIW, I did open a bug, so we can discuss this further there since it's not related to this change. https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo/+bug/1189635"}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:37:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

oh you mean bits. Wouldn't that change original behavior since it is currently case insensitive? However, I agree b and B should be distinguished."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-12 16:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Only about 90% sure that it matches exactly the previous behaviour in all cases, but it looks close enough :)'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-12 16:39:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

If we do find cases where behaviour has changed, that means we need more coverage in test_string_conversions()'}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2013-06-12 18:27:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 18:27:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 18:30:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Fails

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:19:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Mark, I've tried some more test cases on the original version and it seems invalid formats have been returning the default value such as "-", "-b", "123-456mb", "123-k". But these are obvious format errors so in the refactored version it raises ValueError. Should the above formats still return default since it was the original behavior?'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:25:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:32:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

commit_message:
Move log.setup to Bootstrap and use cfg.CONF opts

This patch uses cfg.CONF as ConfigOpts in common/config instead of
creating a new instance of it. This is needed since most of Oslo's
modules use the global CONF object to register their config parameters.

The patch also moves log.setup call into Bootstrap and calls it after
configs are loaded.

Fixes bug: #1190524

Change-Id: Ib601418a7dbcad84c79b640b93bc5798ec4a62c4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-07 18:46:36.000000000', 'message': "Guarantee FIFO/once-and-only-once delivery for the MongoDB driver.

This patch modifies the way message markers are generated and
used, such that Marconi can guarantee FIFO for a single message
producer posting to a single queue (FIFO for multiple producers
is not guaranteed.) At the same time, these changes guarantee
that observer clients will recieve messages once-and-only once
by removing race conditions inherent in timestamp-based markers.

Along the way, some technical debt was also addressed, particulary
regarding style, as well as some minor optimizations.

A new service, marconi-mongo-gc, was also added, and is required
when using the MongoDB storage driver for Marconi. This service
was necessary due to the special requirement that at least the
most recent message always remain in each queue, which is an
a-priori assumption upon which the FIFO/pagination algorithm
is based, and arises from the particular constraints imposed
by MongoDB's semantics.

Note: While implementing this blueprint, many calculated tradeoffs
were made in an attempt to balance performance, risk, readability,
and maintainability. The goal was to create a resonable baseline
implementation that can be iterated upon pending comprehensive
system and performance testing. Due to the many subtleties
of solving the FIFO/once-and-only-once problem for the MongoDB
driver, future contributors should excercise extreme caution when
modifying the algorithm introduced in this patch.

Changes include:
* Align text in comments
* Add counter to queue, messages
* Markers are now converted over to using monotonic counter
* Handle DuplicateKeyError
* Return resources in body as a response to a message POST
* Added mongo driver claims tests
* Return 503 when no messages were enqueued due to marker conflict
* Added backoff sleep between retries
* Added marconi-mongo-gc service. This is a new required servi

Implements: blueprint message-pagination
Change-Id: Ifa0bb9e1bc393545adc4c804d14c6eb2df01848c

commit_message:
Guarantee FIFO/once-and-only-once delivery when using MongoDB

This patch modifies the way message markers are generated and
used, such that Marconi can guarantee FIFO for a single message
producer posting to a single queue (FIFO for multiple producers
is not guaranteed.) At the same time, these changes guarantee
that observer clients will recieve messages once-and-only once
by removing race conditions inherent in timestamp-based markers.

Along the way, some technical debt was also addressed, particulary
regarding style, as well as some minor optimizations.

A new service, marconi-mongo-gc, was also added, and is required
when using the MongoDB storage driver for Marconi. This service
was necessary due to the special requirement that at least the
most recent message always remain in each queue, which is an
a-priori assumption upon which the FIFO/pagination algorithm
is based, and arises from the particular constraints imposed
by MongoDB's semantics.

Note: While implementing this blueprint, many calculated tradeoffs
were made in an attempt to balance performance, risk, readability,
and maintainability. The goal was to create a resonable baseline
implementation that can be iterated upon pending comprehensive
system and performance testing. Due to the many subtleties
of solving the FIFO/once-and-only-once problem for the MongoDB
driver, future contributors should excercise extreme caution when
modifying the algorithm introduced in this patch.

Changes include:
* Align text in comments
* Add counter to queue, messages
* Markers are now converted over to using monotonic counter
* Handle DuplicateKeyError
* Return resources in body as a response to a message POST
* Added mongo driver claims tests
* Return 503 when no messages were enqueued due to marker conflict
* Added backoff sleep between retries
* Added marconi-mongo-gc service. This is a new required servi

Implements: blueprint message-pagination
Change-Id: Ifa0bb9e1bc393545adc4c804d14c6eb2df01848c

@p-draigbrady when I started writing this, it would already conflict with 4 other patchsets. This way it has a reasonable chance of getting merged one day without going through 20 conflict resolution updates ;)

There's another part coming + probably the last cleanup and turning off the tox ignore flag at the end."}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-06-11 15:59:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

This patch is a large mix of obviously-correct unused local variable removals, and less-obviously-correct removals of function calls and instance variable sets.

It's hard to review like that.

Can you split it into two patches, one with only obviously-correct unused local variable removals, and one that contains the ones that require thought?  (Basically, anything that a peephole optimizer can't tell doesn't have a side effect.)

(I stopped noting potential pitfalls after a few files.)"}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2013-06-11 17:24:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

I'll split the trivial changes from this one into another patchset unless this one gets accepted earlier."}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2013-06-13 17:26:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Patch split to cleanup trivial instances only at the moment. Please check topic "pyflakes_cleanup" in gerrit for the whole list.'}]

commit_message:
Remove unused variables from various places (2)

Kill variables marked as unused by flakes8. This should allow to enable
F841 check in the future. Commits split over multiple parts to lower
the chance of conflicts.
Functions without global side-effects which may throw internally were
left in tests since they do additional verification (eg. json.loads).

Part 2 of cleanup.

Change-Id: I47219d470cb2793d420af8cfe6fd8afca8d01290

commit_message:
Remove unused variables from various places

Kill variables marked as unused by flakes8. This should allow to enable
F841 check in the future. Commits split over multiple parts to lower
the chance of conflicts.
Functions without global side-effects which may throw internally were
left in tests since they do additional verification (eg. json.loads).

Part 1 of cleanup. (also includes some missing '()' after close)

Change-Id: If7f2299d46332c65a1181b51fbd202e005d81087

commit_message:
Fix some unittest cases failed on osx

dd shouldn't actually be called in the unit tests to begin with. Stub these
improper calls out.

Fixes bug: 1188972

Change-Id: I2966382a66eebbf49ce74e091e444a91ab274869

commit_message:
Force simple Bind for authentication

The authentication code was using a common code path with
other LDAP code that got an LDAP connection.  If the system
was configured to do Anonymous binding, users could by pass
the authentication check.

This patch forces the authentication code to do a simple_bind.

Change-Id: Id0c19f09d615446927db1ba074561b129329b5c8

commit_message:
Force simple Bind for authentication

The authentication code was using a common code path with
other LDAP code that got an LDAP connection.  If the system
was configured to do Anonymous binding, users could by pass
the authentication check.

This patch forces the authentication code to do a simple_bind.

Change-Id: Id0c19f09d615446927db1ba074561b129329b5c8

Install agent packages when running the Nicira plugin.

other agents.

Fixes bug #1190057

commit_message:
Longer string columns for Trait and UniqueNames

UUID's are larger than the 32 columns previously allocated. Bumped to 255.
Arguably could have gone larger but we should be aware of long strings since
we're going to have so many Events.

Change-Id: Ib3785e3546ee77937d5a63691a9ae1dc16147c37

[{'created': '2013-06-03 21:59:33.000000000', 'message': 'Periodic formatting cleanup

This is the semi-irregular comment and docs cleanup.

commit_message:
Periodic formatting cleanup

This is the semi-irregular comment and docs cleanup.

No functional changes should be here although some code is moved in a
small attempt to sort functions and get things where they need to be.

Change-Id: Ib4a3e2590c6fbd016c391acc7aef6421e91c0dca

commit_message:
Use strainer to isolate and test individual cookbooks

Included:
- Add strainer gem
- Update test-related gems
- Add Strainer file
- Remove run_tests.bash
- Update .gitignore
- Update README file
- Update specs to use require_relative

Partial fix for bug 1188345

Change-Id: I6cb9e535212346cccb45f8c41c647b8daa8a4c7d

commit_message:
Add missing tests for compute_node_* methods

There was some missing tests in test_db_api for
compute_node_* methods.

Add tests to ensure that all works.

Also: old compute_node_* methods tests refactoring,
test_compute_node_stat_unchanged() rewrited
(sqlalchemy_api dependence removed).

blueprint db-api-tests

Change-Id: I0204eba442e2c6bbc06a238bbdff1eb236a713db

commit_message:
allow using image uuid for instance resource

make the instance resource accept image uuid for its ImageId
properties in addition to unique image name.

Fixes bug #1186410

Change-Id: Iae7705e73fe223d80e85d261a04f88f8c5207487

subject: Fix local variable 'root_uuid' ref before assign
messages:
[{'account_id': 5805, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:50:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Dan,

I'm not sure that is the right fix.

Can I ask how the image was build. If DIB was used what were the elements included in the build."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:57:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/32747/1/check/gate-ironic-docs/108/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 58s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32747/1/check/gate-ironic-pep8/271 : SUCCESS in 1m 59s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32747/1/check/gate-ironic-python26/271 : SUCCESS in 2m 47s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32747/1/check/gate-ironic-python27/271 : SUCCESS in 2m 23s
'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:10:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Dan,

So, there are a few issues here, and this isn't the right way to fix any of them, IMHO.

As Chris points out, it seems like your disk image may have been built improperly, since the root partition should have a UUID if the image is built using diskimage-builder and the correct elements.

I'm fairly confident that if the root partition doesn't have a UUID, then the whole PXE deploy process as-it-is-today won't work - it relies on adding UUID as a kernel parameter when the node reboots. Failing to detect the root UUID and then either not substituting it in the pxe config file, or not updating the pxe config file at all, will lead to the node failing to boot properly. Thus, an exception should be raised and the deploy status (in the database) set to ERROR.

If you have a good reason to remove the reliance on root partition having a UUID, I think it's possible, but it will take some more work."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also, this change should really be applied to Nova.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:13:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hm, I just realized this was already committed to nova. Going to copy my comment there and move to revert that change.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-06-13 13:33:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-06-13 13:34:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the feedback. We should fix this as it could be confusing to get the variable assigned error.

I am using DIB images but had another network failure cause imaging to bomb out... so I hit this.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-12 15:42:02.000000000', 'message': "Fix local variable 'root_uuid' ref before assign

Fixes an issue where the root_uuid variable gets used
before it is assigned.

This moves the switch_pxe_config function so that it only gets
called if root_uuid is assigned.

Fixes LP Bug #1190269.

Change-Id: I6e19c91e643ef4f4ad365f95c9af8dae60866708
"}]
commit_message:
Fix local variable 'root_uuid' ref before assign

Fixes an issue where the root_uuid variable gets used
before it is assigned.

This moves the switch_pxe_config function so that it only gets
called if root_uuid is assigned.

Fixes LP Bug #1190269.

Change-Id: I6e19c91e643ef4f4ad365f95c9af8dae60866708

* node groups will copied from the cluster template

commit_message:
Basic impl of 'convert' method.

* now 'convert' targeted to convert provider-specific config file to the ClusterTemplate
* i-faces updated to fit the new behaviour of 'convert'

Change-Id: I86328a44ab4e1600a6c826b9eadf7aca221db091

Fixes bug #1188473

commit_message:
Correct some overzealous s/moniker/designate/'s

The PowerDNS migrations were altered by mistake. This reverts those
changes and add's a new migration to rename the columns correctly.

Change-Id: Ieee66af5c52fba259be05c628fffdc393da8dd67

Correcting spacing on older releases

The older releases in the CHANGELOG do not follow the same spacing
rules.  Simply cleaning this up.  Should also have '.' at the end of
sentences.

[{'created': '2013-06-13 07:08:10.000000000', 'message': "Remove use of locals() in db migrations.

This isn't logging usage, but I still feel that something more
explicit is safer. Let's not try to be too clever.

Change-Id: I40633283dbdced6d69eb78e22a04eeb6957c0841
"}]
commit_message:
Remove use of locals() in db migrations.

This isn't logging usage, but I still feel that something more
explicit is safer. Let's not try to be too clever.

Change-Id: I40633283dbdced6d69eb78e22a04eeb6957c0841

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-11 00:06:25.000000000', 'message': "python3: Fix traceback while running tests.

In python3 you can't sort mixed data, that is,
for example you can't have a dict that contains
srings and inergers. Otherwise you will get the
dreaded:

TypeError: unorderable types: DictOpt() < _ConfigFileOpt()

Change-Id: If712e1d51c1e1329093acb16ed6a84e9f0baf8c1
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
"}, {'created': '2013-06-13 02:00:41.000000000', 'message': "python3: Fix traceback while running tests.

In python3 you can't sort mixed data, that is,
for example you can't have a dict that contains
strings and intergers. Otherwise you will get the
dreaded:

TypeError: unorderable types: DictOpt() < _ConfigFileOpt()

Change-Id: If712e1d51c1e1329093acb16ed6a84e9f0baf8c1
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
"}]
commit_message:
python3: Fix traceback while running tests.

In python3 you can't sort mixed data, that is,
for example you can't have a dict that contains
strings and intergers. Otherwise you will get the
dreaded:

TypeError: unorderable types: DictOpt() < _ConfigFileOpt()

Change-Id: If712e1d51c1e1329093acb16ed6a84e9f0baf8c1
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Nodegroup templates table and flow data from api.

Nodegroup templates page is populated with data provided by rest api.
Nodegroup creation flow uses hadoop configurations from rest api.

Change-Id: I8b2b64f50b8cd053c5e4d987430bc981236c2a23

@lifeless:

I think we need to sort out somethings on dib-run-parts firstly, I gave it a shot and it fails if the target folder is empty for e.g

###

[root@localhost ~]# dib-run-parts /opt/stack/os-config-refresh/pre-configure.d
----------------------- PROFILING -----------------------

Target: pre-configure.d

Script                                     Seconds
---------------------------------------  ----------

cat: start_*: No such file or directory'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-13 11:14:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

You should make this depend on your pep8 fix, otherwise we'll have to do a reverify after that lands."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-06-13 11:14:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Use dib-run-parts.

dib-run-parts is simpler and gives us profiling data. The --list option
was removed because it's not yet supported.

Change-Id: Icab4c5c04a26572e9b8564a25b1a328c889ead1c

"}, {'created': '2013-06-13 11:04:41.000000000', 'message': "Make reference lbaas implementation as a pluggable driver

implements blueprint multi-vendor-support-for-lbaas-step1

Split current lbaas plugin in two parts: generic plugin and
plugin driver. Plugin driver is responsible for additional
tasks such as: communicating with the agent, receiving specific
callbacks, communicating with external vendor-specific components.
Note that plugin driver is not a device driver and it's main goal
is to provide flexibility in choosing lbaas architecture.

Change-Id: Ib4bfe286826acdedeadbeeff4713448c073378d2

commit_message:
Make reference lbaas implementation as a pluggable driver

implements blueprint multi-vendor-support-for-lbaas-step1

This patch implements the following changes:
 * merge lbaas_plugin.py and plugin.py into 'plugin.py'
   After that the default 'reference' implementation is available again.
 * move all code related to reference implementation from plugin.py to
   drivers/haproxy/plugin_driver.py
 * Inherit HaproxyOnHostPluginDriver from abstract driver and implement
   its interface.
 * modify tests accordingly

Change-Id: Ib4bfe286826acdedeadbeeff4713448c073378d2

commit_message:
python3: Fix traceback while running tests.

While running the tests with python3, some tests
fail while running with python3. This is due to
change in strings in Python3.

http://docs.python.org/3.1/whatsnew/3.0.html

Change-Id: I4375bdda74363757dc7180ff3fd68cf7c8dc9c15
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
dib-run-parts was failing with empty targets.

When the target directory is empty, the for loop printing our profile
data was failing because of a glob problem.

Change-Id: I34e612021c70d6b8f75423de0d8be969c52e58e2

commit_message:
Enable "Start Instance" and "Shut Off Instance" buttons

Now that the shutdown and start actions in the nova-api are sane
we'd like to add support for these actions to Horizon.

Fixes Bug: 1190402
Change-Id: I1dffff3850e3fd45e766836600f6c04ebb2f3944

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-28 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 6719, 'date': '2013-05-29 10:31:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Restored'}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2013-06-12 22:50:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Nova does not talk to keystone when quotas are setup. 
Thus the only thing it can do is to accept any tenant_id it is passed. 
I'd rather see this changed in nova rather than tested for, as the current implementation is error prone. 
A quota may be defined by mistake on a non-existing tenant id, and stay in system without talking effect. However if the exact tenant ID is generated by keystone, the owner of the project will have undesired quotas."}, {'account_id': 6719, 'date': '2013-06-13 08:31:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-12 20:35:35.000000000', 'message': 'IGNORE THIS CHANGE Add Sheepdog store

Sheepdog is a distributed block storage. This patch enables Sheepdog cluster
as a backend store for glance.

Test:

You can set up a simulated 3 node cluster on the local machine with
following script:

 $ sudo apt-get install liburcu-dev
 $ git clone git://github.com/collie/sheepdog.git
 $ cd sheepdog
 $ ./autogen.sh; ./configure --disable-corosync
 $ make; sudo make install
 $ for i in 0 1 2; do sheep /tmp/store$i -n -c local -z $i -p 700$i;done
 $ collie cluster format

Then change the default store in glance-api.conf as sheepdog

Change-Id: I50e52b125f33d99975ea7e309770467d00982b60
blueprint: add-sheepdog-support
'}]
commit_message:
IGNORE THIS CHANGE Add Sheepdog store

Sheepdog is a distributed block storage. This patch enables Sheepdog cluster
as a backend store for glance.

Test:

You can set up a simulated 3 node cluster on the local machine with
following script:

 $ sudo apt-get install liburcu-dev
 $ git clone git://github.com/collie/sheepdog.git
 $ cd sheepdog
 $ ./autogen.sh; ./configure --disable-corosync
 $ make; sudo make install
 $ for i in 0 1 2; do sheep /tmp/store$i -n -c local -z $i -p 700$i;done
 $ collie cluster format

Then change the default store in glance-api.conf as sheepdog

Change-Id: I50e52b125f33d99975ea7e309770467d00982b60
blueprint: add-sheepdog-support

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 22:10:34.000000000', 'message': "Fix optional keyring support, add basic keyring tests

Commit 06d9437e8388b369546d760607f17cb5022750e9 made using a keyring
optional by adding a function to handle the imports. The problem is that
import needs to be available at a global level for it to be usable in
other parts of the code.

A couple of global variables are used to store the references.

Fixing the imports isn't enough to get keyring support working because
in get_auth_ref_from_keyring() the wrong token was being used when
evaluating token expiration. It was using the token already in the
HTTPClient object and not the one returned from the keyring.

Some simple tests were added to prevent future regressions. nose was
added to tools/test-requires because these tests will be skipped if
the keyring or pickle packages are not installed.

Change-Id: I1fe2c9e5cdf275df2047018368da2e4b3d2d6de2
Fixes: bug #1183072
"}, {'created': '2013-05-24 19:21:25.000000000', 'message': "Fix optional keyring support, add basic keyring tests

Commit 06d9437e8388b369546d760607f17cb5022750e9 made using a keyring
optional by adding a function to handle the imports. The problem is that
import needs to be available at a global level for it to be usable in
other parts of the code.

A couple of global variables are used to store the references.

Fixing the imports isn't enough to get keyring support working because
in get_auth_ref_from_keyring() the wrong token was being used when
evaluating token expiration. It was using the token already in the
HTTPClient object and not the one returned from the keyring.

Some simple tests were added to prevent future regressions. These
tests will be skipped if the keyring or pickle packages are not
installed.

Change-Id: I1fe2c9e5cdf275df2047018368da2e4b3d2d6de2
Fixes: bug #1183072
"}, {'created': '2013-05-30 19:03:10.000000000', 'message': "Fix optional keyring support, add basic keyring tests

Commit 06d9437e8388b369546d760607f17cb5022750e9 made using a keyring
optional by adding a function to handle the imports. The problem is that
import needs to be available at a global level for it to be usable in
other parts of the code.

The function is replaced by a top-level try/except.

Fixing the imports isn't enough to get keyring support working because
in get_auth_ref_from_keyring() the wrong token was being used when
evaluating token expiration. It was using the token already in the
HTTPClient object and not the one returned from the keyring.

Some simple tests were added to prevent future regressions. These
tests will be skipped if the keyring or pickle packages are not
installed.

Change-Id: I1fe2c9e5cdf275df2047018368da2e4b3d2d6de2
Fixes: bug #1183072
"}, {'created': '2013-05-31 20:45:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix optional keyring support, add basic keyring tests

Commit 06d9437e8388b369546d760607f17cb5022750e9 made using a keyring
optional by adding a function to handle the imports. The problem is that
import needs to be available at a global level for it to be usable in
other parts of the code.

The function is replaced by a top-level try/except.

Fixing the imports isn't enough to get keyring support working because
in get_auth_ref_from_keyring() the wrong token was being used when
evaluating token expiration. It was using the token already in the
HTTPClient object and not the one returned from the keyring.

Some simple tests were added to prevent future regressions. These
tests will be skipped if the keyring or pickle packages are not
installed.

Change-Id: I1fe2c9e5cdf275df2047018368da2e4b3d2d6de2
Fixes: bug #1183072

commit_message:
Fix optional keyring support, add basic keyring tests

Commit 06d9437e8388b369546d760607f17cb5022750e9 made using a keyring
optional by adding a function to handle the imports. The problem is that
import needs to be available at a global level for it to be usable in
other parts of the code.

The function is replaced by a top-level try/except.

Fixing the imports isn't enough to get keyring support working because
in get_auth_ref_from_keyring() the wrong token was being used when
evaluating token expiration. It was using the token already in the
HTTPClient object and not the one returned from the keyring.

Some simple tests were added to prevent future regressions. These
tests will be skipped if the keyring or pickle packages are not
installed.

Change-Id: I1fe2c9e5cdf275df2047018368da2e4b3d2d6de2
Fixes: bug #1183072

commit_message:
Revert "Fix local variable 'root_uuid' ref before assign"

This reverts commit 30bc1ef250f0230a9a1f562cd51b0f57d4a35912, which
fixed a NameError but introduced a new bug in the deploy process
that could cause silent failures in a deploy. Instead, we should
log a more descriptive error and allow the exception to be raised.

Change-Id: I0221984ce4f7c406990315ef820d9ce63fc6e015

commit_message:
Creates external bridge before starting ovs agent

The agent is currently involved in a race condition
where br-ex is created after it, but will still be
created before the agent searches for it in cases
where the intermediate resources are resolved quickly.

The agent will terminate immediately if the bridge
is not found.

Change-Id: Ie93289ce156f5c1d76bae7616b573107d16dd6aa
Fixes: bug #1190117

commit_message:
Improve SAIO deploy document.

improving points:
1. Remove yum install swift in Fedora; Use installing from source for
both Ubuntu and Fedora.
2. Explain you could use all users including root, your own guest. An
d the points developer have to care.

Change-Id: Id6d683441bd790a21734624e29eb7c98bb40de85
Fixes: bug #1126389

commit_message:
Add UT for checking special chars in object name

Add special chars could help checking quote/unquote, encode/decode
problems. Those two is one of most common mistakes.

Change-Id: Ife1c0b481f08c1666d62b4fb51b7fdcdfdbf2ba6

subject: Add Heat DSL samples for WordPress_Single_Instance
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 668, 'name': 'Adrian Otto', 'email': 'aotto@aotto.com', 'username': 'aotto'}, {'_account_id': 2834, 'name': 'Steven Dake', 'email': 'steven.dake@gmail.com', 'username': 'sdake'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 4328, 'name': 'Steven Hardy', 'email': 'shardy@redhat.com', 'username': 'shardy'}, {'_account_id': 4715, 'name': 'Angus Salkeld', 'email': 'asalkeld@redhat.com', 'username': 'asalkeld'}, {'_account_id': 6434, 'name': 'keith-bray', 'email': 'kebray@gmail.com', 'username': 'keith-bray'}, {'_account_id': 6488, 'name': 'Clint Byrum', 'email': 'clint@fewbar.com', 'username': 'clint-fewbar'}, {'_account_id': 7090, 'name': 'Jeff Sloyer', 'email': 'jbsloyer@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'jsloyer'}, {'_account_id': 7193, 'name': 'Thomas Spatzier', 'email': 'thomas.spatzier@icloud.com', 'username': 'thomasspatzier'}, {'_account_id': 7256, 'name': 'Randall Burt', 'email': 'randall.burt@rackspace.com', 'username': 'randall-burt'}, {'_account_id': 7432, 'name': 'Alex Heneveld', 'email': 'alex.heneveld@cloudsoftcorp.com', 'username': 'alexheneveld'}, {'_account_id': 7453, 'name': 'Florian Rosenberg', 'email': 'rosenberg@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'frosenberg'}, {'_account_id': 7514, 'name': 'Matt Rutkowski', 'email': 'mrutkows@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'mrutkows'}, {'_account_id': 7518, 'name': 'Frank Leymann', 'email': 'frank.leymann@iaas.uni-stuttgart.de'}, {'_account_id': 7665, 'name': 'Travis Tripp', 'email': 'os.travis.tripp@gmail.com', 'username': 'travis.tripp'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-08 19:36:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28598/1/check/gate-noop/1452 : SUCCESS in 00:00:00
'}, {'account_id': 7432, 'date': '2013-05-10 08:56:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I like where this is going.  Starts to feel intuitive (to me at least!).

A few thoughts:

* the keys underneath "requires" should not be the ID of a referred component, as this prevents requirements which don't refer to a component, and this prevents multiple references to the same such component (unless you allow multiple keys which can cause problems); suggest making the component a value in the map

* putting constants for lookup in "options" seems confusing; i'd favour a root "metadata" key with things like description and constants underneath

* and for best practice and re-use i agree that scripts -- and constants -- should come from external files; also where the keys are repeated (e.g. in instance_type allowed_values) it would be nice to do a reference, such as `fn::get_keys(${inputs.InstanceType2Arch})`'}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-10 09:18:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Alex: some replies to your comments:

on bullet 1: We thought about two ways of specifying the requires clause: (1) requiring a type (e.g. os::nova::compute) and let the engine fulfill the requirement, or (2) require another component in the same template, which basically defines a relation between two components. I think your comment related to #2 and the alt3 example, right? But both use cases are supported

on bullet 2: got your point, and also remember that Adrian expressed a concern with this in the Wednesday IRC meeting. I did it like this so far to have a straight-forward mapping to CFN, because I understood that CFN must be covered by the DSL, but no question this can be improved. It would be good to see a concrete example of how you (or Adrian) think this should look like. Anyway, I think we need this feature, e.g. to define alternative software packages for different OS distros etc.

re bullet 3: Yes, having things like scripts in external files would be the cleaner way. And for scripts we would probably also need a way for defining alternatives (e.g. for different OS distros). Regarding other things like valid values, I am not yet sure if referencing this would be good, because users might also want to see everything in one place instead of having to jump between many places.'}, {'account_id': 7432, 'date': '2013-05-10 10:43:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Re bullet 1 I'm looking especially at alt3 which I like because it addresses Clint's OOO use case where processes may sometimes want to be collocated.  Currently it says that the two "process" components are hosted_on the same server (my_instance):

    requires:
      my_instance:
        relation: hosted_on

Having this concept is extremely powerful so strong +1 to introducing this concept.  However I'd suggest expressing it slightly differently.  Starting with a long form where we simply list typed requirements/relationships:

    requires:
    - type: hosted_on
      fulfillment: my_instance

And for convenience there could be a short form as follows:

    requires:
      hosted_on: my_instance

(Or in the short form case we could even promote hosted_on so that it is a mixin attribute on the component itself.)'}, {'account_id': 7256, 'date': '2013-05-10 19:20:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-15 11:47:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 7665, 'date': '2013-05-23 00:52:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

Comments inline on alt1.

Alt 3 is closest to what was described in the email thread as a way to separate application definition from infrastructure definition.

I agree with Alex on the requires syntax.  It didn't make sense to me in the sample. I think the third expression makes sense. Although I wonder if it could be done using the options / mappings or the environments concept somehow.  

requires:
   hosted_on: fn::find_in_map(Instances, inputs.DeploymentSize)

This would allow application expression to be dynamically linked with target based on inputs or environment choices perhaps.

From a true declarative perspective on application separation, this is not really declaring what it requires, rather it is linking to a definition. For example, declare a requirement on compute with X resources (cpu, memory), storage, OS, runtime. However, that goes down a whole other tangent."}, {'account_id': 7193, 'date': '2013-05-23 16:00:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Added some inline comments to hot/WordPress_Single_Instance-alt1.yaml'}, {'account_id': 2834, 'date': '2013-05-27 18:54:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

looks pretty good.  Version could be an input but I don't have strong feelings on this point.

As we are coming to conclusion of the review process, one aspect I would like to see before +2 of this change is that we don't disable autoscaling in Heat.  Would you make samples of:
https://github.com/openstack/heat-templates/blob/master/cfn/AutoScalingMultiAZSample.yaml

and

https://github.com/openstack/heat-templates/blob/master/cfn/InstanceGroup.template

Thanks!

commit_message:
Add Heat DSL samples for WordPress_Single_Instance

This patch adds a few Heat DSL draft samples derived from
the CFN WordPress_Single_Instance.template as input for
discussion to drive definition of the Heat DSL.

The yaml files have been run thru python-yaml parsing to
ensure it is valid yaml.

A README file is also included that contains more details
about each sample.

Change-Id: I7bd837aae983e5f29931ee28f2872ebc6a090489

If we remove the old library, won't all nova builds fail until someone changes it to use the new library? It seems less disruptive to add the new one, change nova, then remove the old one.

I do agree we need an upper bound."}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2013-05-31 16:49:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Currently nothing is removed from our pypi mirror, so you can safely remove suds in this patch without breaking nova. commit_message:
Add dependency of suds-jurko

Suds seems to be a dead project that last released
on 2010-09-15 accoriding to pypi. It is also not
python3 compaitble. So use the suds-jurko fork
which is more maintained and python3 compatible.

Change-Id: I7cc70445fd9c845f444ee9d8b7a62e3a03a4da50
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

'}, {'account_id': 7473, 'date': '2013-05-20 23:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2013-05-22 13:08:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It seems that the problem is not so trivial. This patch doesn't work for unicode symbols(e.g. translated messages), because the CookieStorage backend encodes the message content using json.JSONEncoder, which generates a string like '\u1234\u1234\u1234...' for unicode symbols. Also the CookieStorage has a limit for cookie size of ~2000 by default.  Thus a single symbol being represented as '\u1234' and the cookie can store up to ~350-400 unicode symbols instead of the desired 2000. Then the limit this patch applies - 1000 will fail in the cookie storage limit check.

My belief is that this problem requires different approach, possibly something to be implemented into Django, or probably better - a custom storage for the messages, which encodes the messages in a better way, providing a handling for long messages."}, {'account_id': 7419, 'date': '2013-05-27 13:02:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

The reason for that string representation ('\u1234') can be found in RFC 6265. Basically the cookie value can contain only "US-ASCII characters excluding CTLs, whitespace DQUOTE, comma, semicolon, and backslash". So there's not much room for improvement.

I can think of a few possible solutions here:
- we limit the length of the message based on its json representation
- we change the MESSAGE_STORAGE from django.contrib.messages.storage.cookie.CookieStorage to django.contrib.messages.storage.session.SessionStorage. It would give us a much higher limit so the current MESSAGE_LIMIT would still work.
- change the message not to include the name of the instances, only the number of instances

I prefer the first solution even if it will generate a shorter messages for unicode messages. I think it will be still long enough for the user the know what happened. Also note that this message only appears for a few seconds, so there's no way the user could read 1000 chars.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-04 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-04 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 7419, 'date': '2013-06-04 11:57:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Restored

I am waiting for feedback before updating the patch.'}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2013-06-04 13:58:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thank you for this patch. It looks really useful and the code looks sane to me.'}, {'account_id': 7553, 'date': '2013-06-04 15:44:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2013-06-04 16:31:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Sorry for the delayed response, I haven't noticed the comment here. The first option seems as the easiest one.

Anyway, I'm more concerned that this patch actually almost duplicates an existing check in Django:
https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/contrib/messages/storage/cookie.py#L98

So we already have max_cookie_size. It would be perfect if the truncation goes here, or a callback is being executed somehow.. In fact this is the exception being thrown when cookie size exceeds the limit:
https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/contrib/messages/middleware.py#L22

If we now add some new logic, it might partially duplicate existing checks, but might also be unstable for some edge cases. I'd like to hear what Gabriel thinks of it, but my gut feeling is that this issue has to be fixed either in Django someday, or to be fixed with using some Django internals until it gets a nice failover added in Django in future versions.


P.S. Hm, it seems there is already a Fallback storage in Django:
https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/contrib/messages/storage/fallback.py

I haven't used it, but it seems to have a failover for truncated message... Can you check if it might solve the issue?"}, {'account_id': 7419, 'date': '2013-06-04 17:26:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Work In Progress

Based on the review by Tihomir Trifonov, I need to update the patch.'}, {'account_id': 7419, 'date': '2013-06-05 12:22:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Tihomir, You are right, that check is already done in Django and would be a duplicate.

As for the FallbackStorage, according to the Django documentation: "This class first uses CookieStorage, and falls back to using SessionStorage for the messages that could not fit in a single cookie."
(https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/contrib/messages/) 
So it would not solve the issue but would make it much much less probable to occur. Partly for the same reason, I suggested previously as another alternative approach to change the MESSAGE_STORAGE from CookieStorage to SessionStorage, but I aggree, FallbackStorage is probably better.

Btw, it's great you pointed out the middleware class. I have just realized that the exception is not even raised if the application is not in debug mode. In that case, the user just doesn't receive the message at all.
https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/contrib/messages/middleware.py#L24

Having considered that, I would say that this issue is not even a bug but enabling FallbackStorage would be a nice enhancement. As would also be a feature request in Django for a better handling of unstored messages.

What do you think?'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-13 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-13 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

commit_message:
Limit the length of each message

Adding messages can cause storage capacity overflows. Maximizing the length of each messages helps to prevent such issues.

Fixes: bug #1168541
Change-Id: I967636e393be6368b9e1894e762158f475673e69

commit_message:
Add Kerberos authentication to Client.

Allow using kerberos data from the session to authenticate against a
keystone server. This makes numerous assumptions about how the server
has implemented kerberos HTTP authentication.
 - A TGT for the appropriate realm must already be in the session.
 - The service must be named HTTP (limitation of requests-kerberos).

Change-Id: Icb5adb9c234a4c5a2ada140520c47abb22aefd5b

commit_message:
Use an inner join on aggregate_hosts in aggregate_get_by_host

Fixes bug 1187708

By default, sqlalchemy.orm.joinedload does a left outer join.  But in
aggregate_get_by_host, we only want to get aggregates rows with
aggregate_hosts rows that match the host, and a left outer join also
gave us aggregates rows with no matching aggregate_hosts row.

Also improve test_aggregate_get_by_host to catch this bug.

Change-Id: Ida9647af02ab58229abe3c50dc3d2c7ec9792a5e

commit_message:
Improve the performance of migration 186

This patch significantly improves the performance of migration 186 by
refactoring the migration code to use SQL joins. It does in no way
functionally change what the migration does.

It also adds a more robust test to make sure that there were no
regressions.

Change-Id: I654ed8dd229d774e8f680cae2b8d2ad2cf28550c

commit_message:
Add HACKING.rst

Add HACKING.rst but instead of copying the file around point to the new
cannonical location for it
https://github.com/openstack-dev/hacking/blob/master/HACKING.rst

Also expand out the flake8 H series ignores, so they can be enabled one
by one.

Change-Id: I6ec39d00c3beabbc3e661754bac6e43a0fb351d6

'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-06 14:54:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

Overall I find the direction of removing auto_disk_config interesting, but I'm not sure we can get there quite yet.  I think it needs to be considered a 'feature' which will require some discussion to remove.  So I like everything you've done here, but I think we still require some "if instance['auto_disk_config']: self._auto_disk_config()" type logic somewhere.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-06 15:08:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: (4 inline comments)

I figured I was removing a check that was added for a bug, so it isn't really a feature:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1081225

Basically I am finding a slightly different way to fix the above bug, which also fixes the other two bugs that are listed.

This would leave the auto_disk_config image and server setting just to notify if the disk should be resized during boot, returning it it its original purpose. We could discuss removing that also, but that certainly is a wider issue."}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-06-06 15:09:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(7 inline comments)

I wonder if the easiest "quick fix" would be to make the default to assume that auto configure will happen unless auto_config_disk is present and set to false?

Then there can be a longer discussion about whether this feature should be deprecated, moved out of XenAPI or kept as-is?'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-06 15:25:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

just to clarify this change is about fixing issues with resize down, not for removing the auto_disk_config feature'}, {'account_id': 6735, 'date': '2013-06-06 15:28:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

My bad - but the line-by-line comments still stand! :)'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-06 15:30:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Work In Progress

commit_message:
xenapi: remove auto_disk_config check during resize

This check was introduced by the following change:
7c5c8a743c21733120c85fdefb84b4357f5848d0

This is an alternative fix to ensure resize down
is not processed if the disk cannot be resized.

Note the failure now registers an instance action
and does not leave the VM in an error state.

In addition, this keeps the behavior that a failure
to resize up and instance during spawn will not
cause the operation to fail and put the VM into error.

fixes bug 1188135
fixes bug 1187934
fixes bug 1081225

Change-Id: I5b3dfdc7fcda26c55702dde6cdf191beee0c818c

'}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-06-09 02:05:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Do we really need to do this? I just see tons of merge conflicts stemming from it. If others disagree with my concern I'll reverse the -1."}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-06-10 18:51:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-10 20:41:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Rafi,
"The BDFL [3] recommends inserting a blank line between the last paragraph in a multi-line docstring and its closing quotes, placing the closing quotes on a line by themselves. This way, Emacs' fill-paragraph command can be used on it."
http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0257/

Furthermore, concern over merge conflicts hardly seems like a good reason not to merge something.  If there is a merge conflict it can be resolved.

While I am fine with removing this requirement altogether (I don't use emacs), If we keep this around as part of the style guide I prefer to enforce it automatically instead of manually.

http://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2013/06/is-it-a-good-idea-to-impose-uniform-code-format-for-all-developers/ 

Note: only giving this a +1, to wait for more consensus.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I think the only sensible way to avoid merge conflicts in the long run is to enforce a strict style. It also is friendlier to newcomers because there is only one code style, not the style of multiple developers that needs to be mimiced in various places differently. 

FWIW, this is the python way - there is only one way to do it.'}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-06-12 19:07:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-06-12 19:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This was a lot of files to go through at once.  Merge conflicts are definitely not a reason to -1 this...  but I might prefer to see this split into a few different patches next time... with the final one fixing the tox config.  There is potential of going through a number of iterations because of conflicts and I really do not want to have to look through all of this at once again. :)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 19:47:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

I'm not object if there's some future possible need here, just seems odd."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-06-13 00:11:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Ok, so it seems there's a bit of a mess uncovered here.  The base driver has:
def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, force=False, **kwargs): 

and we have a mix of force and kwargs throughout everywhere that inherits.  Shouldn't be your problem to deal with.  

The base iscsi drivers is like you have it, so that should be fine for now.  We should log a defect and clean this stuff up everywhere though."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-13 00:11:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

3PAR drivers now default the third parameter when terminate_connection
is called after copying a volume to image.
Fixes: bug #1190056

Change-Id: Icadacc9e083c6e97a919857d735ec16068d0f0c6

commit_message:
Fixes 3PAR drivers terminate_connection issue.

3PAR drivers now default the third parameter when terminate_connection
is called after copying a volume to image.
Fixes: bug #1190056

Change-Id: Icadacc9e083c6e97a919857d735ec16068d0f0c6

commit_message:
Use Python 3.x compatible except construct

Python 3.x deprecated excecpt x,y. Use except x as y,
which works with any Python version >= 2.6

Change-Id: I264049ee41e75bcedea86adf7c2011c343f47ddb

commit_message:
Split H102 into 2 checks and enable them

H102 Apache 2.0 license header not found
H103 Header does not match Apache 2.0 License notice

Change-Id: I92611cc6540c2d8acd84a28aa230bd906cd0dfeb

subject: Add support for setting extra networking configuration options.

For things like this I think quantum should just support some kind of EXTRA_CONFIG variable. We shouldn't put code in devstack that just passes through single config variables."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-05-24 12:58:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sean, can you elaborate here? This is exactly how the existing Quantum config is handled in devstack, I'm just following the way it's done and adding support for setting the tunnel type. Adding this as EXTRA_CONFIG would stil mean I'd have to parse EXTRA_CONFIG to determine what's in there, and would make this a much larger change, don't you think?"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-28 12:31:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

it would make it bigger, but it would also prevent 75% of the quantum related devstack changes from being proposed. There has been a huge number of "enable this one flag" patches coming through the queue.

In nova we've got a catch all variable for just this reason, so that you don't need to enable every single config option explicitly in devstack.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-05-28 19:32:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK, makes sense, thanks for the input Sean, I will refactor this to work similar to Nova. Thanks for the review and input!'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-05-30 21:35:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-05-30 21:38:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-05-30 21:38:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Q_SRV_EXTRA_OPTS is still wrong in the commit message, that doesn't appear in your code at all, but Q_AGENT_EXTRA_SRV_OPTS does.  The commit message needs to reflect what the code does."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-06-07 17:50:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

Dean, it does appear in the code, I'm not sure you're reading the entire patch, please look at the last block in each of the linux_bridge and openvswitch files. I've provided the relevant chunks of the patch for your viewing pleasure:

In linux_bridge:
    # Define extra "LINUX_BRIDGE" configuration options when q-svc is configured by defining
    # the array ``Q_SRV_EXTRA_OPTS``.
    # For Example: ``Q_SRV_EXTRA_OPTS=(foo=true bar=2)``
    for I in "${Q_SRV_EXTRA_OPTS[@]}"; do
        # Replace the first '=' with ' ' for iniset syntax
        iniset /$Q_PLUGIN_CONF_FILE LINUX_BRIDGE ${I/=/ }
    done

In openvswitch:
    # Define extra "OVS" configuration options when q-svc is configured by defining
    # the array ``Q_SRV_EXTRA_OPTS``.
    # For Example: ``Q_SRV_EXTRA_OPTS=(foo=true bar=2)``
    for I in "${Q_SRV_EXTRA_OPTS[@]}"; do
        # Replace the first '=' with ' ' for iniset syntax
        iniset /$Q_PLUGIN_CONF_FILE OVS ${I/=/ }
    done'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-06-07 18:03:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Kyle, it has to be before 09:00 somewhere in the world, right?  Too bad it isn't where I am sitting...down-arrow is my friend...down-arrow is my friend..."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-06-07 21:05:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

I'm going to rebase this because Bob's ML2 patch moved some of the agent configuration for LinuxBridge and Open vSwitch into their own files. Testing the rebase out now, new change inbound in 20 minutes or so."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-06-07 21:13:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 6524, 'date': '2013-06-07 21:23:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Add support for setting extra networking configuration options.

Add support for generically setting arguments for OpenStack Networking
for both the server and agent. This is done using Q_SRV_EXTRA_OPTS for the
server, which let you place settings in the "OVS" or "LINUX_BRIDGE"
sections of the plugin configuration file. For the agent, two variables
are defined: Q_AGENT_EXTRA_AGENT_OPTS lets you set items in the "AGENT"
section of the plugin configuration file, and Q_AGENT_EXTRA_SRV_OPTS
lets you set things in the "OVS" or "LINUX_BRIDGE" sections of the
plugin configuration file.

Implements blueprint devstack-quantum-config.

Change-Id: I9ba44b21231f88cda1bcc5e3389c7875f03d8145

commit_message:
Fix live migrate qemu.conf option

dynamic_ownership = 0 in /etc/libvirt/qemu.conf is necessary
 for live migration to work properly

fixes bug 10756002

Change-Id: Ibab0ddc12eab3f431e0231507288b95805dde527

If deletion fails because the volume is busy, log at "warning" level
rather than "debug" to increase the odds that a user will see the
message.

Change-Id: I04031ee6b1f6647a126baa8a29c15a00b84b27b1
'}, {'created': '2013-06-12 22:21:36.000000000', 'message': 'Elevate volume/snap "is busy" log message for volume/snap_delete

If deletion fails because the volume is busy, log at "error" level
rather than "debug" to ensure that the error is logged and visible
to a user.

Change-Id: I04031ee6b1f6647a126baa8a29c15a00b84b27b1
'}]
commit_message:
Elevate volume/snap "is busy" log message for volume/snap_delete

If deletion fails because the volume is busy, log at "error" level
rather than "debug" to ensure that the error is logged and visible
to a user.

Change-Id: I04031ee6b1f6647a126baa8a29c15a00b84b27b1

[{'created': '2013-06-11 18:28:21.000000000', 'message': 'Use Python 3.x compatible octal literals

Python 3.x deprecated octal literals in the form 0755.
Use the Python 2.x compatible version 0o755 instead.

Change-Id: I64ca97e87ab29764c3cbcb42cefc313635cc178d
'}]
commit_message:
Use Python 3.x compatible octal literals

Python 3.x deprecated octal literals in the form 0755.
Use the Python 2.x compatible version 0o755 instead.

Change-Id: I64ca97e87ab29764c3cbcb42cefc313635cc178d

commit_message:
Update to the latest stevedore

Use a version of stevedore that does not try to
install distribute.

The requirements change is in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32738/

Change-Id: I727dd6b4c8d8bab271c51c23bba6945cf5cd6225
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Remove unused methods from VirtAPI

The instance_get_all_by_host() and instance_get_by_uuid() methods are
no longer needed by any virt drivers, so remove them from the virtapi..

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: Ib51bf3b3e068d69e7a75f7312f03db6c85e7cf49
