'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 17:30:20.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:13:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dan,

So, there are a few issues here, and this isn't the right way to fix any of them, IMHO. I would like to REVERT this change.

As Chris pointed out on the corresponding Ironic review, it seems like your disk image may have been built improperly, since the root partition should have a UUID if the image is built using diskimage-builder and the correct elements.

I'm fairly confident that if the root partition doesn't have a UUID, then the whole PXE deploy process as-it-is-today won't work - it relies on adding UUID as a kernel parameter when the node reboots. Failing to detect the root UUID and then either not substituting it in the pxe config file, or not updating the pxe config file at all, will lead to the node failing to boot properly. Thus, an exception should be raised and the deploy status (in the database) set to ERROR.
If you have a good reason to remove the reliance on root partition having a UUID, I think it's possible, but it will take some more work."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:21:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'd like to understand the behavior difference this causes such that you'd like to revert the change.

Is it that switch_pxe_config() can also raise ProcessExecuteError and now it will only log and not raise back?

Or is it that switch_pxe_config() now runs before logout_iscsi()?  <--  *This* is something I missed when I reviewed this patch and I would have asked about it.  :(   The finally: didn't stand out to me.

Or is it both of these things? :)"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:27:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

And because I said it publicly: I'm all for moving this line back to where it was.  But when you do, you might as well set root_uuid=None or some such in the except:  so that you don't get an immediate NameError traceback trying to call switch_pxe_config().   Or reraise the exception if that's what you meant to do, instead.  Or something.  :)"}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-06-13 01:28:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Have a look at
  https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/baremetal/pxe_config.template

If the first "deploy xxx" line isn't changed to indicate "boot", then the baremetal node will never boot into the tenant instance.

Furthermore, if it is changed to "deploy boot", but the ${ROOT} macro isn't replaced with a valid UUID, then the boot most likely will fail.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-12 15:34:49.000000000', 'message': "Fix local variable 'root_uuid' ref before assign

Fixes an issue where the root_uuid variable gets used
before it is assigned.

This moves the switch_pxe_config function so that it only gets
called if root_uuid is assigned.

Fixes LP Bug #1190269.

Change-Id: I1abaf391f3a80dcacc815d2e38c6da9ad1b099ff
"}]
commit_message:
Fix local variable 'root_uuid' ref before assign

Fixes an issue where the root_uuid variable gets used
before it is assigned.

This moves the switch_pxe_config function so that it only gets
called if root_uuid is assigned.

Fixes LP Bug #1190269.

Change-Id: I1abaf391f3a80dcacc815d2e38c6da9ad1b099ff

commit_message:
Make xenapi use Instance object for host_maintenance_mode()

This makes xenapi grab an Instance object in host_maintenance_mode()
instead of calling into virtapi. This removes the one and only use
of instance_get_by_uuid() in nova/virt.

The existing tests for host_maintenance_mode() need no changes
since they just stub out the database call that eventually gets
called in the same way.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: Iff4b5de1741653fad8c59e311341aeb3d0bb3539

subject: Make xenapi/host use instance objects for _uuid_find

commit_message:
Make xenapi/host use instance objects for _uuid_find

This is the one and only use of instance_get_all_by_host() in the
nova/virt tree. Converting it to objects immediately eliminates the
need for that method in the virtapi.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I21dfd5a34fb1eef4d442c0711f37e5ef6b18e5bb

commit_message:
Skip ipv6 tests on system without ipv6 support

On system without ipv6 support, CONFIG_IPV6 disabled kernel for
instance, WSGI service testcases for ipv6 would fail for "[Errno 97]
Address family not supported by protocol".

Since there is no easy way to detect actual ipv6 support,
socket.has_ipv6 not working for this case, simply skip ipv6 tests if
errno.EAFNOSUPPORT happens.

Fixes: bug 1174404

Change-Id: I9fa8653f5ccfbcb8c31c51bfda137cb58388afde

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: Ie875bbaae191cd0719db76cc375cd97d5bf90de7

Refactored tests for instance_fault_*

Moved tests to separate test case
Improved test assertions

blueprint db-api-tests

commit_message:
Put VM UUID to live migration error notification

If live migration encounter some exception before nova scheduler
cast message to nova compute, nova scheduler will set the VM state
to ERROR and send notification, but the notification do not include
VM UUID, this might cause some problem if some components want to
handle the notification since those components will not able to know
the VM UUID about the notification.

The solution is add UUID to live migration error notification so other
components can get the related notification correctly.

Fix bug 1182117

Change-Id: Id101f9e2a689a02d1604c12cd7677e0975bd7428

Change-Id: I86e72df622be756959f2600bbe28aaa50a7f7c57
Fixes: bug #1102461
'}, {'created': '2013-06-10 19:22:54.000000000', 'message': 'Quota summary graphs, added styling to indicate percentage full

At 80% the chart becomes orange indicating nearly full
At 100% the chart becomes red just as in the quota bar graphs
when creating new instances, volumes, etc.

Same color scheme across overview charts and progress bars when loading
instances, etc.

Fixes bug where reaching a limit when creating a new instance would
cause the progress bar to have square corners instead of rounded ones

Change-Id: I86e72df622be756959f2600bbe28aaa50a7f7c57
Fixes: bug #1102461
'}]
commit_message:
Quota summary graphs, added styling to indicate percentage full

At 80% the chart becomes orange indicating nearly full
At 100% the chart becomes red just as in the quota bar graphs
when creating new instances, volumes, etc.

Same color scheme across overview charts and progress bars when loading
instances, etc.

Fixes bug where reaching a limit when creating a new instance would
cause the progress bar to have square corners instead of rounded ones

Change-Id: I86e72df622be756959f2600bbe28aaa50a7f7c57
Fixes: bug #1102461

commit_message:
Floodlight doesn't have L3 functionality

Document that, when using BigSwitch/Floodlight plugin with Floodlight,
you need to use quantum-l3-agent since Floodlight doesn't
provide L3 functionality.

Cherry-picked from https://review.openstack.org/32080

Change-Id: Iaec2d58615530c21fdc0c6532a1f6786ff4f3a5a

commit_message:
Fix typos in network admin guide

As reported by Marco Consonni, there were a number of small typos in
the network admin guide. This patch fixes them.

fixes bug 1189091

Cherry-picked from https://review.openstack.org/32351

Change-Id: I84ad55ded9bd7e31e23b2318586966ea1b0e9640

commit_message:
Prepare base image before checking qcow2 disk size

The base image must be prepared before comparing the
disk size and base image size, otherwise builds will
fail if the image is not already cached locally.

Fixes bug #1182624

Change-Id: I51e49ebd32220746de522e3dde14224740d38589

commit_message:
Allow to hide config values from Puppet logs

Hide configuration value from Puppet logs if the secret parameter
is set to true.

Fixes: bug #1173322
Change-Id: I0815c3a1b84201fc7c39d221ff7f07fbd22fbcd4

Two other points:

2. I'm not sure about the separate policy for the standard get and create, I raised this question before, but it seems odd to me to allow a tenant to create, but not "get" or "delete".  Delete was explained and I can kinda see it, but not sure about "get".

commit_message:
Added policy check for backup operations

This patch adds policy checks for operations in the backup extension
consisting of create, delete, restore, get and get_all.  It also adds
policies into the policy.json files in the tests and etc directories.

Fixes Bug: 1188386

Change-Id: I847640051c5d25cebf06b8658b27d4b82603d796

commit_message:
Enhance unit test code coverage for availability zone

In current unit test code for availability zone, the update and
delete operation for AZ is missing. So this review submits two
test methods to test AZ update and delete.

Change-Id: Id98756351f0ecdf5405b9dfea2602a9aee0c5522

[{'created': '2013-06-12 23:23:38.000000000', 'message': "Add a default entry of sudo to execute root_helper.

The current execute function in processutils:execute doesn't
set a default root_helper.  Since we're only setting this when
run_as_root is True, it seems like it would be ok to add a default
of the currently accepted root_helper.

This won't impact folks that are currently using the code with
a different root_helper specified as they need to set this currently
anyway.

Change-Id: Iead33772326e63a26d533bd256b8caa30d6451bc
"}, {'created': '2013-06-12 23:25:23.000000000', 'message': "Add a default entry of sudo to execute root_helper.

The current execute function in processutils:execute doesn't
set a default root_helper.  Since we're only setting this when
run_as_root is True, it seems like it would be ok to add a default
of the currently accepted root_helper.

This won't impact folks that are currently using the code with

anyway.

Change-Id: Iead33772326e63a26d533bd256b8caa30d6451bc
"}]
commit_message:
Add a default entry of sudo to execute root_helper.

The current execute function in processutils:execute doesn't
set a default root_helper.  Since we're only setting this when
run_as_root is True, it seems like it would be ok to add a default
of the currently accepted root_helper.

This won't impact folks that are currently using the code with
a different root_helper specified as they need to set this currently
anyway.

Change-Id: Iead33772326e63a26d533bd256b8caa30d6451bc

commit_message:
Fix msg version type sent to cells RPC API

Regression fix from 6b16c8731c44e4a6c80b803f3e8afdd88386d577, cannot
build instances through cells.

The RPC dispatcher dislikes floats for version numbers.

bug 1190371

Change-Id: I18994ce8a524f88910cfe37c9b302296ce30102f

commit_message:
Exit w/ valid code when no servers are deleted.

This change updates do_delete in v1_1/shell.py to keep track of
deletion failures and raises an exception when all of the specified
servers cannot be deleted.  This in turn causes nova client to exit
with a correct exit code when no successful deletes occur.

Change-Id: I16ee7a4c754cf2e8add09a41becbcc37edc767ff
Fixes: bug #1185009

commit_message:
Remove unused method in VMware driver.

list_interface method in VMware  driver isn't used any where.

Fix bug #1187251

Change-Id: Idc7cee5ab1d0c5b4ebf57ca28511e3b7b4a85240

commit_message:
Fix race conditions with xenstore

xenapi code updates xenstore using _add_to_param_xenstore(), which has
to ensure a key doesn't exist before it can add the same key.  However,
if you have 2 calls at the same time, this is racey.

Fixes bug 1190026

Change-Id: I545b7a9fab0bc4c3749bc75387ed3f6ff27a512f

commit_message:
Use Python 3.x compatible octal literals

Python 3.x deprecated octal literals in the form
0755. Use 0o755  instead which works at least
with Python 2.6 and newer.

Change-Id: I6300e61d78619d8310e0ea7ddc8b46b94c1ef833

Fixes test_detail_servers in the config drive unittest where the wrong db
stub was set which resulted in an empty server list being returned.
Fixes asserTrue typo which was never executed because of the empty server
list bug

Change-Id: I160e91c55e60e3636804b4d2b31800386a21538d
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes test_config_drive unittest

Fixes test_detail_servers in the config drive unittest where the wrong db
stub was set which resulted in an empty server list being returned.
Fixes asserTrue typo which was never executed because of the empty server
list bug

Change-Id: I160e91c55e60e3636804b4d2b31800386a21538d

which expected from this method.

commit_message:
Add Instance.info_cache

This adds our first nested object: the InstanceInfoCache at
Instance.info_cache.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I2dd8727bbe38eadd080e9ea1ef9feabc2fa50520

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-18 10:25:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-05-18 10:27:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-18 10:29:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29635/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/1725 : SUCCESS in 1m 32s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29635/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/1500/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 38s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29635/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/1349 : SUCCESS in 1m 15s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29635/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/1684 : SUCCESS in 2m 16s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29635/2/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/1685 : SUCCESS in 2m 01s
'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-05-20 15:28:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hmm, I don't really like that we change the semantics of exec_dirs (now to be used as path for executed commands AND KillFilter target PID process match checks), nor the fact that we add exec_dirs in the contract of the match() method for every filter.

In particular, I think you may want to kill executables placed in less-trusted directories that you'd prefer to exclude from the root-run exec_dirs.

How about considering, if the KillFilter target is not anchored to /, that any target with that name in $PATH is fine ? That would avoid having to modify the documented match() contract and avoid overloading the meaning of exec_dirs."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-05-27 21:10:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I wonder why we should restrict it to $PATH then at all instead of simply accepting any binary (perhaps not writeable by non-root) to be killed that matches the given name, if name doesn't start with /."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-05-27 21:10:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

will reimplement to check for $PATH instead'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-05-28 09:08:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Accepting any executable named X is like accepting anything. Restricting to executables residing in root-writeable directories is better but still not as strong as relying on $PATH.

I think it's safe to use $PATH for non-anchored values and keep the possibility to specify a fully-anchored value to catch corner cases (like executables living in weird directories)."}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2013-05-31 21:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-31 21:07:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/29635/3/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/1869 : SUCCESS in 1m 24s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/29635/3/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/1644/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 23s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29635/3/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/1493 : SUCCESS in 1m 23s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29635/3/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/1828 : SUCCESS in 2m 26s
- http://logs.openstack.org/29635/3/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/1829 : SUCCESS in 2m 08s
'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2013-06-03 12:23:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Handle relative path arguments in Killfilter

KillFilter currently expects an absolute path
to be specified for the process name to kill. This
is inconvenient when the exact location of the running
binary is not known or differs accross installs.

Extend KillFilter to accept also commands in $PATH
to be killed if the given argument is not absolute.

Change-Id: I6b90206b587ff3f949af2c256a78ca21af31867a

commit_message:
Allow to override local_setttings.py template

Add the ability to override the location of the template
used to generate local_setttings.py configuration file.

This could be useful in situations where the provided template
isn't flexible enough to allow the configuration of some settings.

The value still defaults to 'horizon/local_settings.py.erb'.

Change-Id: I8dca1324324b5c96487b9e900b1fe89a38943dcd

commit_message:
Update to the latest stevedore

Use a version of stevedore that does not try to
install distribute.

The requirements change is in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32738/

Change-Id: I74bc6013710965401b7e64abc8827a46c817fd56
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Fix nova-compute fails to start if quantum is down

When nova-compute starts it needs to check the state of instances that
were previously running and needs to query quantum. Previously, if
it queried quantum and quantum raised an error or was unreachable
nova-compute would terminate. This patch adds a retry loop to prevent
this from happening.

Fixes bug 1186357

Change-Id: I0d865e464f7bf60a0b6dc4ca8a42436d16e29790

Implement metadata update.

Metadata can be specified as a file containing JSON or as a
command line parameter.

Change-Id: I7a6d35c3a3a204b2c7a6a632a5ae0ae2f32e8b3e

https://github.com/openstack/heat/commit/8e4938525793fb601c7372bf9bcb69fe33ebecb3 I guess you should hunt that bug and Zane down to see why it was changed.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-12 05:37:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

that change just says that it is a sync with versions in oslo-incubator.

This is a sync with the project-wide requirements.

Possibly openstack/requirements needs greenlet>=0.3.2 for https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo/+bug/1097203 ?'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-06-12 07:41:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Don't merge this, we removed the workaround for the old broken version of greenlet yesterday, so we have to bump openstack/requirements instead"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-06-12 07:46:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Here's the heat commit removing the workaround:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32428/

The old version of greenlet (pre 0.3.2) inherits GreenletExit from Exception, as described in 1097203, and we really don't want to regress to that behavior, as on delete greenthreads randomly fail to get killed.  Everywhere should be using >= 0.3.2"}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-12 21:07:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

openstack/requirements needs an update to greenlet>=0.3.2 instead (I won't be submitting that change)"}]

commit_message:
Require greenlet>=0.3.1 instead of 0.3.2

This aligns the greenlet version with openstack/requirements.

Change-Id: I2bbc2e2a54932a121f7079b2e4f8d034f3e07449

'}, {'account_id': 1343, 'date': '2013-06-09 08:14:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Grizzly packages available in the Ubuntu Cloud Archive for Ubuntu 12.04 LTS were backported from Ubuntu 13.04 and not backported from Ubuntu 12.10 like it's written in the documentation now.

Ubuntu 13.04 is not a testing version but the current stable version non-LTS since 25 April :
https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Releases"}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2013-06-09 23:53:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Erwan, you are of course correct :)

I agree also that the line in the documentation referencing 12.10 is misleading.

However, I think that in clarifying everything (and noting that similar objectives can be achieved with 13.04), we have to take into account that we've not actually tested this instructions with anything other than 12.04 :)"}, {'account_id': 1343, 'date': '2013-06-11 20:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 20:28:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Add missing tests for nova.db.api.network_*.

Added new tests for nova.db.api.network_*.
Moved existent tests for nova.db.api.network_* into NetworkTestCase.
Removed unused and invalid method network_get_all_by_instance().

blueprint test-db-api

Change-Id: Ib06135138d846f50f1aad1277afadf7639522226

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: Idb465068d25433582b8579a3ea96293f23368708

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 00:32:56.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Use Instance Objects for Start/Stop

This WIP patch shows how the Instance object can be used for the
start and stop operations. The EC2 code works, but is a little
messy because it's harder to isolate changes than the openstack
one, but it should be reasonable until more is done and the
entire thing can be converted to objects.

Note that something still needs to be done with object
import/registration before this can be put into the tree, but
that's fairly minor.

Related to bp/unified-internal-objects

Change-Id: I3c8d9cba07d34097a279502062906de802d19d1f
"}, {'created': '2013-05-23 01:53:29.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Use Instance Objects for Start/Stop

This WIP patch shows how the Instance object can be used for the
start and stop operations. The EC2 code works, but is a little
messy because it's harder to isolate changes than the openstack
one, but it should be reasonable until more is done and the
entire thing can be converted to objects.

Note that something still needs to be done with object
import/registration before this can be put into the tree, but
that's fairly minor.

Related to bp/unified-internal-objects

Change-Id: I3c8d9cba07d34097a279502062906de802d19d1f

commit_message:
Use Instance Objects for Start/Stop

This patch makes the start and stop operations use the Instance
object instead of passing SQLA-derived dicts over RPC. Until
something more sophisticated is needed (and developed), it also
adds a nova.object.register_all() function which just triggers
imports of all the object models so that they are registered.
When adding a new object type, that register function should be
updated appropriately.

Related to bp/unified-object-model

Change-Id: I3c8d9cba07d34097a279502062906de802d19d1f

commit_message:
Install arping for quantum-network-node.

We're missing a helper used by the Quantum l3 agent - installing it
fixes bug 1182710.

Change-Id: I404b628eaa40d8b160e3c29b1683280c129eaeeb

commit_message:
The use_floating_ip flag implemented.

* it have the following behaviour - take the first fixed and floating ips and then use them rely on the flag value.

Change-Id: Ia0584b3cc836c69a433547f26663fb14b20db050

"}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-04-08 10:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-08 10:45:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/5/check/gate-nova-pep8/24218 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/5/check/gate-nova-docs/18451 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/5/check/gate-nova-python26/19859 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/5/check/gate-nova-python26-rhel6/532 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/5/check/gate-nova-python27/19947 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/11876 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/11591 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/17648 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/5/check/gate-nova-pylint/10236 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-04-08 15:25:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Interesting idea

At the very least, I'd like to see a more explicit explanation of what the criteria are for a valid reason, either via the blueprint spec or in documentation. Also, I might be mistaken, but I think this is one of those patches that warrants a "DocImpact" in the commit message. Maybe others can weigh in?

Finally, the more I think about it, the more I'd prefer to see reason either treated more like the state fields on an instance; an enumeration of reasonable values that are consistent. I'm trying to think of engineers and support staff that may have to look at this field and try to discern what it means. A documented catalog of entries seems easier to follow, in my opinion, plus being able to enter anything (within 20 characters) might leave the reason open to interpretation.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-08 22:49:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Matt,

I think you might be missing the operational concept motivating this change.

On a large system with 100's or 1000's of services at any one time there are a number of services disabled while various issues are worked through.   There may also be services that have been reserved for various reasons (dedicated testing, reserve capacity, etc).   Without some form of tag this quickly becomes a nightmare and error prone to administer.

This isn't a known list of software states like the life cycle of an instance, its an optional way to provide a (very) short commentary on why a particular service has been disabled by a manual action. As such its not possible to enumerate all of the possible reasons that might lead to an operator needing to disable a service.  

A very common usage would be to just use this field as a reference to a ticket ID in the incident tracking system.   

Making this a restricted list of reasons would impose too many constraints on the way the different people want to run their systems - and many would end up having to select the catch-all "other" reason.

Phil'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-04-09 12:46:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-04-09 12:46:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-04-09 12:53:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Matt
you are right about the DocImpact, the patch set 6 has that in the commit message.
If we use a catalog for reasons you can't use it in the scenario described by Phil (logging ticket ID) which is a really common scenario and a real use case.
Maybe if I change the name of the method to "is_valid_format_for_reason", its purpose is clearer?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-09 13:29:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/6/check/gate-nova-pep8/24276 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/6/check/gate-nova-docs/18502 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/6/check/gate-nova-python26/19910 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/6/check/gate-nova-python26-rhel6/574 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/6/check/gate-nova-python27/19998 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/12031 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/11746 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/17824 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/26020/6/check/gate-nova-pylint/10278 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-04-22 20:32:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm with Matt on this one. I really feel like 20 characters is too short to be free form (is really something that needs a subset of values if it's really that short). So the 20 character limit is just taking an existing vendor implementation and pushing it in.

I think in the general upstream case we should have it either be a restricted list, or something much larger. It might also be better to be like system metadata, so it's really a side table that lets you add more than just the 20 characters of value inline."}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-04-23 14:20:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Hi Sean, Matt and Phil

thank you very much for your feedbacks.

I understand that the 20 chars field is too short, this came out from our experience where we typically need to log a ref to a ticket number of our internal bug/ticketing system.
What do you think about the following:
1 - have a longer field (60 is long enough?)
2 - move the validation process to an external class in order to have the freedom to implement a custom validator, for example a validator that accepts a pre-defined set of values. By default the validator will check the syntax and the length of the reason as-is in my original proposal.

I am not totally convinced about the idea to have a side table, it seems to me that solution is overkill.
Maybe a further version of the same extension can introduce a new table to log more information, but as first step I think a simpler implementation could be better.
But that's my personal opinion and I am really interested in yours.

Again a couple of questions:
- If we agree to use an external class for the validation I am thinking to define the class name for the default validator in the config parameters, is that still allowed or do we have a better way?
- Is it correct to have this discussion here or is it better to move it in the blueprint's whiteboard?

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-04-23 15:27:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

@sean, unfortunately, SystemMetadata doesn't work here since that's for an instance. I don't think there is any per-service metadata at the moment.

I think Matt's suggestion of using an enumerated state like we do everywhere else is probably best. However, it's already hard to determine why, and I can certainly see some additional bit of information being useful in making that determination (i.e. a state combined with a free-form reason)."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-04-23 17:55:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

@dan right, I wasn't thinking system meta data per say, but an idea like it. I can imagine another team showing up with a different set of annotations they want on hosts."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-04-23 18:14:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

@sean, ah, I see yeah.

So, I'm not sure I think adding another table is warranted here without further justification and/or other examples. That said, moving to just an enumerated state value doesn't quite seem like enough either.

/me remains at +0"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-24 14:15:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Dan @Sean @Matt 

A 20 character text field seems to be too limited – I get that.

An enumeration type just won’t work against the wide variety of operational practices.   Suspending an service is a manual operation, and only the operator knows why they’re doing it.   We can’t anticipate what all the reasons will be, so we’ll end up with an “other” category that will then need a text field to explain it ;-)

There may be other metadata that people want to capture about a service, but as Dan says we don’t really have any concrete examples for that, and  I really think puts us in danger here of letting a simple but valuable change morph into something more complex than in needs to be.

So can’t we just bring this to a close now by making the text field longer?   varchar(255) still seems to be quite popular in the DB, and is long enough for a short poem if folks are so inclined.      A simple text field now is easily migrated to service_metadata if at some point in the future we have a more solid reason for that.

We have been trying to get this in for quite a long time now – we already have it as a fork on our production systems and trust me it really is a valuable addition.  

Cheers,
Phil'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-04-24 16:59:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Phil - agree with basically everything you said.

I do think that an enumerated state is a reasonable thing, which when combined with a variable reason, would help identify certain problems:

 1. Haven't heard from the host recently
 2. Time on host is out of sync
 3. DB schema version mismatch
 4. Can't talk to the hypervisor
 5. Other

The first being "host is dead" and 2-4 being "the host is alive, but something is wrong", which seems a useful distinction from a UI perspective.

But, if we can't agree on that, I definitely think a varchar(255) is better than what we have now :)'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-24 17:35:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Dan: I think when we have bad conditions like the ones you mention being detected by Nova itself (and the service mgmt stuff discussed at the might move us towards that I guess assuming it gets implements in H) then adding a enum along side the description might make sense - but not before ;-)'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-04-24 21:32:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Presumably whatever is setting the host as disabled has some idea of why it wants to do so.  I like the idea of having some predefined states plus a free form field."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-25 14:08:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Russell

I agree with your observation that "whatever is setting the host as disabled has some idea of why it wants to do so" - but the issue is that at the moment that whatever is a System Admin (this is still a manual process), not something in the Nova code.   On that basis there is no way to anticipate in an enumeration type all of the possible reasons they may have.   In effect you'd be saying to the opertaors "You're now only allowed to disable a service for one of these reasons" - and I think that's more like adding a unwelcome restriction to the system rather than enhancing it.

I can think of dozens of different reasons we've had over the last year, and its an ever growing list.  If we code this in as enumeration type then we risk forever extending the extension as we add new values.

With a simple free text field, if someone wants to impose a parseable format (for example if they're linking this to an external system) then they can do all of that logic outside of Nova. 

At the point where Nova starts to automagically enable and disable services then there's a case for an enumeration field (or at least a predefined set of System test strings) - but there is no such mechanism in place today.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-04-25 14:27:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Phil,

I think that we're thinking of the case where a service is disabled automatically by the scheduler because it hasn't heard from the node recently, or when a service disables itself because of a time skew problem. You seem to be talking about an admin user disabling the service, is that right? If so, can't "ADMIN" be one of the states in the enumeration to solve that particular problem?'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-04-25 15:54:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Actually we are using this feature just in "human and manual" mode: there is some operator who decides to disable a service and log, in the reason field, a reference to a ticket number of our ticketing system.
If the scheduler or some other non-human actor is disabling a service automatically, I think that the chance to have a proliferation of unstructured values is low as an automatic process has to use a list of predefined values.
Does it make sense?
My second concern is that if we introduce a predefined list we have to add one more call to get the list of accepted values, and if you think to our use case described above, this could be a big restriction and I'd expect to see most of the disabled services disabled by the /os-services/disable call without the indication of a reason.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-25 15:55:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

@Dan

I see some of the confusion now.

AFAIK The service never gets disabled because it hasn't checked in for some time. There is a derived *status* that is used by the scheduler and reported in the service list as XXX or :-)  - but that's separate from the enabled/disables state which is a addional layer of filtering, and (aside from configuring the initial state of new services) is only ever changed by a manual operation.

There was talk at the summit of making changes so that a node will change its status based on time drift, but AFAIK there is no code around this today

Phil"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-25 16:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@Dan (cont - sorry, fat fingers :-( )

In the system with no automatic disabling of services every reason would in effect be "ADMIN" with all of the info in the text field - That's why I see the enum as not useful at this point in time.

When we have something in the code doing the disables then yes fine, make that an enum.  But I don't want to wait for that to be developed before we cover this basic case.

Cheers,
Phil'}, {'account_id': 6172, 'date': '2013-04-25 19:53:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

One question +  as I know, even for such trivial migrations we should add test in test_migrations.py ..'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-04-26 12:44:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

@boris I replied to your question. As soon as we close the open points about this change I'll submit a new patch and I'll add the test for the db migration.

I like the patch as a whole:

 * It'll need to update the DB migration number from 177 to 178 before it can land

I imagine some of field values we'd use it for as:

 * SPARE
 * Crashed twice in 24 hours - customers migrated off 2013-05-06 - needs testing and re-burn-in
 * Part of experiment X - see ticket number 207143
 * Two drives missing

So a 255 char field is perfect.

If someone wants to use a predefined list, they can easily do it with a set of client side scripts like:

 * make_spare.sh compute1 compute2
 * activate_spare.sh compute1"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-06 19:17:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I like the idea.  Unfortunately, the prevailing sentiment is that you need to define a new extension for this sort of added functionality, in order to advertise to clients the enhancement to the API.  See the extended_floating_ips.py and floating_ips.py  extensions for one way in which this could be done…'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-05-16 09:06:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@kevin thanks for your comment.
My understanding is that we want to avoid the proliferation of extensions, in order to achieve that there is the proposal to add a version number to each extension.
If I am right this kind of change should be a new version of the extension but to do that we need the new extensions framework for v3 API.
I am following all the big efforts around this topic and I saw that the new framework just landed few days ago (https://review.openstack.org/27276).
Is that correct?

My plan is to get this change merged as soon as possible and then work on porting this extension from v2 to v3.
I know that seems to do the work twice, but I 'd prefer to proceed step-by-step: so get it merged wait for a while to see if other suggestions or improvements come out and then porting it using the new framework.

Please also consider that when I started to work on this change the general feeling was that we had too many extensions and "extensions of extensions" and that was an issue, so I tried to design this change to not change the original behaviour.

Does that make sense to you? 
Maybe I am completely wrong and I misunderstood the API roadmap and strategy, if so please help me to understand.

Thank you'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-16 11:54:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

@andrea

However, we don't have extension versioning today. How could nova client know if /v2/{tenant_id}/os-services/disable-log-reason is a valid REST url in an arbitrary environment?

Today our only lever for this is GET /extensions. So if GET /extensions returning os-services needs to mean one set of REST services and expected data back.

Please respin as a new extension, then it's ok. v3 efforts are to give us versioning in the extension so we don't have to do this in the future."}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-05-16 15:47:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

As per IRC chat I am going to create a new extension with the new functionalities and leave the original extension as-is.

The new extension will have the following calls
- A PUT for disable a service and specify a reason field
- A GET to get the list of services + the reason field

The new extensions doesn't support the enable action.
For enabling a service we need to use the original extension, is that acceptable or is it better to replicate the enable action in the new extension?
I don't like duplication I'd prefer to add just the new functionalities.

Please let me know.
Thanks"}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-05-17 17:35:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agree with Sean's thoughts

So Andrea, about your idea, yes, the methods calls are these two that you listed.

About how to implement that, sadly api v2 seems to me awful to extend when you want to post or update, just works fine with GET...

So I think there is 3 reasonable ways to do it here:
1 - Extend the os-services (the same way we would do to servers) and just offer the 2 new methods. I believe that you would have to create an update method which would copy most of os-services update method but with a return (and so the response would come back to the user I think) right after update the db instead of allow os-services to execute it's own update after that. If the new extension is not loaded os-services would deal with it.
The problem here is once you find some bug, or change something on the update method that would not be synced between both of them, so that would generate creepy bugs =S.

2 - Create a new entry point like /v2/{tenant_id}/service-disable which would just contain this two actions *related to disable* (turn off a service with a reason and get details of disabled services showing the reason).

or 
3 - Add the new entry point and copy all the method logic from os-services to your new extension... maybe creating a servicesutils with the common parts of os-services and the new extension.

Due to the sync issue between os-services.update and new-extension.update I would go with #2, but just suggesting, of course.

APIv3 in other hand will offer a discovery/versioning that will help this kind of situation."}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-05-21 12:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 1865, 'date': '2013-05-21 12:39:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-03 16:49:05.000000000', 'message': 'Give a way to save why a service has been disabled.

Implements blueprint record-reason-for-disabling-service

We added a short field to the service table to log a reason when a service has
been disabled.
We modified the API extensions os-services:
- adding a new method to disable a service and specify a reason for that.
PUT /v2/{tenant_id}/os-services/disable-log-reason
- adding a new method to get the list of services with reason information it
  that exists
GET /V2/{tenant_id}/os-services/detail

Change-Id: I87a4affc45160796ff11c7b03e591e6aba73d62a

been disabled.
We added a new API extension called os-extended-services. The new extension has
two main method:
- A method for disabling a service and specify a reason for that.
PUT /v2/{tenant_id}/os-extended-services/disable-log-reason
- a method to get the list of services with reason information it
  that exists

commit_message:
Give a way to save why a service has been disabled.

Implements blueprint record-reason-for-disabling-service

We added a field to the service table to log a reason when a service has
been disabled.
We added a new API extension called os-extended-services. The new extension
will extend the os-services extension adding:
- A method for disabling a service and specify a reason for that.

PUT /v2/{tenant_id}/os-services/disable-log-reason

When the os-extended-extension is loaded the call:

GET /V2/{tenant_id}/os-services
will return the list of services with reason information it that exists.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I87a4affc45160796ff11c7b03e591e6aba73d62a

[{'created': '2013-05-23 17:37:57.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: implement get_console_output for XCP/XenServer

Inspired by this previous change:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17959/

If an administrator has enabled the logging of guest
consoles on XCP/XenServer, this enables nova to return
the last MB of those logs to the user.

The management of the logs on the server is a little
tricky, and a helper script to setup the management
will be a later patch.

DocImpact
part of blueprint xenapi-server-log

Change-Id: I23c83bcf8c648cc2714a0c78951acc29a16d5c31

commit_message:
xenapi: implement get_console_output for XCP/XenServer

If an administrator has enabled the logging of guest
consoles on XCP/XenServer, this enables nova to return
the last MB of those logs to the user.

The management of the logs on the server is a little
tricky, and will be sorted in a later patch.

Change was based on this previous idea:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17959/

DocImpact
Part of blueprint xenapi-server-log
Change-Id: I23c83bcf8c648cc2714a0c78951acc29a16d5c31

commit_message:
Start using Hacking

Instead of globally disabling hacking warnings, only
blacklist those that trigger currently. These can
be cleaned up in a followup commit.

Change-Id: I4ea3d96b336481a9b29053b87bd480945efb4267

what exactly is broken? was there a bug report? do we need a test?"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-06-07 17:25:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's actually kind of obvious if you read the patch.

- This code has been imported from Nova, where it was run from a different path directory, so that's the first diff, let's fix BASEDIR to match it add more ..
- getfqdn() isn't used (anymore?) in nova to get hostname, gethostname() is used instead."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-06-07 17:26:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There's no bug report, and there never was any unit test on this script, so don't blame me.

I'm the one trying to merge copy/pasted code and improve it here."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:52:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Add a funcutils file for working with functions.

Multiple projects are starting to copy around the various
function utilities that exist in nova and elsewhere. It
would seem appropriate that there exist a helper file in
oslo that was used instead as a central place for this type
of code.

Change-Id: Ia83f26da16b0c868506ecf90e1aaf8affecf3617

commit_message:
Part of REST client for Savanna

* Implemented REST client for node group templates
* Moved implementation for images and plugins there as well

Change-Id: I412fe8eb7f7856fd49c16055fa49358b1b65e175

[{'created': '2013-06-11 21:55:36.000000000', 'message': "Re-set default sql_connection and sqlite_db.

The defaults seem to have been lost in the migration to Oslo's
DB code.  Re-set them to pre-grizzly defaults.

Fixes bug: #1190036

Change-Id: I7fca70e67d67905b15c2faaa745a86e957bec06e
"}]
commit_message:
Re-set default sql_connection and sqlite_db.

The defaults seem to have been lost in the migration to Oslo's
DB code.  Re-set them to pre-grizzly defaults.

Fixes bug: #1190036

Change-Id: I7fca70e67d67905b15c2faaa745a86e957bec06e

commit_message:
Fix db.models.Instance description

DB models definition should be up-to-date with DB schema obtained after
applying of migrations. Currently, there are no tests enforcing this and it's
really hard to analyze what indexes should be added, and what indexes we have
at the moment.

So the first step is it to fix all models, and add missing descriptions about
Indexes and UniqueConstraints in __table_args__ and use explicit 'nullable'
parameter in columns description.

Add missing 'nullable' parameters to all Columns

Add empty __table_args__ parameter to Table

Add 6 missing indexes in Instance model definition.

blueprint db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: I01025789f00dcf058754ee1def726e3b48ec7fda

commit_message:
Fix db.models.Certificate description

DB models definition should be up-to-date with DB schema obtained after applying of
migrations. Currently, there are no tests enforcing this and it's really hard to
analyze what indexes should be added, and what indexes we have at the moment.

So the first step is it to fix all models, and add missing descriptions about
Indexes and UniqueConstraints in __table_args__ and use explicit 'nullable'
parameter in columns description.

Add missing 'nullable' parameters to all Columns

Add empty __table_args__ parameter to Table

Add 2 missing indexes in Certificate model definition.

blueprint db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: Ida607c2b8899e145116d46cffdc49b7176b05550

commit_message:
Fix db.models.ComputeNode description

DB models definition should be up-to-date with DB schema obtained after
applying of migrations. Currently, there are no tests enforcing this and it's
really hard to analyze what indexes should be added, and what indexes we have
at the moment.

So the first step is it to fix all models, and add missing descriptions about
Indexes and UniqueConstraints in __table_args__ and use explicit 'nullable'
parameter in columns description.

Add missing 'nullable' parameters to all Columns

Add empty __table_args__ parameter to Table

There is no indexes in ComputeNode model definition.

blueprint db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: I13c92bdd33eede97bb7b2fc45cbedca556992060

I'm fine with doing this as a stepping stone to separating them out in the database (and, in fact everywhere else except in heat-cfn-api). A couple of suggestions though:

- Let's put the definitions at module level.
- Let's call this module "state" or "action" instead of "utils". That way people could import it and refer to state.CREATE. Instead of having a copy in every object.

commit_message:
engine : Add StateMixin state-attribute class

Add a utility mixin class which provides state related attributes

This allows us to avoid duplication between classes which care about
state (e.g resource.Resource and parser.Stack), and also to avoid
lots of hardcoded-attribute bloat when we start adding (potentially
many) additional states related to the stack actions work.

Change-Id: I7a4f3ce7b8460246d2aa34df10182f94e4dd1447

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-12 16:30:19.000000000', 'message': 'Expose most common QueuePoll parameters from SQLAlchemy

Fixes bug 1160442

The defualt parameters are used unless otherwise configured. This
is applicable for:
 - pool_size
 - max_overflow
 - pool_timeout

By increasing the pool_size and the max_overflow and lowering the timeout
the issue reported in the bug is resolved.

NOTE: the configuration values enable the user to make use of the default
QueuePool tuning values.

(cherry picked from commit 725d636da5959aee1954a8e8d5ff383d2a8b7bb9)

Change-Id: Ic258442531a2caf2db4f05c4ddd6fbfb0c180f17
'}]
commit_message:
Expose most common QueuePoll parameters from SQLAlchemy

Fixes bug 1160442

The defualt parameters are used unless otherwise configured. This
is applicable for:
 - pool_size
 - max_overflow
 - pool_timeout

By increasing the pool_size and the max_overflow and lowering the timeout
the issue reported in the bug is resolved.

NOTE: the configuration values enable the user to make use of the default
QueuePool tuning values.

(cherry picked from commit 725d636da5959aee1954a8e8d5ff383d2a8b7bb9)

Change-Id: Ic258442531a2caf2db4f05c4ddd6fbfb0c180f17

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-12 13:32:24.000000000', 'message': 'python3: fix imports compatibility

Python3 reorganized the standard library and moved several functions
to different modules. Six provides a consistent interface
to them through the fake six.moves module.

However, the urlparse, urllib2, etc modules have been combined
into one module which Six does not support so do it the old
fashioned way.

Change-Id: Ieb7cc7ee2a4a97807873cfe2fc3fa0a5cf3c3980
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
python3: fix imports compatibility

Python3 reorganized the standard library and moved several functions
to different modules. Six provides a consistent interface
to them through the fake six.moves module.

However, the urlparse, urllib2, etc modules have been combined
into one module which Six does not support so do it the old
fashioned way.

Change-Id: Ieb7cc7ee2a4a97807873cfe2fc3fa0a5cf3c3980
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

[{'created': '2013-06-10 21:11:39.000000000', 'message': "Remove direct call to utils.execute.

The executes calls in the base driver class
are set up to use the exectue enginge passed in on
init.  There are a couple of methods that call
utils.execute directly, and as a result you end
up not using the expected execute engine when
you pass in something other than default for these
two calls.

We'd like to get away from the local execute altogether
and use the OpenStack common version only, so fix these
in driver.py and put the appropriate wrapper around them.

Change-Id: Ibc17c9c2a0c8f27b4533ed86377a66ce668aeab5
"}]
commit_message:
Remove direct call to utils.execute.

The executes calls in the base driver class
are set up to use the exectue enginge passed in on
init.  There are a couple of methods that call
utils.execute directly, and as a result you end
up not using the expected execute engine when
you pass in something other than default for these
two calls.

We'd like to get away from the local execute altogether
and use the OpenStack common version only, so fix these
in driver.py and put the appropriate wrapper around them.

Change-Id: Ibc17c9c2a0c8f27b4533ed86377a66ce668aeab5

commit_message:
Enables the multibackend Cinder tests in tempest when useful.

The change adds in lib/tempest an optional dependency on the var
$CINDER_MULTI_LVM_BACKEND which, if set, enables the multibackend
tests in the tempest config.

Change-Id: Iccafd00f5adabbbc2309fa72664bf29440744d91

commit_message:
Fix functional tests with keystone.

- Make sure storage_url is string and not unicode or the unicode
  no_safe_quote test will not get this nicely.
- Fixes bug 1190190.

Change-Id: I945f2b94f2063b836c10131fa4bd57938ed48f3c

@nachi: I knew someone was going to bring that up. :)

The VXLAN referenced in that email is the upstream Linux kernel VXLAN support. That support can and should be aggregated across both the OVX and LinuxBridge plugins. The VXLAN support I'm adding here is the VXLAN which is embedded in OVS itself, and it will only work with OVS, not LinuxBridge. While confusing, I think there is a clear benefit to adding this code here into the OVS plugin since it's in a released version of OVS (1.10)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Great, I think we're on the same page, Bob! There is certiainly no reason that GRE and VXLAN networks could not exist at the same time in the context of the OVS plugin itself. In fact, a version of OVS which supports both could in fact translate between the two.

I want to offer my support for writing a VXLAN type driver for the ML2 plugin as well, I'll reach out to you off this review and see how I can help make this happen in H2 for the ML2 plugin.

Thanks for removing your -1 and for getting in sync with me here!"}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Bob, no worries on the -1, what you're proposing with regards to tunnel_type and the RPC messages makes sense to me. I'll take a look at this code in the morning and see what I can do there, reaching out to you for help as needed.

Also, the kernel VXLAN implementation should be wire compatible with the OVS implementation, though I've not tested this. I guess as part of the ML2 integration we'll test this out."}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 105, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Bob, the cloud tenant doesn't select the "type" of tunnel network, the cloud admin would do this when deploying the OpenStack cloud. I think given the fact that Open vSwitch natively supports VXLAN since release 1.10, exposing this functionality in the Open vSwitch plugin itself makes sense to me. Once we port the agents over to ML2, adding a VXLAN driver there and porting the agents is also a good thing. But for people who will not make use of ML2 in Havana but would like to utilize VXLAN with OVS, this would provide a solution for them.

At the end of the day, this won't get through with any -1 reviews. Please advise me how I can remove your -1 review.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Works for me

(1 inline comment)

I'm not sold on the idea of a generic tunnel network type that might be realized as either GRE or as VXLAN. I'd prefer to see these both supported as distinct network types. None of these details are visible to normal cloud tenants, so I don't see any issue with administrators explicitly choosing to support either GRE, VXLAN, or both.

Also, given that the initial ml2 implementation seems close to being merged, I think its worth considering implementing the server side support for VXLAN as an ml2 TypeDriver rather than in the legacy openvswitch (and linuxbridge) plugins. I'm more than willing to help with that if there is interest."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: No score

(1 inline comment)

I don't intend to block getting VXLAN support into the monolithic openvswitch (or linuxbridge) plugin(s). Focusing on ml2 for the server side was just a suggestion, although I am interested in the community's view on adding significant new features to plugins that we may also be starting to deprecate in the same release. But I do want to ensure that the VXLAN support in the L2 agent(s) will work with ml2 in havana, and that a corresponding ml2 TypeDriver gets written soon after ml2 is merged. The contents of the RPC messages are what's key here.

My main concern turns out to have been a silly misinterpretation of the subset of code I had briefly looked at. I now see that you are not adding a new "generic tunnel network type", but are instead adding a new vxlan network type alongside the gre network type, just as I was advocating. I therefore apologize, and am removing my -1.

I can certainly imagine ml2 deployments that involve both gre and vxlan networks (or network segments) existing at the same time. Even with the legacy openvswitch plugin, I could imagine transitioning tenant_network_type from gre to vxlan, so that existing gre tenant networks would continue to work while new tenant networks use vxlan. Is there any reason gre and vxlan networks can't be made to coexist?'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Kyle - one more thing. I had not been tracking this review, and have tried to quickly catch up on the previous discussion. Can you explain what would prevent this OVS-based VXLAN implementation in the openvswitch agent from interoperating with a kernel-based VXLAN implementation in the linuxbridge agent? Don't these implement the same wire protocol? If there are no blockers, I'd like to make sure both agent's VXLAN implementations can work concurrently with the same VxlanTypeDriver in ml2 (and each other for the same network)."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

Kyle, I hate to do this, but I need to give this a -1 again. The tunnel endpoint management RPCs need to be defined such that GRE and VXLAN tunnel endpoints can coexist and be kept separate from each other. Adding a network_type attribute to the tunnel management RPC messages might be sufficient, with it defaulting to gre when not present for backward compatibility."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

I've still got some concerns about the tunnel_type for the tunnel endpoint management. It does not seem correct for the agent to be using the server's tenant_network_type configuration variable for this, since not all networks are tenant networks. 

We need to decide whether tunnel endpoints are inherently global or network-type-specific. If they are network-type-specific, its fine for the openvswitch plugin to only support one tunnel type at a time, but this should not be based on tenant_network_type. Even if the openvswitch plugin is limited to supporting a single tunnel type. The openvswitch agent should be able to simultaneously handle tunnelled networks of different types when used with ml2."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Kyle,

I agree passing the tunnel_type in the tunnel endpoint management RPCs is not sufficient to enable the agent to support multiple tunnel types simultaneously. Either separate tunnel bridges for each tunnel type or more complex flow rules would also be needed. Therefore, it does make sense to remove tunnel_type from the RPCs for now. If and when multiple tunnel types are eventually made to work with ml2, the tunnel_type can be added back to the RPCs if needed.

The main issue I have with the current patch set is the agent's use of config.OVS.tenant_network_type to determine the tunnel type. There are three issues with this:

1) This configuration variable is not necessarily set on the compute and network nodes. Deployment tools so far only need to set it (and network_vlan_ranges) on the server node(s).

2) Its possible (although maybe unlikely) that provider gre or vxlan networks would be used with tenant_network_type set to something else like vlan or none. 

3) With ml2, there is no config.OVS.tenant_network_type config variable, and the openvswitch-agent must continue to work with the ml2 plugin as well as the openvswitch plugin.

If the agent needs to know which tunnel type to support, that should be configured for the agent, regardless of which plugin it is used with, with something like config.AGENT.tunnel_type. Alternatively, it might be reasonable for the agent to simply use the first tunnel network_type for which it tries to plug a port as its tunnel type, and avoid needing this configuration.

If the agent only supports a single tunnel type, it needs to log an error if its told to plug a port of a different tunnel network_type, and leave the port unplugged.

Finally, see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/quantum/+spec/ml2-portbinding for a description of how ml2 will be validating that an agent really can provide the requested connectivity when a port is being plugged. This will use configuration information in the agents_db that the agent sends to the server. It would make sense for the agent to report the tunnel type(s) that it supports using this mechanism, so the ml2 plugin can take this into account when establishing a port binding. 

To allow support for simultaneous tunnel types to be added in the future, the agent should report a list a tunnel types rather than just a single value. Given that, maybe config.AGENT.tunnel_types should be a list as well, and an error raised in the current agent implementation if multiple tunnel types are requested."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 27: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

This is relatively minor, but I think its worth making the tunnel_type configuration variable (and agent_db data) plural and a list now so backward compatibility can be maintained when the agent is enhanced to support multiple tunnel types concurrently. For now, just log an error and exit if multiple tunnel types are listed."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

OK, I would have preferred to set things up from the start for supporting multiple tunnel types, and just treat this as a current limitation, but this can definitely be taken care of later.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27:

I forgot to mention that configuring a single "tunnel_type" vs. a list of "tunnel_types" is my only remaining concern. Configuration and RPCs are two items, along with APIs, for which backwards compatibility needs to be maintained, so I think these are worth addressing now. Kyle, are you willing to make this change? Does anyone else feel strongly either way on this? I'm happy to give this a +2 if the consensus is to leave tunnel_type as-is for now and figure out some way tunnel_type and tunnel_types can co-exist later.'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Hi Kyle

Great job!
May be, you and Bob should talk :)
see http://markmail.org/message/rrw7bohkey3ts6n7'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

I think we need add a udp dest port in config, which is defaulted to 4789'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

can u point one URL for the ovs vxlan settings in BP description?"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

why not do it in this patch? I think it is not a big change.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2888, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

As you said kyle, this will not be compatible with ML2.

it seems that if you use this patch with ML2 that support both VXLan and GRE, the tunnel_sync call will lead to create vxlan and GRE interfaces. So if two networks share the same segmentation id, one with vxlan and one with GRE, since flow forward traffic in tun_id, this traffic would go in the two tunnels.

This could be addressed in another BP, but you may have to check that every tunnel that tunnel_sync returns and that tunnel_update sends, have the same type.

If we want to support both vxlan and gre, we could write flow by port and send traffic only to vxlan endpoint, or gre endpoint, depending on the network_type that the traffic comes from. Moreover, we could send traffic to endpoint that host the concerned network. This is something that is done in partial_mesh BP.'}, {'account_id': 2888, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

just had a deeper look and I saw that you use the ovs_db_v2.reserve_tunnel, so that two tunnels, even if they have different tunnel_type, can't have the same segmentation_id. so existing GRE tunnels can co-exist with new vxlan tunnel when you change your plugin.ini to use vxlan instead of gre. Apologize for that."}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: (4 inline comments)

Looks pretty good. A few small nits and I think this should be good to go.'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Nice work. Tested between two machines and works well.'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Minor typo, otherwise looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 6820, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22: (4 inline comments)

Didn't managed to test it yet, so please apologise if I misunderstood something.

I don't see where tunnel_type comes from in tunnel_sync, isn't some DB-related code missing?

It looks like it gradually replaces GRE tunnels by VXLAN tunnels between agents, is it the objective? (Which could make sense...). In that case, shouldn't old GRE tunnels be deleted if they exist?

One the other hand, if the objective is just to have a VXLAN POC that works on fresh installs and doesn't care about migration, wouldn't it be easier to just rely on tenant_network_type in both plugin and agents, and avoid overloading RPC (to ease current endpoint management port in ML2)?

Because if we manage to implement l2-population in ML2, we'll have to use per-port flow rules, and one of the side effects will be that we'll be able to support both network_type simultaneously, even if they use the same segmentation_id (see what has been done here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29376/2/quantum/plugins/openvswitch/agent/ovs_quantum_agent.py)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for VXLAN to the Open vSwitch plugin.

This commit adds support for utilizing the VXLAN tunneling protocol in versions
of Open vSwitch >= 1.10. This is configurable and will default to GRE if not
configured.

Note: The VXLAN functionality utilized here is what is implemented in Open
vSwitch itself, and is different than the VXLAN functionality in the
upstream Linux kernel.

Implements blueprint ovs-vxlan-lisp-tunnel

Change-Id: I45d49d5d6463e574922c7f50d6499c6bdb6c862c

'}, {'created': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for VXLAN to the Open vSwitch plugin.

This commit adds support for utilizing the VXLAN tunneling protocol in versions
of Open vSwitch >= 1.10. This is configurable and will default to GRE if not
configured. As part of this commit, it is possible to configure the UDP port
VXLAN will utilize as well. VXLAN and GRE cannot be configured at the same
time with this patch. Also note the RPC code has been updated to pass in
tunnel_type when configuring tunnel ports. This is in preparation for when
the OVS agent will run in the context of ML2.

Note: The VXLAN functionality utilized here is what is implemented in Open
vSwitch itself, and is different than the VXLAN functionality in the
upstream Linux kernel.

Implements blueprint ovs-vxlan-lisp-tunnel

Change-Id: I45d49d5d6463e574922c7f50d6499c6bdb6c862c
'}, {'created': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for VXLAN to the Open vSwitch plugin.

of Open vSwitch >= 1.10. This is configurable and will default to GRE if not
configured. As part of this commit, it is possible to configure the UDP port
VXLAN will utilize as well. VXLAN and GRE cannot be configured at the same
time with this patch. Also note the RPC code has been updated to pass in
tunnel_type when configuring tunnel ports. This is in preparation for when
the OVS agent will run in the context of ML2.

Note: The VXLAN functionality utilized here is what is implemented in Open
vSwitch itself, and is different than the VXLAN functionality in the
upstream Linux kernel.

Implements blueprint ovs-vxlan-lisp-tunnel

Change-Id: I45d49d5d6463e574922c7f50d6499c6bdb6c862c
'}, {'created': '2013-06-12 15:47:58.000000000', 'message': "Add support for VXLAN to the Open vSwitch plugin.

This commit adds support for utilizing the VXLAN tunneling protocol in versions
of Open vSwitch >= 1.10. This is configurable and will default to GRE if not
configured. As part of this commit, it is possible to configure the UDP port
VXLAN will utilize as well. VXLAN and GRE cannot be configured at the same
time with this patch. 2 new configuration file options are added to the AGENT
section of the config to support this: 'tunnel_type' and 'vxlan_udp_port'.
In addition, the agent no longer makes use of enable_tunneling, as this can
be determined if tunnel_type is set.

Note: The VXLAN functionality utilized here is what is implemented in Open
vSwitch itself, and is different than the VXLAN functionality in the
upstream Linux kernel.

Implements blueprint ovs-vxlan-lisp-tunnel

Change-Id: I45d49d5d6463e574922c7f50d6499c6bdb6c862c

In addition, the agent no longer makes use of enable_tunneling, as this can
be determined if tunnel_type is set.

Note: The VXLAN functionality utilized here is what is implemented in Open
vSwitch itself, and is different than the VXLAN functionality in the
upstream Linux kernel. The code validates both the userspace and kernel
pieces of OVS to verify if VXLAN functionality can be supported on the

commit_message:
Add support for VXLAN to the Open vSwitch plugin.

This commit adds support for utilizing the VXLAN tunneling protocol in versions
of Open vSwitch >= 1.10. This is configurable and will default to GRE if not
configured. As part of this commit, it is possible to configure the UDP port
VXLAN will utilize as well. VXLAN and GRE cannot be configured at the same
time with this patch. 2 new configuration file options are added to the AGENT
section of the config to support this: 'tunnel_type' and 'vxlan_udp_port'.
In addition, the agent no longer makes use of enable_tunneling, as this can
be determined if tunnel_type is set.

Note: The VXLAN functionality utilized here is what is implemented in Open
vSwitch itself, and is different than the VXLAN functionality in the
upstream Linux kernel. The code validates both the userspace and kernel
pieces of OVS to verify if VXLAN functionality can be supported on the
running system

Implements blueprint ovs-vxlan-lisp-tunnel

Change-Id: I45d49d5d6463e574922c7f50d6499c6bdb6c862c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-12 15:12:24.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure to remove auto delete ports from OFC in NEC plugin

When deleting a network, dhcp ports are removed automatically
in db_plugin. This causes a failure network deletion since the
corresponding port exists on OFC and the network on OFC cannot
be deleted unless a subnet on the network is deleted explicitly.
This commit gets auto-delete ports and delete the corresponding
ports on the controller before deleting the network.

Fixes bug #1190163

Change-Id: Ifffaa1a28b5fac0b0a98036a926550255cc25c9d
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure to remove auto delete ports from OFC in NEC plugin

When deleting a network, dhcp ports are removed automatically
in db_plugin. This causes a failure network deletion since the
corresponding port exists on OFC and the network on OFC cannot
be deleted unless a subnet on the network is deleted explicitly.
This commit gets auto-delete ports and delete the corresponding
ports on the controller before deleting the network.

Fixes bug #1190163

Change-Id: Ifffaa1a28b5fac0b0a98036a926550255cc25c9d

commit_message:
Bump kombu requirements

Now that we require msgpack, old version of kombu are not compatible
with msgpack<0.2 and breaks. So let's depend on versions of kombu that
supports msgpack>=0.2.

Fixes: bug 1134575

Change-Id: I910ff21f3df75e486816aea533396852eb3fbf16
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Remove distribute from the requires list.

We want to stop doing explicit depends on it, because it's causing
confusion with the setuptools merge.

Change-Id: I6e82ae9875db24fc3940aa119ab234657a6a2495

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-11 15:26:52.000000000', 'message': 'Pass content length to req.stream.read() in WSGI transport

This update modifies the WSGI transport driver so that it
always passes in a length when reading from the request
stream. This is necessary because WSGI servers are not
required to provide a stream that supports "read all"
semantics. For example, wsgiref will simply block if
read() is called without arguments.

Fixes: bug #1189648
Change-Id: I267e3bce36f0e11d931d9e9800bf3ad3aca7a804
'}]
commit_message:
Pass content length to req.stream.read() in WSGI transport

This update modifies the WSGI transport driver so that it
always passes in a length when reading from the request
stream. This is necessary because WSGI servers are not
required to provide a stream that supports "read all"
semantics. For example, wsgiref will simply block if
read() is called without arguments.

Fixes: bug #1189648
Change-Id: I267e3bce36f0e11d931d9e9800bf3ad3aca7a804

subject: Remove periodic watcher debug message.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 21:57:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/32639/1/check/gate-heat-pep8/3457 : SUCCESS in 1m 32s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32639/1/check/gate-heat-python26/3412 : SUCCESS in 3m 59s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32639/1/check/gate-heat-python27/3411 : SUCCESS in 1m 44s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32639/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/22376 : SUCCESS in 44m 44s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32639/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/22083 : SUCCESS in 56m 48s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32639/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/29632 : SUCCESS in 19m 33s
'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-06-12 09:18:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is *DEBUG* output, so IMHO, if you're running in an environment where you have over 100 stacks, you should probably just switch to INFO log level.

Possibly debug shouldn't be enabled by default in heat-engine.conf, or at least it should be sedded out for packaged versions of heat.

The problem with just deleting this, is we've had bugs where, for one reason or another, the periodic task wasn't firing, which means stuff like CloudWatch alarms (which drive scaling events etc etc) don't work - I for one still find this output useful when developing, so would prefer to not have it removed."}, {'account_id': 7253, 'date': '2013-06-12 14:13:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Ah, so I'm seeing so many of these messages because of how many stacks I have.  I'll clear out my stacks to resolve this.  Thanks for the explanation."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-11 20:59:45.000000000', 'message': 'Remove periodic watcher debug message.

Debug output is periodically flooded with over a hundred "Periodic
watcher task for stack" messages, making debug-mode much less useful.

Change-Id: I2245f88ca68b83c7dd2cd98a2e4fe47ef7c8dc14
'}]
commit_message:
Remove periodic watcher debug message.

Debug output is periodically flooded with over a hundred "Periodic
watcher task for stack" messages, making debug-mode much less useful.

Change-Id: I2245f88ca68b83c7dd2cd98a2e4fe47ef7c8dc14
