revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-06 15:42:46.000000000', 'message': 'scheduler: Fix an issue with wrappertasks and exceptions

Using a 'for' loop on a generator is incompatible with calling throw() on
it, because the latter causes the generator to advance to the next yield.
Consequently, ignoring an exception from a subtask in the parent task would
cause the next subtask to be skipped.

This issue does not affect any existing code to date.

The inner and outer loops should each be equivalent to the definition of
"yield from" (http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0380/#formal-semantics) in
PEP 380, with the following simplifications:
 - Assume that the throw() and close() methods exist
 - Don't support send()
 - Don't support return values (these are Python 3-only feature)

Change-Id: Ie29e68d4505f667f408b67b365c37511f73372fe
'}, {'created': '2013-06-07 18:48:50.000000000', 'message': 'scheduler: Fix an issue with wrappertasks and exceptions

Change-Id: Ie29e68d4505f667f408b67b365c37511f73372fe

commit_message:
scheduler: Fix an issue with wrappertasks and exceptions

Using a 'for' loop on a generator is incompatible with calling throw() on
it, because the latter causes the generator to advance to the next yield.
Consequently, ignoring an exception from a subtask in the parent task would
cause the next subtask to be skipped.

This issue does not affect any existing code to date.

The inner and outer loops should each be equivalent to the definition of
"yield from" (http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0380/#formal-semantics) in
PEP 380, with the following simplifications:
 - Assume that the throw() and close() methods exist
 - Don't support send()
 - Don't support return values (these are Python 3-only feature)

Change-Id: Ie29e68d4505f667f408b67b365c37511f73372fe

commit_message:
Improve Python 3.x compatibility

Per (proposed) Hacking H203 check, use the
non-deprecated except x as y: construct, which
works with any Python version >= 2.6

Change-Id: I42935ada01ea7487d76040832578e06ac8ad87dd

This is commit 15d8d698b7 in oslo-incubator.

Fixes bug 1185465

Don't log exceptions that happen during connection.close().  They're
not surprising (a closed socket can't be read or written), don't
require sysadmin attention, and provide red herrings in the logs
to distract from finding real root causes of problems.

Change-Id: Ia0e25fbc11094b5ad5d6d2cf7d0e786acb3df1f6
"}]
commit_message:
Silence exceptions from qpid connection.close() (from oslo)

This is commit 15d8d698b7 in oslo-incubator.

Fixes bug 1185465

Don't log exceptions that happen during connection.close().  They're
not surprising (a closed socket can't be read or written), don't
require sysadmin attention, and provide red herrings in the logs
to distract from finding real root causes of problems.

Change-Id: Ia0e25fbc11094b5ad5d6d2cf7d0e786acb3df1f6

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: I2ea9b54c3b745ad60d62cf26e2f53f40242d2848

Adding SVI support to the Cisco Nexus plugin

Adding support to create vlan SVI gateways on Cisco Nexus hardware switches.

[{'created': '2013-06-12 03:35:12.000000000', 'message': 'Fix assumed port has port_security_enabled

Previously if adding a security group to an instance it would fail
if the port did not contain port_security_enabled=True. This patch
also changes the unit tests so that networks by default are not
associated with port_security_enabled=True because this is only true
if a plugin is running the port_security extension.

Fixes bug 1189059

Change-Id: Ieebb7aafba01c18164b86a01a3c289a6957321e4
(cherry picked from commit eddab7ba0e45c47fa8503b29484ce296f46c0d27)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix assumed port has port_security_enabled

Previously if adding a security group to an instance it would fail
if the port did not contain port_security_enabled=True. This patch
also changes the unit tests so that networks by default are not
associated with port_security_enabled=True because this is only true
if a plugin is running the port_security extension.

Fixes bug 1189059

Change-Id: Ieebb7aafba01c18164b86a01a3c289a6957321e4
(cherry picked from commit eddab7ba0e45c47fa8503b29484ce296f46c0d27)

(1 inline comment)

Inline comment suggests a different way of enforcing the django 1.4 dependency."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2013-05-29 03:14:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Trying this out, it does seem to work as intended though I get a number of test failures (presumably because horizon master has broken compatability with django 1.4?).

Also, we need to have a broader discussion around CI supporting tests with multiple versions of dependencies--without setting some limits this sort of support matrix could grow to an unreasonably large number of automated tests. I'll try to bring this discussion up when we have a quorum of core devs awake tomorrow, and see if it's something we can agree on or whether it needs additional community input."}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-05-29 09:43:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for the feedback, Clark, Jeremy. I'll post an update to the tox deps (with a dependency on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30679/).

Considering Django 1.4 guarantees support with Python 2.6 and 2.7 I think we can get away with running the dj14 tests only in one environment and avoid increasing the dependency support matrix too much -- I'll remove py26dj14 and only keep one.

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/faq/install/#what-python-version-can-i-use-with-django

When I posted the patch there wasn't any test failures with either environment (although I did have to delete my initial .tox directory for the py27 to pass, I think due to stale *.pyc hanging around) so I'm surprised there would be a number of them already. I'll check again."}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-05-29 09:43:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-05-29 11:15:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2013-05-29 11:18:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

We should keep the deprecated code in during this patch and start removing it with time in a future patch. In this patch we changed the implementation of the way we get and cache info in the env and in memcache. We did not change the users of this info - which is left for a future patch (in which the deprecated code will be slowly removed)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-29 22:56:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(16 inline comments)

I think the API right now is suffering from a lack of symmetry. On the one hand, you've got

    def get_info(app, env, account, container=None, ret_not_found=False):

So, that's how you fetch things out of the cache. On the other hand, here's how you clear things:

    def clear_info_cache(app, req):

Seems bizarre to me that I can get things with an account and optional container, but to delete them, I need a request. I'd much rather have clear_info() take an account and optional container so it matches get_info().

(I looked at all the call sites for clear_info() in this diff, and they've each already parsed the request path and have an account/container in hand, so the amount of work done would be roughly the same.)


Also, I wonder about having a single get_info() function for both accounts and containers. It might be the case that you want separate get_account_info() and get_container_info() functions, as the return values are quite different. Of course, those could still be *implemented* in terms of a single get_info() function that does the cache lookups, and that would minimize code duplication while still providing a clear API... I'm not sure what the best thing to do here is. More thought is required.


Also, a bunch of typos and such in inline comments. Not big deals, but if you're going to submit another patch set anyway, it'd be nice to fix those up. Not essential, just nice. (Sorry about the sheer number of nitpicky comments; I tend to do an initial read-through of patches before getting too detailed, and typos just sort of jump out at me during that phase.)"}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-05-29 23:42:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

making that change will lead the _set_info_cache to use container and account rather than req - this means we need to parts in GETorHEAD_base. 

This seems like a style issue to me  - I dont mind changing it and would have done so if not the extra overhead. So, the old get_container info would look in memcache, then fall back to making a container HEAD request.

The new get_container_info looks in memcache, then (recursive call to get_info) looks in memcache for the account, then falls back to an account HEAD request (end recursive call), then falls back to a container HEAD request.

  * all object requests
  * container quotas

    container_info = get_info(app, env, account, container)   # got a bug in your code that lets container be None? enjoy your account info!

@Sam, 

get_account_info and get_container_info is working against code reuse. 

As another example, I think we need to move to _get_broker from the current _get_account_broker and _get_container_broker - for code reuse. 

We should not have account/container/obj in the function name where we have a series of practically identical functions performed on an "object" where the "object" can be a/c/o or just a/c.

if you feel get_info is not clear, we can change this, but please do not dress it with account vs container as it prevents the caller to perform code reuse.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-05-31 20:40:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

You might be confusing code reuse with something else. I think Sam gave a pretty good reason (that I hadn't thought of before) for separate functions. Each of those functions might just call the same helper function after doing their own validation or something -- that's where the code reuse comes into play."}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-05-31 21:14:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

@gholt

I was referring to code reuse at the caller. If the caller is the same for container and account, it would want to use 

info = get_info(account, container) 

(where container may be None) 
instead of having: 

if container: 
    info = get_container_info(account, container)
else:
    info = get_account_info(account)

I encountered such an example in get_account_broker and get_container_broker while trying to achieve code reuse in the caller for these functions.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-01 00:06:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

_set_info_cache doc string is formatted oddly and would render as one big run on sentence.

Not your issue exactly, but the controllers should be in the Sphinx docs.

_set_info_cache uses unquote when it shouldn't.

_set_info_cache doesn't use recheck_account_existence.

get_info should have the note:

    Note: This call bypasses auth. Success does not imply that the
          request has authorization to the get_info.

get_info doesn't use quote when it should.

The comment regarding why env_key is named the way it is was lost:

    # Use a unique environment cache key per container.  If you copy this env

The original tests from master fail and I wouldn't expect that with this refactor which shouldn't really change any existing behavior."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-01 12:59:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Well, I thought "would render as one big run on sentence" was elaborating enough ;) but here ya go -- it would look something like this rendered:

Cache info in both memcache and env Caching is used to avoid unnecessary calls to account and container servers This is a private function that is being called by GETorHEAD_base Any attempt to GET or HEAD from the container/account server should use the GETorHEAD_base interface This function is also used by the clear_info_cache to delete the cache entries

So it could use some punctuation at the very least.

    $ grep -r recheck_account_existence swift
    swift/proxy/server.py:        self.recheck_account_existence = \
    swift/proxy/server.py:            int(conf.get('recheck_account_existence', 60))

    02:52 davidhadas gholt: there were minor changes needed to the tests. Some
                     were since the test was preserving a misbehaviour. I tried

                     more depth and let me know if any of the changes worry you

I have reviewed this in depth, hours upon hours of depth. One example here is that the new implementation could use "if info.get('container_count') is None:" instead of "if info['container_count'] is None:" and some of the failing original tests would pass.

I can certainly see if a test is testing backend return code orders or has set up certain backend requests and such that those might need to be changed. But what I saw seemed like things that could be fixed to be 100% passing.

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-02 02:38:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

There are deprecation comments and I don't understand why since the functions aren't going away. Even so, the deprecation comments aren't on all the calls (for example, inside POST, PUT, and DELETE in controllers/obj.py).

Since this is a refactor, I don't intend to approve of this change unless all the original tests pass or, if an original test needs to be changed in order for it to pass it is well understood as to why.

I have spent *quite* some time figuring out for you why these original tests don't pass.

Some problems did exist with the new code:

* Because account_info always returned as if the account existed with account auto create turned on, the container code had no way of knowing it should truly auto create the account. I added a fakeable keyword argument to allow turning this behavior off for such scenarios.

* The container_count stuff used to be cached as an int and I wouldn't be surprised if code out there expects it to be an int from cache. However, as you noted, it is a string when returned from headers_to_account_info. I just made sure it was always put in cache as an int. This made the existing tests happier.

* get_info was causing a double account existence check when working on container info. I added an environment variable to let the ContainerController know to skip the extra check.

* get_info was propagating any subrequest error instead of returning None like the info functions were before.

* get_info wasn't handling a complete lack of caching.

* account_info wasn't returning Nones when the account wasn't found like it was before.

* container_info was setting 'partition' and 'nodes' to actual values for 404s when it wasn't before.

Here is my 'git diff' output against patch set 8 (doesn't include any test changes):

    diff --git a/swift/proxy/controllers/account.py b/swift/proxy/controllers/account.py
    index 25492be..4f009a9 100644
    --- a/swift/proxy/controllers/account.py
    +++ b/swift/proxy/controllers/account.py
    @@ -58,7 +58,9 @@ class AccountController(Controller):
             resp = self.GETorHEAD_base(
                 req, _('Account'), self.app.account_ring, partition,
                 req.path_info.rstrip('/'))
    -        if resp.status_int == HTTP_NOT_FOUND and self.app.account_autocreate:
    +        if resp.status_int == HTTP_NOT_FOUND and \
    +                self.app.account_autocreate and \
    +                req.environ.get('swift.fakeable', True):
                 # Fake a response
                 headers = {'Content-Length': '0',
                            'Accept-Ranges': 'bytes',
    diff --git a/swift/proxy/controllers/base.py b/swift/proxy/controllers/base.py
    index 9dfc569..fef1e78 100644
    --- a/swift/proxy/controllers/base.py
    +++ b/swift/proxy/controllers/base.py
    @@ -109,10 +109,6 @@ def headers_to_account_info(headers, status_int=HTTP_OK):
         headers = dict((k.lower(), v) for k, v in dict(headers).iteritems())
         return {
             'status': status_int,
    -        # 'container_count' anomaly:
    -        # Previous code sometimes expects an int sometimes a string
    -        # Current code aligns to str and None, yet translates to int in
    -        # deprecated functions as needed
             'container_count': headers.get('x-account-container-count'),
             'total_object_count': headers.get('x-account-object-count'),
             'bytes': headers.get('x-account-bytes-used'),
    @@ -243,10 +239,7 @@ def get_account_info(env, app, swift_source=None):
         info = get_info(app, env, account, ret_not_found=True)
         if not info:
             info = headers_to_account_info({}, 0)
    -    if info.get('container_count') is None:
    -        info['container_count'] = 0
    -    else:
    -        info['container_count'] = int(info['container_count'])
    +    info['container_count'] = int(info.get('container_count') or 0)
         return info
     
     
    @@ -312,6 +305,8 @@ def _set_info_cache(app, env, account, container, resp):
             info = headers_to_container_info(resp.headers, resp.status_int)
         else:
             info = headers_to_account_info(resp.headers, resp.status_int)
    +        # Here for backwards compatibility
    +        info['container_count'] = int(info.get('container_count') or 0)
         memcache = getattr(app, 'memcache', None) or env.get('swift.cache')
         if memcache:
             memcache.set(cache_key, info, cache_time)
    @@ -352,7 +347,8 @@ def _get_info_cache(app, env, account, container=None):
         return None
     
     
    -def get_info(app, env, account, container=None, ret_not_found=False):
    +def get_info(app, env, account, container=None, ret_not_found=False,
    +             fakeable=True):
         """
         Get the info about accounts or containers
         Note: This call bypasses auth. Success does not imply that the
    @@ -380,10 +376,16 @@ def get_info(app, env, account, container=None, ret_not_found=False):
         # Note that make_pre_authed_request expects quoted path
         req = make_pre_authed_request(env, 'HEAD', quote(path),
                                       swift_source='GET_INFO')
    +    if not fakeable:
    +        req.environ['swift.fakeable'] = False
    +    if container:
    +        req.environ['swift.account_existence_already_checked'] = True
         # Whenever we do a GET/HEAD the GETorHEAD_base will set the info in
         # the environment under environ[env_key] and in memcache. We will
         # pick the one from environ[env_key] and use it to set the caller env
         resp = req.get_response(app)
    +    if resp.status_int != HTTP_NOT_FOUND and not is_success(resp.status_int):
    +        return None
         cache_key, env_key = _get_cache_key(account, container)
         try:
             info = resp.environ[env_key]
    @@ -392,7 +394,12 @@ def get_info(app, env, account, container=None, ret_not_found=False):
                 return info
         except (KeyError, AttributeError):
             pass
    -    return None
    +    # Wasn't cached, so cache might not be in use, so try directly.
    +    if container:
    +        info = headers_to_container_info(resp.headers, resp.status_int)
    +    else:
    +        info = headers_to_account_info(resp.headers, resp.status_int)
    +    return info

Some existing tests did need changing, in my opinion:

* FakeRequest didn't have a self.environ (you had already found this one).

* FakeRequest wasn't ever using the passed path and just always trying env['PATH_INFO'] (you had found this one too, I just fixed it a bit more broadly).

* TestFuncs wasn't properly restoring make_pre_authed_request value and so causing random failures elsewhere.

* TestController's test_account_info_no_cache and test_container_info_no_cache asserted non-unanimous 404s didn't not cache, but they are now, so I deleted the tests. NOTE: THIS IS A SUBTLE CHANGE IN BEHAVIOR. WE DIDN'T USED TO CACHE 404S UNLESS WE GOT ALL 404S. NOW WE WILL CACHE IF WE GET A MAJORITY OF 404S. I'm okay with the change, but it should be considered by reviewers.

* TestController's test_container_info_200 and test_container_info_404 overrode account_info expecting it to be called by container_info, but that doesn't happen anymore. Simple reworking of the tests.

* The last part of TestContainerController's test_HEAD_GET and test_POST needed additional 404s to be returned when account auto create was turned on (3x 404 for initial account check but faked 204, 3x 404 for missing container).

@gholt, I appreciate the time you spent on this.

Lets remove the DEPRECATED notes and indications on the four existing <get_>account_info, <get_>container_info functions and their callers - it seems to be causing unnecessary noise. 

I suggest hearing the view of others (at least of Sam and Chmouel that followed that patch) before making the 'fackable' and 'container_count' changes you requested.  

The other changes you requested below are already covered by the current code, no change seem to be needed - see details below. 

•	Adding the fakeable keyword argument seems to pollute our code just to make the (fakeable) tests run. I would probably -1 it if I saw it written elsewhere :), Yet if others are ok with this change I will merge it into the next patch set.
•	Preserving the past container_count as int - while all other parameters are strings is something I would recommend against. Yet if others are ok with this change I will merge it into the next patch set.
•	There seem to be already an env variable shared between the first and second invocations of get_info :) - which is the env cacheable account info. If not exists, it is created in the first invocation and therefore immediately OKed by the second. Why add another env for the same purpose?  
•	The code you added to get_info to avoid propagating a subrequest error is repeating code that is already in get_info (few lines after the addition). See - 

if ret_not_found or is_success(info['status']):

•	Caching in memcache is optional, caching in env is always used – hence the code need not handle a case where the caching in env was not used.  
•	There is no need to change account_info and container_info the way you suggested since they already behave the same way you wanted – through the use of the ret_not_found parameter.  Get_info will return None for anything but is_success if this parameter is not set and the two functions never set this parameter."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-02 14:12:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> Adding the fakeable keyword argument seems to pollute our code just to make
> the (fakeable) tests run. I would probably -1 it if I saw it written
> elsewhere :), Yet if others are ok with this change I will merge it into the
> next patch set.

Ah, you see why I wanted you to do the work of documenting the why for each test change? I saw the (undocumented) ret_not_found but it wasn't acting the way I expected; but yeah, its purpose seems the same as fakeable. Perhaps it wasn't working as expected because the account controller returns a 204 and not 404 when it fakes an account? Getting rid of fakeable makes test/unit/proxy/test_server.py TestContainerController.test_PUT fail, but perhaps it is for other reasons?

> Preserving the past container_count as int - while all other parameters are
> strings is something I would recommend against. Yet if others are ok with
> this change I will merge it into the next patch set.

My argument the other way is that container_count is currently always cached as an int, there is a test for that, and probably other's code would break if it's changed to a string.

> There seem to be already an env variable shared between the first and second
> invocations of get_info :) - which is the env cacheable account info. If not
> exists, it is created in the first invocation and therefore immediately OKed
> by the second. Why add another env for the same purpose?  

I'm assuming you're talking about the account_existence_already_checked thing. I'm not sure on this now, I'll have to revisit it later when you submit your next patch set. I'm thinking it was because make_pre_authed_request creates a fresh env that doesn't have the original cache, but I'm not certain right now.

> The code you added to get_info to avoid propagating a subrequest error is
> repeating code that is already in get_info (few lines after the addition).
> See - 
> if ret_not_found or is_success(info['status']):

This addition was due to my adding the no-cache check at the end. The line you mention doesn't get run since the env_key wouldn't exist. Returning None instead of the "pass" would've worked to fix my case too.

> Caching in memcache is optional, caching in env is always used – hence the
> code need not handle a case where the caching in env was not used.  

I'm thinking this part is because of the faked account response in AccountController's GETorHEAD. In the case of the faked response, there will be no env key. Then again, maybe that's not the issue but a separate one.

It could also be that all this assumes the app given to get_info will eventually call swift/proxy/controllers/base.py Controller's GETorHEAD_base. That certainly isn't the case in many tests that fake it, which would cause issues of not caching the env key. But it could even be the case elsewhere, though I know of no such instances.

I don't much like this indirect call-this / hope-for-that approach. If I pass get_info an app to use for performing HEADs against, I don't think it should assume I'm going to set an env key for it to read later. I'm going to assume it's going to actually use the value I gave it from making a HEAD request and cache that value itself if it wants to. I understand proactively caching whenever a GET or HEAD is made; I just don't think that should be required behavior and relied upon the way it is by get_info.

> There is no need to change account_info and container_info the way you
> suggested since they already behave the same way you wanted – through the use
> of the ret_not_found parameter.  Get_info will return None for anything but
> is_success if this parameter is not set and the two functions never set this
> parameter.

See way above with first response regarding ret_not_found.

-----

This whole thing is starting to get weird to me. I do think the area needs cleanup and I welcome the effort, but this actually confuses me more and seems like more code. Maybe it'll grow on me by the next time I look at it.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-02 14:13:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

gholt seem to experience this nagging NIH feeling, I know that one as it often creeps on me as well…  (I sometimes try yelling 'Down boy, down' in case it will help) :)  

My immediate concern is with bringing Account ACLs in, as discussed in the summit…    ...and yes, I do like mine better and would like to see container and account servers merging as much as possible to one. 

Forward looking, I consider the choice of two levels (accounts and containers) as somewhat of a random choice – although it maybe just right to get to a service offering as done by the Rackspace. 

But in 'Enterprise' use cases (I am hearing at least three people jumping their seats now saying… "hehe, he is again using the E* word  - this must be evidence of his weak brain, poor education and luck of anything smarter to say"), this is not always the case. 

Different use cases may require more levels – but this is really long term and explains part of why I dislike the get_container_info vs. get_account_info – enough of these around and any change to grow and expand Swift in this area is gone.

If I can't get reviewers to approve the get_info API, or any of the other approaches suggested in my patch, I am ok with any improvement to the current code that will help put some order, such that I can move on to adding account ACLs ASAP.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-03 12:21:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

I've taken my alternate down, as it was kind of... mean? There are stronger words to describe it, but I'll leave those unwritten.

Anyway, it really wasn't intended to be mean, or NIH, or anything but educational at first, because I was just trying to figure this stuff out and why it was so difficult. I got that education that's for sure, this area is a mess. When I was nearly done, I felt the educational edition was better so I posted it. I have a bit of a "code wins, people be damned" outlook and that gets me into trouble (with people, not as much with code ;)

I'll let it go from here, as long as the final result isn't too buggy I'll figure out how to work with it. And I'm obviously biased against this review.

For the further question of accounts and containers and enterprise... Uhm, ever looked at S3? It seems to work just fine for a lot of folks.

The main reason I groan when I hear "enterprise" is that it's often used as an escape hatch. Instead of promoting and defending an idea on its own merits, it's defended with "Well, you wouldn't understand I guess, this is needed for the Enterprise."

Anyway, if suddenly we have collections of thingies instead of accounts, containers, and objects, I'll adapt to that as well.'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-03 13:25:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

hey gholt, all cool – I get the "code wins" part. NIH is just there and we can't expect different programmers coming from different backgrounds i.e. were exposed to different experiences, to think the same. 

(…come to think of it, we can't expect some programmers to think at all… specially if their title is 'Architect')

We have one or two people here that sell to the E* market and they tell me that an S3 'me too' product is not what an E* customer requires. I see a lot of potential in Swift, as an open-source high-performance scaleable platform, but to become the platform of choice for the E* market, it probably would need to offer a more generic, flexible and extendable service than it already does. 

All this has little to do with refactoring info. Now that you see that 'this area is a mess', you may understand why I was looking to solve this before we continue adding Account ACLs (instead of just adding more to the current mess). Similar mess was with account autocreate - so at least this is now solved.

Of course if accounts and containers where just collections of thingies…  …account ACLs would already have been supported since we have them for containers.

Same goes for account listing.

But lets take this one step at a time.. for now, we need either specific suggestions how to improve the present patch or that we OK it, leaving further work to later patches.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-04 01:05:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

I've got a couple of problems with the new get_info() function.

First, it seems fragile to me the way it makes a request to the app, then reaches into that response's WSGI environment at a magic key, and then returns the value it finds. We've already got the functions headers_to_(account|container)_info; why not use those on the response headers? In addition to being less susceptible to change, it means you're building on something (the client-facing API) that's really well-tested.

Second, why does get_info(app, env, account, container) make a recursive call for get_info(app, env, account)? I know there's a discrepancy between how things handled it; get_container_info() didn't check the account, while base.Controller.container_info() did. Given the choice between the two, I'd rather resolve it in favor of *not* checking the account for one simple reason: it's faster.

Also, I haven't had a chance to take a look at the tests yet. I'll get to them, but I've spent a bunch of time on this and now my brain is fried."}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-04 06:40:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (6 inline comments)

@Sam
I fixed the code based on the inline comments. The env in req is done for tests to pass.  

As for the broader issues:

Using _to_(account|container)_info on the resp inside get_info means messing up things again as the info we will return to the caller may differ from the one we added to cache for example… this will again introduce multiple places in the code that 'calculate' the info. I would rather we avoid this.

The change you are suggesting as for not checking the account_info during container_info is a significant functional change, which I rather you put in a separate patch (my guts tell me that this is there for a good reason, although I never analyzed it). My understanding is that the base.Controller.container_info() is the right "API way" which is also backed up by tests to ensure it works as planned (ensure account is tested for existence). While the get_container_info() behavior is a mishup introduced later and we should not follow its lead.'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-04 06:44:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-04 07:36:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Works for me

First: well, it looks like I was wrong about it being faster, since swift.proxy.controllers.ContainerController.GETorHEAD() already calls self.account_info(), so the check is already being made. With that in mind, I think it'd be better for a container get_info() to not check the account existence since it's already being done by the proxy.

To summarize, on master we have:
* get_container_info() already checks account existence via ContainerController.GETorHEAD()
* s.c.p.b.Controller.container_info() already checks account existence via calling self.account_info()


With this patchset, we have:
* get_container_info checks account existence *twice*: once via get_info(), then again via ContainerController.GETorHEAD()
* s.c.p.b.Controller.container_info() checks account existence via calling get_info()


It's the double-checking that I find objectionable.


Second: I don't see a problem with having two places in the codebase that compute cache values from headers, as long as "two places" means "two call sites for the same function".

In fact, we've got three call sites for headers_to_container_info() already: one in s.c.p.b.get_container_info(), one in _set_info_cache(), and one in Controller.container_info().'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-04 18:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I really have nothing more to add to what I wrote before. 

Sam seem to object to not making a functional change in get_container_info while gholt seem  to insist that we refactor without making functional changes. Please discuss and decide. My 2 cents is to leave any functional tests that we do not have to do now to a separate patch. 

gholt, please also review the current code and the second change requested by Sam and compile a list of still needed changes.

To me it seems like for a while now, we are moving between flavors of implementation. Lets just decide and finish this.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-04 19:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I'm "out" on this review at this point, due to my previously discussed bias. Whatever two other core devs approve, I'll just go with.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-04 19:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: No score

Okay, so the stuff about the account checking was mostly due to me misreading this patch. Please disregard that; sorry for the noise.

I still have to go look at the tests though.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-05 21:34:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

I've got a few things to cover here, so please bear with me.

I took a look at Greg's alternative, and there's a few things worth discussing in there. (I know Greg said he's out wrt this review, but maybe he'll chime in if I'm flat-out wrong about something.)

(one)
The for_write stuff in Greg's patch is sort of cool, but I don't see it as being necessary for this patch. If the cache winds up holding a faked-out response for a little while, well, that matches the response you'd get from the proxy anyway. There may be more to it, but I don't see it.

(two)
This patch (the one this comment is attached to) gets account/container info by making a request, then reaching into the response's environment and returning a value from there. Greg's patch builds it from the response headers.

I definitely prefer building it from the response headers. However, I could live with the retrieve-from-environment code if it had a unit test specifically for that behavior.

What I mean is this: if get_info() is using the response headers, and I'm writing some other code and I break the response headers, I've got a bunch of tests that fail, and they point me to exactly what's wrong: a header is wrong in the response. With the code here in patch set 11, if I break the plumbing for the thing in the environment, I get one test failure, and it doesn't really tell me what's wrong (something gets a 404 instead of a 200). If there were a unit test that would assert something like "assertEqual(resp.environ['swift.container/a/c/'], {'blah': 'blah'})" and *that* broke, I'd have a much better idea what's wrong.

(three)
This patch leaves the cache population only in the proxy controllers and relies on GET/HEAD requests to have the side effect of cache population, while Greg's adds  cache population to get_(account|container)_info. It's certainly more comprehensible to have cache population in those functions, but it comes at a cost of a redundant memcache "set" command, and IMHO it's not worth it. I prefer the approach in this patch.


So, to summarize the small novel I've written here, there's one big change I'd like to see in this patch: *either* make get_info's return value come from the response headers, *or* add some unit tests around how get_info works. Either one of those will result in a state where, if I break the code, then the tests will help me figure out what exactly is wrong.

There's also a couple of important-looking things with no test coverage, but those should be fairly easy to fix (see inline comments).'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-05 22:19:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Sam, I will add tests to cover the items you pointed out - its a very busy non coding day for me tomorrow, so I hope I can get this by week end. 

Chmouel, if possible please have a look tomorrow during the day such that I can encompass your review remarks as well.'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-07 07:20:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-07 08:03:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-07 08:58:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13: Doesn't seem to work

As you noted in IRC, it can't be in proxy/test_server.py because that fails too early when stuff is broken. Also, there's some serious copy+paste going on there because I'm too lazy to refactor the tests just for an example. Wouldn't be too hard, though.

Here's a breakage I introduced:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/IiysMV04WcRopdaO1L4X/

and here's the test output:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/GdNk9yuxZrZeBzZCa8zk/

It does break several tests, but there's one nice clear failure that says "hey, something's missing from the response environment". (Turns out that it's hard to break only the container level, so I went with account-level tests too, as there you can get a 2xx response with a broken get_info(). Can't do that with a container HEAD.)'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-08 09:27:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Change-Id: I67b58030d3f9e3bc86bcd7ece0f1dc693c4e08c3
Fixes: Bug #1162199
'}]
commit_message:
get_info - removes duplicate code (Take 3)

Consolidate the different ways in which info of account/container
is gathered, cached, used, updated, etc.

This refactoring increases code reuse and is a basis for later
addition of account ACLs.
Changing the get_info users is left for future.
This staged approach ensures the behaviour is unchanged.

Change-Id: I67b58030d3f9e3bc86bcd7ece0f1dc693c4e08c3
Fixes: Bug #1162199

    def get_project_users(self, context, tenant_id, **kw):
        self.assert_admin(context)

        for user_ref in user_refs:

        return {'users': user_refs}


It's just not exposed to the outside (no url to action map defined in routers.py). Is there any background info I missed here? Thanks."}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-06-05 07:43:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Remove GET /projects/{project_id}/users (bug 1187257)

This resources was unimplemented in grizzly, and the semantics of the
call need to be carefully considered (and perhaps redesigned) prior to
implementation.

Change-Id: I34dcf10ad5536f22c350b33154d96fec78774d42

Fix the after subscription size checks.

It seems like the calculation was incorrect previously.

Fixes bug: #1190094

how long has this package been available?'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-04-11 06:41:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

can you just leave the keystone python class there so that we do not immediately break backwards compatibility? If you feel that it should be deprecated, then add a deprecation warning to that class.'}, {'account_id': 1607, 'date': '2013-04-11 07:41:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The keystone::python's annotation is fuzzing, it describe as 'installs client python libraries for keystone'.

But actually it install the python-keystone package which is the  keystone python lib. 

The client python libraries for keystone is python-keystoneclient, which is available  in  Debian and Redhat.

I will add a new patch to retrieve the keystone::python and modify its annotation."}, {'account_id': 1607, 'date': '2013-04-11 07:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-11 07:55:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Update keystone::python and keystone::client

The patch contains:
   * add keystone::python
   * add keystone_client_spec
   * remove keystone::params::client_package_name

Fix Bug 1167699

Change-Id: Idefdf4e4d8aef30f659779d5d1b9640ddd79fbfb

[{'created': '2013-06-04 11:00:47.000000000', 'message': "Allow exceptions to hop up cells

When an exception happens in an RPC call using nova cells, it can travel
back up several RPC boundaries. eg, child-cell=>parent-cell=>nova-api

Before this patch if an exception (eg. AggregateNotFound) was raised in
the bottom layer, the next layer up would turn it into a special
exception ( AggregateNotFound_Remote ), then in the final layer, it would
see this as an unrecognizable exception and raise RemoteException.

After this patch, at each layer where the expeption is deserialized,
it'll recognie exceptions with the _Remote postfix, and leave them as
they are, instead of turning them into RemoteExceptions.

It also preserves the exception's original __module__ now.

Change-Id: I158a80f1cec20d3e1805b565ffddaffd7a15295b

commit_message:
Allow exceptions to hop up cells

When an exception happens in an RPC call using nova cells, it can travel
back up several RPC boundaries. eg, child-cell=>parent-cell=>nova-api

Before this patch if an exception (eg. AggregateNotFound) was raised in
the bottom layer, the next layer up would turn it into a special
exception ( AggregateNotFound_Remote ), then in the final layer, it would
see this as an unrecognizable exception and raise RemoteException.

After this patch, at each layer where the expeption is deserialized,
it'll recognize exceptions with the _Remote postfix, and leave them as
they are, instead of turning them into RemoteExceptions.

It also preserves the exception's original __module__ now.

Change-Id: I158a80f1cec20d3e1805b565ffddaffd7a15295b

- no tests for 'income' param'}, {'account_id': 1267, 'date': '2013-06-10 12:52:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

To Nikita

1. The function name describes what is does: it constructs a slug. Slug is a newspaper term. A slug is a short label for something, containing only letters, numbers, underscores or hyphens. They’re generally used in URLs. (https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/models/fields/)

Nobody knows a priori what is a "normalized" string. Even more, nobody knows a priori what is a "normalized" vector (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norm_(mathematics)#Examples)

2, 3. `slugify` is flesh of flesh of `safe_decode` function. Since `safe_decode` is a respectable Oslo function, its documentation was copied with awe.'}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2013-06-11 07:57:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-31 14:25:15.000000000', 'message': "Remove routes collection mappings

When using the routes mapper's collection to map from URLs to
python functions several additional URIs are created by
default: 'new', 'format' and 'edit', eg this URI

/v1/images/new

was accessible and would return a '500'.

Other collection URIs would return unexpected behaviour.

Use explicit mappings rather than a 'collection' to remove
these stray mappings.

Fixes bug 1185828.

Change-Id: I2f451f0208d43cdc83dcf58a41ea31359b18fcf2
"}, {'created': '2013-06-04 13:44:21.000000000', 'message': "Remove routes collection mappings

When using the routes mapper's collection to map from URLs to
python functions several additional URIs are created by
default: 'new', 'format' and 'edit', eg this URI

/v1/images/new

was accessible and would return a '500'.

/v1/images/detail.xxx

was accessible and a 'GET' to it would create a file called 'detail.xxx'
in the image cache directory (where 'xxx' is an arbitrary string).

Similar resources for image memberships existed.

Other collection URIs (for both the API and Registry) would return
unexpected behaviour.

Use explicit mappings rather than a 'collection' to remove
the superfluous resources.

Fixes bug 1185828.

Change-Id: I2f451f0208d43cdc83dcf58a41ea31359b18fcf2
"}]
commit_message:
Remove routes collection mappings

When using the routes mapper's collection to map from URLs to
python functions several additional URIs are created by
default: 'new', 'format' and 'edit', eg this URI

/v1/images/new

was accessible and would return a '500'.

/v1/images/detail.xxx

was accessible and a 'GET' to it would create a file called 'detail.xxx'
in the image cache directory (where 'xxx' is an arbitrary string).

Similar resources for image memberships existed.

Other collection URIs (for both the API and Registry) would return
unexpected behaviour.

Use explicit mappings rather than a 'collection' to remove
the superfluous resources.

Fixes bug 1185828.

Change-Id: I2f451f0208d43cdc83dcf58a41ea31359b18fcf2

subject: Prevent '500' error when admin uses private marker

[{'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-04-25 14:46:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-04-25 14:46:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-04-25 16:30:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hi Stuart!

I have a few questions:

1. The bug you filed also notes an issue with PUT's returning a 500 error; does this patch address that problem as well, or should there be more patches?


2. Can we process these index/detail requests as normal rather than returning 4xx? There is an implicit relationship between /images?marker=foo and /images/foo, so it seems a bit odd to get a 404 in the former case but a 200 in the latter.


3. While I (now) agree that 404 is the correct response when a marker is not found or intentionally hidden, I'm not sure that the benefits of correctness outweigh the general burden against API changes, especially in v1. Would you be okay with dropping that part of the change?"}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-04-25 16:41:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Mark,

I agree this is a bit confusing.

Let me try to explain where I'm coming from with the main change and why I think its consist with the slightly eccentric current behaviour.

Imagine there are 6 images, three public images (A, B, C) and three private images (a, b, c) owned by user '2'. The admin is user '1'.

If the admin does a GET to:

/v1/images

they will see a list of three images (the public ones).

if they do a GET to:

/v1/images?is_public=None

they will see all six images.

Without this patch a GET to:

/v1/images?marker=b

will return 500

with this patch a GET to

/v1/images?marker=b

will return 404 (which is consistent with 'b' not being in the list).

a GET to /v1/images?is_public=None?marker=b

will get a 'hit' and will traverse the list.

So, none of this is ideal, and I'm open to other suggestions, but if we don't return 404 to the '/v1/images?marker=b' what happens? Do we return 'c' or nothing? I think 404 might be the least worst option...but always open to suggestions!"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-04-25 17:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I think it makes sense to say that a valid marker is any image id that you can get directly. For example, isn't it true that if I do

GET /v1/images?name=ubuntu&marker=abcd

I can get a valid list of images with name == "ubuntu" even if image 'abcd' has name == "fedora"?'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-04-25 19:14:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Here's how I'd see it...

Going back to my previous example, if an admin does

GET /v1/images

they will see three ids [A,B,C] listed. The way I see markers is that the admin can subsequently choose to use a marker to start from one of those three ids, ie to get a subset of the original list. Like a bookmark -- in this case for a book with three pages. I think of trying to use a marker to select one of the images that is not listed [a, b, c] as being a bit like trying to start from page 5 of a book with only three pages.

So I'd see:

GET /v1/images?name=ubuntu&marker=A

as getting a list of [B,C] and matching any of those whose name may be ubuntu, but
I'd see

GET /v1/images?name=ubuntu&marker=b

as returning a 404 because b is not visible in the original list."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-04-26 06:37:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Rolling the dice of gerrit formatting!

While this view of markers makes sense, it is not consistent with current api behavior. For a (lengthy) example, if I have the following list of images

  ~/devstack$ curl -X GET -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H 'User-Agent: python-glanceclient' 'http://10.130.50.38:9292/v1/images?status=queued' 2>/dev/null | python -m json.tool | egrep -v "format|checksum|size"
  {
    "images": [
        {
            "id": "5fc53a63-b63f-4f2f-81b3-fb1eff8b236f",
            "name": "fedora",
        },
        {
            "id": "f70be544-4813-42e9-bba6-cf014c2c3f28",
            "name": "ubuntu",
        },
        {
            "id": "8f75c4b9-3b0b-4c97-9b7f-bfb826e61258",
            "name": "fedora",
        },
        {
            "id": "11659ec4-3621-4387-8d42-abe3d34c18e5",
            "name": "fedora",
        },
        {
            "id": "384d29ff-050b-47fc-808c-bfc38e4c3778",
            "name": "ubuntu",
        },
        {
            "id": "52b86835-603c-46bd-a94c-13bb0231cc43",
            "name": "ubuntu",
        }
    ]
  } 


I am free to use the id of the 3rd fedora image as a marker for an ubuntu image search:

  ~/devstack$ curl -X GET -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H 'User-Agent: python-glanceclient' 'http://10.130.50.38:9292/v1/images?status=queued&name=ubuntu&marker=11659ec4-3621-4387-8d42-abe3d34c18e5' 2>/dev/null | python -m json.tool | egrep -v "format|checksum|size"
  {
    "images": [
        {
            "id": "384d29ff-050b-47fc-808c-bfc38e4c3778",
            "name": "ubuntu",
        },
        {
            "id": "52b86835-603c-46bd-a94c-13bb0231cc43",
            "name": "ubuntu",
        }
    ]
  }

Even though the fedora image would never show up in an ubuntu image search:

~/devstack$ curl -X GET -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H 'User-Agent: python-glanceclient' 'http://10.130.50.38:9292/v1/images?status=queued&name=ubuntu' 2>/dev/null | python -m json.tool | egrep -v "format|checksum|size"
  {
    "images": [
        {
            "id": "f70be544-4813-42e9-bba6-cf014c2c3f28",
            "name": "ubuntu",
        },
        {
            "id": "384d29ff-050b-47fc-808c-bfc38e4c3778",
            "name": "ubuntu",
        },
        {
            "id": "52b86835-603c-46bd-a94c-13bb0231cc43",
            "name": "ubuntu",
        }
    ]
  }'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-04-26 12:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Mark,

Thanks for your comment. You won the gerrit formatting bet!

I do agree with your last comment, I but don't think that this patch will affect that behaviour.

I think its the behaviour in the multi-user case which is the open question.

Also running the gauntlet of gerrit formatting!

Consider two users 'glance',who is an admin, and 'demo' a regular, non-admin user.
Imagine six images exist -- three public and three private images *which are owned by 'demo'*:

If user demo lists images he sees all six:

 $ curl -H "x-auth-token: `cat demo.token`" http://localhost:9292/v1/images 2>/dev/null | python -mjson.tool | egrep -v 'checksum|container|disk|size'
 {
    "images": [
        {
            "id": "545ac52f-3985-4331-b366-d6058c84b017",
            "name": "private-demo-3",
        },
        {
            "id": "4db5ccbd-f673-44fb-840e-036ccc30d260",
            "name": "private-demo-2",
        },
        {
            "id": "1f886904-5eff-498e-ac5a-418f3cb069bc",
            "name": "private-demo-1",
        },
        {
            "id": "6c86fbe5-5efb-4513-80b2-28bdf309d6ba",
            "name": "public3",
        },
        {
            "id": "34c9bf52-03a5-4637-8fc4-9ce5298bc9a5",
            "name": "public1",
        },
        {
            "id": "151134a5-62e2-44a2-8ede-7b22a9b4c5cc",
            "name": "public2",
        }
    ]
 }


If user 'glance' lists images he sees only the three public ones (despite being an admin):

 $ curl -H "x-auth-token: `cat glance.token`" http://localhost:9292/v1/images 2>/dev/null | python -mjson.tool | egrep -v 'checksum|container|disk|size'
 {
    "images": [
        {
            "id": "6c86fbe5-5efb-4513-80b2-28bdf309d6ba",
            "name": "public3",
        },
        {
            "id": "34c9bf52-03a5-4637-8fc4-9ce5298bc9a5",
            "name": "public1",
        },
        {
            "id": "151134a5-62e2-44a2-8ede-7b22a9b4c5cc",
            "name": "public2",
        }
    ]
 }

ie this API call means "give me only public images and images that I [glance] own".

So ... its legal for the 'glance' user to do this:

 GET //v1/images/detail?sort_key=name&sort_dir=asc&limit=1&marker=34c9bf52-03a5-4637-8fc4-9ce5298bc9a5
 GET //v1/images/detail?sort_key=name&sort_dir=asc&limit=1&marker=151134a5-62e2-44a2-8ede-7b22a9b4c5cc
 GET //v1/images/detail?sort_key=name&sort_dir=asc&limit=1&marker=6c86fbe5-5efb-4513-80b2-28bdf309d6ba

(this is what the glance cli command will do if you set --page-size 1)

because in each case the three markers exist in the original list. 

However, this:

 GET //v1/images/detail?marker=545ac52f-3985-4331-b366-d6058c84b017

should return a 404 since "545ac52f-3985-4331-b366-d6058c84b017" is neither "a public image or an
image that I [glance] own". (Currently this is what returns a 500).

Note that it *is* possible for the glance admin to list all six images, by using the is_public=None query string:

 $ curl -H "x-auth-token: `cat glance.token`" http://localhost:9292/v1/images?is_public=None 2>/dev/null | python -mjson.tool | egrep -v 'checksum|container|disk|size'
 {
    "images": [
        {
            "id": "545ac52f-3985-4331-b366-d6058c84b017",
            "name": "private-demo-3",
        },
        {
            "id": "4db5ccbd-f673-44fb-840e-036ccc30d260",
            "name": "private-demo-2",
        },
        {
            "id": "1f886904-5eff-498e-ac5a-418f3cb069bc",
            "name": "private-demo-1",
        },
        {
            "id": "6c86fbe5-5efb-4513-80b2-28bdf309d6ba",
            "name": "public3",
        },
        {
            "id": "34c9bf52-03a5-4637-8fc4-9ce5298bc9a5",
            "name": "public1",
        },
        {
            "id": "151134a5-62e2-44a2-8ede-7b22a9b4c5cc",
            "name": "public2",
        }
    ]
 }

This call means 'give me all images -- whether I own them or not'. It follows that
in this case it *is* legal for 'glance' to use 545ac52f-3985-4331-b366-d6058c84b017 as a marker, and
this works fine with or without the patch:

 $ curl -H "x-auth-token: `cat glance.token`" 'http://localhost:9292/v1/images?is_public=None&marker=545ac52f-3985-4331-b366-d6058c84b017' | python -mjson.tool | egrep -v 'checksum|container|disk|size'
 {
    "images": [
        {
            "id": "4db5ccbd-f673-44fb-840e-036ccc30d260",
            "name": "private-demo-2",
        },
        {
            "id": "1f886904-5eff-498e-ac5a-418f3cb069bc",
            "name": "private-demo-1",
        },
        {
            "id": "6c86fbe5-5efb-4513-80b2-28bdf309d6ba",
            "name": "public3",
        },
        {
            "id": "34c9bf52-03a5-4637-8fc4-9ce5298bc9a5",
            "name": "public1",
        },
        {
            "id": "151134a5-62e2-44a2-8ede-7b22a9b4c5cc",
            "name": "public2",
        }
    ]
 }'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-04-26 16:25:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I think I understand your point, and I agree that this patch won't affect the behavior I posted in my comment. However, what I was trying to show with my comment is that other query parameters should not affect the validity of a given marker. So, <private image uuid> is a valid marker in a list of public + owned + shared images (the default filter), just as <fedora image uuid> is a valid marker in a list of ubuntu images.

Does this make sense? If not, care to take up the gauntlet in #openstack-glance ?

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-04 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-04 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-05-09 15:34:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Restored

New patch.'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-05-09 15:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-09 16:20:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-25 14:09:21.000000000', 'message': "Fix '500' errors related to listing of images

A 500 error is being raised when an admin attempts
to 'list' a non-public image which is owned by another user.
This can happen in several different ways when a
private unowned image id is specified in the URL.

Return 404 rather than 500 in these cases.

Also change some 400 return statuses to 404 where the
syntax of the request is ok.

Fixes bug 1172719.

Change-Id: If77d45c684dd7d4dda9eefd519fc3d36fc57e07a
"}, {'created': '2013-04-25 14:46:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix '500' errors related to metadata access

A 500 error is being raised in some cases where an admin is trying to
specify a private image owned by another user.

This can happen in several different ways when a the private image id
is specified in the URL.

Return 404 rather than 500 in these cases.

If the is_public=None query string is added to the URL then the request
will be processed rather than returning a 404.

Note that this is consistent with the image-list behaviour where
private images which are not owned by the admin are not listed unless
is_public=None is specified.

Also change some 400 return statuses to 404 where the syntax of the
request is ok.

Fixes bug 1172719.

Change-Id: If77d45c684dd7d4dda9eefd519fc3d36fc57e07a
"}, {'created': '2013-04-25 15:01:56.000000000', 'message': "Fix '500' errors related to metadata access

A 500 error is being raised in some cases where an admin is trying to
specify a private image owned by another user.

This can happen in several different ways when a private image id is
specified in the URL.

Return 404 rather than 500 in these cases.

If the is_public=None query string is added to the URL then the request
will be processed rather than returning a 404.

Note that this is consistent with the image-list behaviour where
private images which are not owned by the admin are not listed unless
is_public=None is specified.

Also change some 400 return statuses to 404 where the syntax of the
request is ok.

Fixes bug 1172719.

Change-Id: If77d45c684dd7d4dda9eefd519fc3d36fc57e07a

commit_message:
Prevent '500' error when admin uses private marker

A 500 error was being raised when an admin tried to use the
id of a private image owned by another user as a marker.

Do not return 500 in these cases.

Also added appropriate test coverage.

Fixes bug 1172719.

Change-Id: If77d45c684dd7d4dda9eefd519fc3d36fc57e07a

commit_message:
List only projects accessible by user

When setting user's primary project, display only projects accessible
by user being updated.

Fixes bug 1161963

Change-Id: Ib83f3a1ee83b8d0441267254582824a3fe07b4e3

[{'created': '2013-06-12 10:03:49.000000000', 'message': 'Add /usr/local/bin to the secure_path variable.

This patch will append /usr/local/bin to the sudoers secure_path variable,
by doing so commands prefixed with sudo will then find some binaries
delivered by other elements in that path (e.g nova-rootwrap).

Change-Id: I1ebad8b1932620559a3d90aa39298f9b12e636fd
'}]
commit_message:
Add /usr/local/bin to the secure_path variable.

This patch will append /usr/local/bin to the sudoers secure_path variable,
by doing so commands prefixed with sudo will then find some binaries
delivered by other elements in that path (e.g nova-rootwrap).

Change-Id: I1ebad8b1932620559a3d90aa39298f9b12e636fd

Will it validate the response?'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-07 09:26:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Hi Ivan-Zhu,

> Will it validate the response?

I will not now, but Yuriy said the same comment:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25884/1/openstack/common/wsgi.py

I'd like to clarify the response validation feature. On the feature, should nova send HTTP500 response ideally, if trying to send a bad response?"}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-07 09:40:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

or "API validation framework" is not a good name?
Should the name be "API input validation framework"?'}, {'account_id': 5586, 'date': '2013-05-07 16:14:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

hi, Ken
In this bp: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/v3-api-expected-errors , we will explicitly declare what errors may occur. So I just thought if we could have a schema for response body to check the result. Although the response body return from the code not from client like input, so it must be right. But if we have a schema to check it, we can ensure it like test and it can help to find  JSON/XML inconsistencies.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-08 01:19:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Hi Ivan-Zhu, Thanks for your explanation.

> it can help to find JSON/XML inconsistencies.

Unfortunately, I guess this validation feature cannot find the JSON/XML inconsistencies of response body.
because a single schema will be used for 'dict' data after JSON/XML deserialization(in request validation) or before JSON/XML serialization(in response validation).

I'd like to implement this patchset just for request validation, and we will be able to implement response validation easily in the future when finding some usecases."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-08 01:43:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

After Ivan-Zhu's comment, I feel it is better to rename 'validator_schema' to 'request_body_schema' for clarifying its purpose and adding 'response_body_schema' easily in the future.
Thanks, Ivan-Zhu."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-08 02:35:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-08 02:38:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Works for me

- http://logs.openstack.org/25884/17/check/gate-oslo-incubator-requirements/43 : SUCCESS in 4s
- http://logs.openstack.org/25884/17/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pep8/1696 : SUCCESS in 1m 32s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/25884/17/check/gate-oslo-incubator-docs/1471/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 44s
- http://logs.openstack.org/25884/17/check/gate-oslo-incubator-pyflakes/1320 : SUCCESS in 1m 17s
- http://logs.openstack.org/25884/17/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python26/1655 : SUCCESS in 2m 36s
- http://logs.openstack.org/25884/17/check/gate-oslo-incubator-python27/1656 : SUCCESS in 2m 00s
'}, {'account_id': 6786, 'date': '2013-05-20 20:05:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-21 05:11:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-21 18:17:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: Do not merge

First, I'm really *really* sorry that it took me so long to get to this review. I see that you've had this up for a while now.

Over the course of the last 2 summits the Oslo team has been moving towards using new, publicly maintained, tools for web API work to replace the tools that we've been maintaining internally. The Pecan framework will eventually replace the Oslo WSGI module and the WSME library will be used for API description, validation, and documentation. The etherpads from the summits (https://etherpad.openstack.org/grizzly-common-wsgi-frameworks and https://etherpad.openstack.org/havana-common-wsgi) have most of the details.

It would be much better if you could help with adopting those tools, rather than continue to work on jsonschema. Since this patch is focused on API validation, it seems to make the most sense to look at how that can be done by adapting WSME to work with the current API framework and possibly extending it to support validation features we need that aren't present already. You'll find examples in the ceilometer code base, and I believe some of the other projects are also looking at it."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-22 03:37:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

Hi Doug,

Thanks for reviewing,
I see Pecan/WSME is good for whole OpenStack, and I agree with you at point of applying Pecan/WSME to Oslo instead of WSGI.
For better validation mechanism, I investigated the WSME validation of Ceilometer, and I have a question.

WSME validation can handle the type of API parameters(int, float, text, etc.), but I feel it cannot handle the range of value and the length of text, also it cannot handle required/optional parameters. right?

If so, it is better to use jsonschema instead of WSME validation for strict validation.
How about adding jsonschema validation on Pecan/WSME framework?

> possibly extending it to support validation features we need that aren't present already. 

Is the above your comment related to the demerit of WSME validation?
I cannot understand the comment clearly, sorry."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-22 12:54:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

WSME handles the type conversion and checking automatically. By defining a constructor for the (de)serializer classes, we can add the other checks you describe (ranges, length, etc.). If we have API endpoints that take simple types, we will need another way to attach validation functions for those cases.

There is a WSME parameter to declare a parameter as required, but it appears to have a bug. Optional parameters to controller methods are handled by defining defaults in the method declaration. Optional attributes of data structures are handled by defining defaults in the constructor for the class.

My other comment was about working to enhance WSME, to add more validation support if we have some needs that it does not meet right now. WSME handles XML as well as JSON, so I don't think it makes sense to add jsonschema as a dependency."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-22 13:45:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

Hi Doug,

Thanks for explanation.
I will try some test code with WSME for testing its validation.

> WSME handles XML as well as JSON, so I don't think it makes sense to add jsonschema as a dependency.

jsonschema is not used for not only JSON but also XML, because jsonschema handles 'dict' data after JSON/XML deserialization.

Please see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25884/17/tests/unit/test_wsgi.py .
Both formats are tested with single schema."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-22 13:49:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

Sorry for my mistype.

- jsonschema is not used for not only JSON but also XML, because jsonschema handles 'dict' data after JSON/XML deserialization.

+ jsonschema is used for not only JSON but also XML, because jsonschema handles 'dict' data after JSON/XML deserialization."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-22 14:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

OK. It looks like jsonschema is doing some of the same work as WSME, then.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-29 02:41:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

Hi Doug,

I'm trying to make some test code with WSME validation, and it has not been completed yet.
Could you give me some hint?

Can we specify a dependency between parameters with WMSE validation?

I select "/os-fixed-ips/{fixed_ip}/action" API of Nova as the sample API, because the API has been ported to Nova v3 API and the first target of this framework is Nova v3 API.
The API has two parameters like the following:
  {
    "reserve": "192.168.1.1" 
  }
  {
    "unreserve": "192.168.1.1" 
  }
On the above sample API, "reserve" and "unreserve" parameters should not be specified together. (It means exclusion.)
The oneOf keyword of jsonschema does it.

The test code of jsonschema has been wrote on the following etherpad.
https://etherpad.openstack.org/NovaApiValidationFramework

To be honest, now I am facing other problem with integrating Pecan and WSME during making some test code, and I'll keep trying.
but I'd like to know the feature of WSME validation previously.'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-05-29 08:07:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

I have gotten over a problem related to Pecan/WSME integration, and I am testing WSME validation with sample code.
(The sample code is on https://etherpad.openstack.org/NovaApiValidationFramework)

I found some concerns of WSME validation through sample code.
* Required option(mandatory=True) does not work as Doug said.
* The instance "None" is not validated.
** Ex) Even if defining the parameter 'foo' as int, {"foo": null} cannot be distinguished as invalid.

I'm afraid to say that I feel jsonschema is better from viewpoint of flexibility/quality now.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-06 16:20:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

See Ieba96718264ad2ddfba63b65425f7e5bbb8606a9 - if Nova is going to go ahead and use this, I'm not against it going into oslo-incubator - e.g. if it makes sense for Nova to use it, it probably makes sense for Cinder too

Doug - what say you?"}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-06-12 09:38:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: Abandoned

Oslo's wsgi code has been deprecated now, and this patch should be abandoned."}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-11 10:49:51.000000000', 'message': 'Add missing Keystone settings to scrubber conf

The provided conf file for glance-scrubber was missing the auth settings
stanza required to make it work 'out of the box' in a Keystone environment
such as Devstack.

Also add the "Security Options" line just below for consistency with the
other configs.

Change-Id: I1182fd3a7a79c0f6aeb601d65c31e462fb3610bb
'}]
commit_message:
Add missing Keystone settings to scrubber conf

The provided conf file for glance-scrubber was missing the auth settings
stanza required to make it work 'out of the box' in a Keystone environment
such as Devstack.

Also add the "Security Options" line just below for consistency with the
other configs.

Change-Id: I1182fd3a7a79c0f6aeb601d65c31e462fb3610bb

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: I63d80c00e94f1831e8f79faa87d57a152338dba7

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: If390cdf328b361d0f76315083f3e6da97bbe4b2f

commit_message:
Add lists of instance objects

This adds a list-of-instances object, which can house the "get all"
methods for instances. It's very simple, emulates a list, but
provides us an object-oriented way to get multiple instances that
mirrors the model.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: Id6579030b88b92d4cb7db13ee6718ad01db7bf63

commit_message:
Mix snapshots and images tables together

Don't filter snapshots from images data, display image_type column in images table,
don't translate image string in get_image_type method, don't show LaunchImage button when
image is in different state than active, remove snapshots table from the UI, update tests

Fixes: bug #1140760

Change-Id: Ie6cc5bc98fa97de00b55540fe9f60e90d20acab3

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-28 20:35:10.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: improve the specification of network disks

Allow zero or more hosts, and make the name optional, since only a
host is needed to use nbd. This allows cinder to fully specify the
location of a sheepdog or rbd volume without depending on extra
configuration files, and lays the groundwork for supporting nbd.

Rename the internal attribute source_host to source_name to reflect
its usage in the libvirt xml, and add source_hosts and source_ports
attributes to store the new information.

Fixes: bug 1077817
blueprint better-libvirt-network-volume-support
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Change-Id: I8ac431751692e52ba0786768cea996388962922d
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: improve the specification of network disks

Allow zero or more hosts, and make the name optional, since only a
host is needed to use nbd. This allows cinder to fully specify the
location of a sheepdog or rbd volume without depending on extra
configuration files, and lays the groundwork for supporting nbd.

Rename the internal attribute source_host to source_name to reflect
its usage in the libvirt xml, and add source_hosts and source_ports
attributes to store the new information.

Fixes: bug 1077817
blueprint better-libvirt-network-volume-support
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Change-Id: I8ac431751692e52ba0786768cea996388962922d

commit_message:
Improve detection of config errors in nvp.ini file

Detect if default params specified in the config file match
what it is returned by NVP.

Fixes bug #1190032

Change-Id: I8084dc938726e050ba82410cbc02a161cc0aa17f

in stand alone mode. The keystone docs indicate that

commit_message:
Key error when auth in standalone mode

Fix a key error caused from the response of authing
in stand alone mode. The keystone docs indicate that
the schema for a response user name is ['user']['name']
rather than ['user']['username'].

Change-Id: I9ac94feeef8f9f2dedaa3842f64a3491e701e199

is applicable for:
 - pool_size
 - max_overflow
 - pool_timeout

By increasing the pool_size and the max_overflow and lowering the timeout
the issue reported in the bug is resolved.

commit_message:
Expose most common QueuePoll parameters from SQLAlchemy

Fixes bug 1160442

The defualt parameters are used unless otherwise configured. This
is applicable for:
 - pool_size
 - max_overflow
 - pool_timeout

By increasing the pool_size and the max_overflow and lowering the timeout
the issue reported in the bug is resolved.

NOTE: the configuration values enable the user to make use of the default
QueuePool tuning values.

(cherry picked from commit 725d636da5959aee1954a8e8d5ff383d2a8b7bb9)

Change-Id: I918f3eae0a1c9d06184c8aee6d27988613dec97c

commit_message:
Start Gating on Pyflakes and Hacking

Instead of globally ignoring Pyflakes and Hacking
warnings, only blacklist those that occur frequently
and fix the others. Start gating on those checks.

Change-Id: Ice032c16d445ef08ef018bcdc5c221ab3c323755

[{'created': '2013-06-11 14:18:15.000000000', 'message': "Allow disabling ssl compression for glance client

Add a new parameter 'glance_api_ssl_compression' which allows
disabling ssl layer compression negotiation for glance requests.

This may improve data throughput, eg when high network bandwidth is
available and you are using already compressed image formats such as
qcow2 .

Addresses bug 1189903.

Change-Id: I180501cc25a1ea177d0d8c52a879682b8a3921c6
"}]
commit_message:
Allow disabling ssl compression for glance client

Add a new parameter 'glance_api_ssl_compression' which allows
disabling ssl layer compression negotiation for glance requests.

This may improve data throughput, eg when high network bandwidth is
available and you are using already compressed image formats such as
qcow2 .

Addresses bug 1189903.

Change-Id: I180501cc25a1ea177d0d8c52a879682b8a3921c6

commit_message:
Consistent upload naming

The image.rb provider uses '#{name}' to upload, but the negation check
uses '#{name.to_s}' which has been causing duplicate images to be uploaded
Made both to use for '#{name}'

This is a regression of an older version of this cookbook

Change-Id: I299a357d2311c73aa6528ccca3c3b66614902fb1

"glance image-create" command works even without giving <name> in the argument. The status of the created image is "Queued" and <name> column is empty.
<name> should be a mandatory field for the command.

In validate_image_meta function is updated to check on image name.

Change-Id: Iadf13166656eaf051787c90650840ace468b4161
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes: bug 1184965

"glance image-create" command works even without giving <name> in the argument. The status of the created image is "Queued" and <name> column is empty.
<name> should be a mandatory field for the command.

In validate_image_meta function is updated to check on image name.

Change-Id: Iadf13166656eaf051787c90650840ace468b4161

variable root disk

Allows a resulting root disk size to be determined by the
instance type, min_disk and the virtual image size

blueprint variable-size-root-disk
