revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-21 16:03:23.000000000', 'message': 'Added volume status check.

In cinder.cinder.volume.driver.VolumeDriver added abstract method
`avaliability_check`, which should provide value status check for
every particular driver. This method is implemented in
cinder.cinder.volume.drivers.lvm.LVMVolumeDriver. In
cinder.cinder.volume.manager uses `avaliability_check`, which does not
change default behavior if it is not implemented.
In cinder.cinder.volume.utils.execute added optional argument `wait`
which will force `execute` to guaranteed waiting for the process
termination. This is required for volume creation to return
availability status strictly after volume was physically created.

Fixes bug #673756

Change-Id: Ia0ce8caa9daadde2be587ed73a98ec1cdf791634
'}, {'created': '2013-05-22 13:47:02.000000000', 'message': 'Added volume status check.

Created volume is reporting its state as "available" a bit of seconds before
it is really available. The cause is `manager.create_volume` method does
not care about volume creation process termination.

In volume.driver.VolumeDriver added method `avaliability_check` with a default
implementation. The method should be implemented for each particular driver
to provide value status check. In the default implementation, this method
does not affect the existing behavior of drivers.
In volume.utils.execute added optional argument `wait`
which will force `execute` to guaranteed waiting for the process
termination. In this way volume creation returns availability status strictly
after volume was physically created.

commit_message:
Added volume status check.

Created volume is reporting its state as "available" a bit of seconds before
it is really become available. The cause is `manager.create_volume` method
does not care about volume creation process termination.

In `volume.driver.VolumeDriver` added method `avaliability_check` with a
default implementation. The method should be implemented for each particular
driver to provide value status check. In the default implementation, this
method does not affect the existing behavior of drivers.
In `volume.utils.execute` added optional argument `wait`
which will force `execute` to guaranteed waiting for the process
termination. In this way volume creation returns availability status strictly
after volume was physically created.

Fixes: bug #673756
Change-Id: Ia0ce8caa9daadde2be587ed73a98ec1cdf791634

commit_message:
python3: compatibility for iteritems and iterkeys

Use six to allow python2/pyton3 for iteritems and
iterkeys.

six.iteriems() replaces dictionary.iteritems() (python2)
and dictionary.iterms() (python3)

six.iterkeys() replaces dictionary.iterkeys (python2)
and dictionary.keys() (python3)

Change-Id: I26c80b78a7dedf3aa32eedf01a83ff6d1e592ba7
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

[{'created': '2013-06-07 11:53:28.000000000', 'message': 'Add missing attributes to xml deserializer for volume request

The v1 and v2 xml deserializers for volume requests are missing
support for the imageRef, snapshot_id and source_volid attributes
resulting in xml format create volume requests which specify any
of those attributes being silently ignored. This fix adds support
to v1 and v2 and extends the volumes unit tests to check for this.
Also includes some minor debug logging enhancements to make this
easier to find in future.

Fixes bug #1188581

Change-Id: Ib661c4a961c57e682e0e4e6db98d863b3a99cf71
'}, {'created': '2013-06-11 07:40:06.000000000', 'message': 'Add missing attributes to xml deserializer for volume request

The v1 and v2 xml deserializers for volume requests are missing
support for the imageRef, snapshot_id and source_volid attributes
resulting in xml format create volume requests which specify any
of those attributes being silently ignored. This fix adds support
to v1 and v2 and extends the volumes unit tests to check for this.
Also includes some minor debug logging enhancements to make this
easier to find in future.

Fixes bug #1188581

Change-Id: Ib661c4a961c57e682e0e4e6db98d863b3a99cf71
'}]
commit_message:
Add missing attributes to xml deserializer for volume request

The v1 and v2 xml deserializers for volume requests are missing
support for the imageRef, snapshot_id and source_volid attributes
resulting in xml format create volume requests which specify any
of those attributes being silently ignored. This fix adds support
to v1 and v2 and extends the volumes unit tests to check for this.
Also includes some minor debug logging enhancements to make this
easier to find in future.

Fixes bug #1188581

Change-Id: Ib661c4a961c57e682e0e4e6db98d863b3a99cf71

commit_message:
Add update method of security group name and description

make it possible to edit the name and description of
common security groups, we can not rename the default.
nova patch : https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29490/

Fixes: bug #918393

Change-Id: I559f2fa09c1f205d3bbe7352fc169152e6b38586

[{'created': '2013-06-12 01:50:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix cloud-init-nocloud to actually work.

Bug 1124593 reported that ssh host keys were not being created, and the
lack of seed metadata files was the cause. Add those files and remove
the workaround.

Change-Id: I6fb55be7f8c7efd1f75aeba9123f495e312ff695
'}]
commit_message:
Fix cloud-init-nocloud to actually work.

Bug 1124593 reported that ssh host keys were not being created, and the
lack of seed metadata files was the cause. Add those files and remove
the workaround.

Change-Id: I6fb55be7f8c7efd1f75aeba9123f495e312ff695

commit_message:
Use Python 3.x compatible octal literals

Python 3.x deprecated octal literals in the form 0755.
Use the Python 2.x compatible version 0o755 instead.

Change-Id: I90ea601847752ae04d4e403ffa16a537efe442e2

'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-06-06 17:29:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

I'm looking at moving ssh & ipmi (& pxe) into ironic/drivers/modules/ as suggested, and it presented a question to me.

I had originally stubbed the pxe_ipmi and pxe_ssh drivers as a means to test both the ipmi and ssh *interfaces*, since the unit tests need stevedore to load a driver. As those unit tests don't in any way depend on an actual pxe driver, I am thinking that there should be separate fake_ipmi, fake_ssh, and fake_pxe drivers which merge the fake interfaces with the real ipmi, ssh, and pxe interfaces for testing those in isolation. That all seems simple.

The question then is, should those "fake+real" drivers live in a separate namespace (eg, reserved for testing)? Or, do they have any practical application -- is a driver that only implements the power interface useful?'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-06-06 17:58:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-06 18:01:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

- no more deploy + control driver; nodes have one and only one driver.
- interfaces for core, standard, and vendor functionality now clearly

- convert ipmi and ssh driver classes into interfaces.

'}, {'created': '2013-06-05 20:51:53.000000000', 'message': 'Restructuring driver API and inheritence.

Based on discussions after the Ironic meeting on June 03,
this is a re-working of the internal driver API. These changes impact
the public API service, but since that is largely not implemented yet,
this change does not attempt to affect the public API.

Highlights:
- No more deploy + control driver; nodes have one and only one driver.
  This drops the deploy_driver and deploy_info parameters,
  and renames control_driver -> driver, and control_info -> driver_info.
- Interfaces for core, standard, and vendor functionality now clearly
  defined in the driver API.
- Improve Fake driver to demonstrate use of interfaces.
- Convert IPMI and SSH driver classes into interfaces.
- Stub for the pxe interfaces.
- Stub implementations of pxe+ipmi and pxe+ssh drivers.

A separate doc change will follow this to update the API v1 spec.

Also includes some cosmetic cleanup of test_ssh.py and test_ipmi.py.

Change-Id: I057ede8e07b1b57010e81ef58415debe0ba8b934

'}, {'created': '2013-06-06 17:58:24.000000000', 'message': 'Restructuring driver API and inheritance.

Based on discussions during and after the Ironic team meeting on June
03, regarding support for substantially different driver work flows,
this is a re-working of the internal driver API.

tl;dr: The strict separation of "control" and "deploy" driver was an
       artefact of the ipmi + pxe implementation used in nova-baremetal,
       and does not map on to all drivers. Furthermore, the prior
       implementation did not accurately represent the separation of
       "core", "standard", and "vendor-specific" driver functionality.

These changes impact the v1 API structure, but since that is largely not
implemented yet, this change does not attempt to affect the public API
itself.

Highlights:
- No more deploy + control driver; nodes have one and only one driver.
  This drops the deploy_driver and deploy_info parameters,
  and renames control_driver -> driver, and control_info -> driver_info.
- Interfaces for core, standard, and vendor functionality now clearly
  defined in the driver API.
- Improve Fake driver to demonstrate use of interfaces.
- Convert IPMI and SSH driver classes into interfaces, and move to
  drivers/modules/ directory.
- Stub for the pxe interfaces.
- Stub implementations of pxe+ipmi and pxe+ssh drivers.
- driver_info field uses more standard names, but requires
  driver-specific data to be in a nested object. Examples in
  tests/db/utils.py as before.

A separate doc change will follow this to update the API v1 spec.

Also includes some cosmetic cleanup of test_ssh.py and test_ipmi.py.

Change-Id: I057ede8e07b1b57010e81ef58415debe0ba8b934

commit_message:
Restructuring driver API and inheritance.

Based on discussions during and after the Ironic team meeting on June
03, regarding support for substantially different driver work flows,
this is a re-working of the internal driver API.

tl;dr: The strict separation of "control" and "deploy" driver was an
       artefact of the ipmi + pxe implementation used in nova-baremetal,
       and does not map on to all drivers. Furthermore, the prior
       implementation did not accurately represent the separation of
       "core", "standard", and "vendor-specific" driver functionality.

These changes impact the v1 API structure, but since that is largely not
implemented yet, this change does not attempt to affect the public API
itself.

Highlights:
- No more deploy + control driver; nodes have one and only one driver.
  This drops the deploy_driver and deploy_info parameters,
  and renames control_driver -> driver, and control_info -> driver_info.
- Interfaces for core, standard, and vendor functionality now clearly
  defined in the driver API.
- Improve Fake driver to demonstrate use of interfaces.
- Convert IPMI and SSH driver classes into interfaces, and move to
  drivers/modules/ directory.
- Stub for the pxe interfaces.
- Stub implementations of pxe+ipmi and pxe+ssh drivers.
- driver_info field uses more standard names, but requires
  driver-specific data to be in a nested object. Examples in
  tests/db/utils.py as before.

A separate doc change will follow this to update the API v1 spec.

Also includes some cosmetic cleanup of test_ssh.py and test_ipmi.py.

Change-Id: I057ede8e07b1b57010e81ef58415debe0ba8b934

commit_message:
Remove deleted[_at] from base object.

Ironic is not using soft-deletion, and since the database models do not
have the deleted or deleted_at fields, neither should the objects.

Change-Id: I152366e75d5d3b0c25eb509db91f411bcc04c6f6

commit_message:
Make object actions pass positional arguments

Port Commit 5d9cb7dd354dc1a1eae9985521c0f4b2ea4d876e from Nova.

This changes the Object API to also pass positional arguments
to remotable methods. Previously, we required only keyword arguments
to these methods in order to mirror our current RPC behavior.
This is not really necessary and could be confusing.

Change-Id: Icd725a2df48883564c0ac131a9a8ef33817f30c5

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-11 23:39:58.000000000', 'message': 'Manage the messagebus service on non-RHEL RHEL-like platforms

Previously, the test for enabling the "messagebus" service checked
for "$operatingsystem == RedHat", which only matches on RHEL;
$operatingsystem is "CentOS" on CentOS machines. I think we want
"$osfamily" here, which is "RedHat" on CentOS machines.

I also added a test for "$operatingsystem != Fedora" to preserve
the existing behavior on those machines, which as far as I can
tell do not require this service.

Change-Id: I020591006df87a9766cefbe36740940915924180
'}]
commit_message:
Manage the messagebus service on non-RHEL RHEL-like platforms

Previously, the test for enabling the "messagebus" service checked
for "$operatingsystem == RedHat", which only matches on RHEL;
$operatingsystem is "CentOS" on CentOS machines. I think we want
"$osfamily" here, which is "RedHat" on CentOS machines.

I also added a test for "$operatingsystem != Fedora" to preserve
the existing behavior on those machines, which as far as I can
tell do not require this service.

Change-Id: I020591006df87a9766cefbe36740940915924180

commit_message:
Automate network router setup.

If quantum.ovs.fixed_range is defined, that network will need to have a
router attached in order to reach the ec2 metadata service, or to reach
any floating ip ranges.

If quantum.floatingip_range is defined, that subnet will be created and
assigned to the default router. This is independent of openvswitch,
which is why it is not in the quantum.ovs namespace.

commit_message:
Add base mixin class for object lists

This provides a base class that provides the bulk of the common
functionality that objects implementing a list of objects will
need.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I5bc4e64cc8fe2d780251cbc43f2ee45f4e0f820a

'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-05-11 21:58:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

I just dont get it - I do not see the need for such parallelism. 

Even if parallelism is needed - we can use threads and need not use seperate processes.  

Hence the entire part parts thing as well as it configuration is not needed and can be hiden by the threads implementation.

Again, I do not even see the need for threads on top of greenthreads.Do you really need all your CPUs working to expire objects? Isnt getting 100% of one CPU for this task enough?"}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2013-05-12 23:20:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

We had a person on the irc channel say they had a cluster in which the object expirer daemon was unable to keep up with the objects that needed to be expired.  Hence this patch.

This *is* the version with threads.  A GreenPool is a pool of green threads.

In addition to threading, the object expirer can also now be run as multiple processes.  That's the part/parts stuff.

Users can use multiple processes, multiple threads, or both.

I think this patch/how things are named is pretty straightforward."}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:38:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 19:24:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Please add something to explain how this works in the docs.  Something like: 

An example of how to run the object-expirer through 3 daemons would be to set up three config files, one for each daemon.  All the configs would have:

parts = 3 

This means that the work is divided into 3 parts.

The first daemon's object-expirer.conf would have 

part = 0

The second daemon would have part = 1, and the third daemon part = 2.

With these settings each daemon will process one third of the work."}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2013-05-20 15:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-20 15:47:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

To clarify, this patch will by default (i.e. an existing deployer updates code but not configs) increase the (single) object expirer's DELETE concurrency from 1 to 1024, right?  That seems totally reasonable, but also perhaps worth mentioning in the commit message (and eventually release notes).

In that vein, the commit message should probably have Doc Impact (or is it DocImpact?).

Finally, one minor spelling/grammar nitpick inline :)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 16:00:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-06 06:14:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

I wish  to repeat my objection to this patch. 

The same goals as achieved by this implementation can be achieved without adding unnecessary complexity to the admin. This complexity adds more room for configuration problems which are hard to impossible to detect. 


Since there is a simple alternative implementation that can be used to achieve the same goal without the added complexity, I prefer that we did not merge this. 

The alternative solution is using OS threads instead of OS processes. 

This implementation use 1. Green Threads and 2. OS Processes for maximal concurrency. 

I find this objectionable as green threads would probably be enough here, but if others feel greenthreads would not offer sufficient level of parallelism, an alternative practically similar implementation could use: 1. Green Threads and 2. OS Level Threads for maximal concurrency (instead of processes).

The advantage of using OS level threads instead of OS processes is that the admin will no longer be required to set the process if and run multiple OS processes (this is also more efficient resource wise, more controllable as there is a single process in the system etc.)"}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2013-06-06 15:53:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2013-06-06 16:09:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

David, thanks for finding that text that I failed to change.

I understand your objections but we decided to go this way so the daemons can be run on multiple servers.  Using os level threads would not accomplish this goal.

We suspect that one process and the default single process concurrency of 1024 will be enough for many cases.

So, in those many cases, there is no extra config or operational complexity.

If a cluster needs more concurrency than one process can provide, the config/operational complexity is higher but it's not substantial.  There are many more complex things in swift.

I think the way this is coded is a reasonable way to accomplish more concurrency for this daemon."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-06 16:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Works for me

commit_message:
Add parallelism to object expirer daemon.

Two types of parallelism are added:

- concurrency to speed up what a single process does
- a way to run multiple daemons to work on different parts of the work

DocImpact

Change-Id: I48997f68eb2fd8de19a5ee8b9fcdf76dde2ba0ab

commit_message:
Fix assumed port has port_security_enabled

Previously if adding a security group to an instance it would fail
if the port did not contain port_security_enabled=True. This patch
also changes the unit tests so that networks by default are not
associated with port_security_enabled=True because this is only true
if a plugin is running the port_security extension.

Fixes bug 1189059

Change-Id: Ieebb7aafba01c18164b86a01a3c289a6957321e4

subject: Use threadpools in the object server for performance.

'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-04-22 13:07:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(13 inline comments)

Sam, 

I gave this some thought as this is a very important work. 

See inline comments.

DH"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-04-25 01:06:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

To answer David Hadas's question about run_in_thread versus force_run_in_thread, the answer is part technical and part historical.

The technical answer: certain operations end up taking a really really long time, like tens of seconds. Consider the fsync. When a disk is a bit busy, an object-server process's write() calls mostly end up in buffer cache, and then after some number of bytes (512 MiB by default) have gone out via write() calls, the process calls fsync(). Now hundreds of MiB have to hit disks, and that can take tens of seconds. In order to not starve every other connected client, we always run that operation in an external thread.

The historical answer: if you look at the code before this changeset, you'll see two types of call site for blocking system calls. The first kind are simply made directly, and the hope is that they'll be reasonably fast. The second kind use eventlet.tpool to do the job, and it's expected that they'll be slow.

I need to express two different expectations at different times. Right now, 'run_in_thread' means 'this is a fairly short blocking call, and running it in a separate thread will improve performance, but you can expect to be okay either way', while 'force_run_in_thread' means 'if this is run in the main thread, performance will be so awful that you can expect users to leave flaming bags of dog poo on your doorstep'. 

So that's how it got to be this way. I agree that the function names are pretty confusing, and I'm definitely open to suggestions."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-04-25 01:12:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

And as far as the ThreadPool vs. DummyThreadPool thing goes, that's just an artifact of how I developed it. Before I added in the configuration stuff, I would swap them out in code and run the functional tests to make sure it was working in both cases and to compare test runtimes and such. If you have a strong objection to having both classes around, I'm fine with combining the two."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-04-25 17:24:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

Fixety fix fix'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-04-25 18:22:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (5 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-04-25 18:27:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-25 19:17:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

At a minimum, if you comment that stuff out, the threadpool tests do fail."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-04-30 16:30:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Ah, cool, never mind then.'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-04-30 22:15:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm still in the middle of reviewing this and have some issues with it, but still need some time to finish going through it.  Just wanted to make sure someone else didn't push it through."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-01 18:45:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Well, feel free to post partial feedback so I can start thinking about how to make this more palatable.'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-05-01 22:00:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

So from an idealistic standpoint, it would be nice if this functionality could exist in eventlet as a green module, and we could just do something like:

from eventlet.green import fileio

And then all normal file io would be async (even if handled via threads on the backend).  Even if this starts in a module in swift that could eventually contributed back to eventlet.

That said, I know it might be asking a bit much.  So looking at this patch as is, a few comments.

Is there a reason why the DiskFile object isn't instantiated with a threadpool?

I need to think about it a bit more, but the current implementation seems a little over-complicated.  I'm not sure I'm convinced that we need to have threads pools per disk rather than one general threadpool.

I also did as much performance testing as I could on an SAIO (unfortunately it is a bit difficult to test the performance characteristics of this patch).  There was no overall performance difference on PUT and DEL requests, but interestingly, there was a 30% increase in GET performance, so it does show some promise.  On the downside, one benchmark ran into a case where DELs got stuck at 11/s for the threadpool implementation, and I'm not sure why.  I also haven't been able to reproduce this.  It would be nice if there was an easy way to turn the overall functionality on and off."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-05-01 22:04:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just as a small aside, I guess you can "turn the functionality off" by setting the threadpool to 0'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-05-01 22:06:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Gah! and evidently I can't type... I meant to ask:

Is there a reason why DiskObject isn't instantiated with a threadpool for object DEL?"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-01 22:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Chuck: re: "I'm not sure I'm convinced that we need to have thread pools per disk rather than one general threadpool."

A per-disk threadpool is important to prevent a slow disk from "poisoning" the rest of the server (Intel's benchmarking with COSBench exhibited that pathological behavior, for instance).   A per-disk threadpool approach also keeps the set of available outstanding work actually tied to something physical that's important: the spindle whose IOPs are limited.  It lets you limit the depth of outstanding requests per spindle which you can't with a general disk I/O threadpool.

So I think the per-disk business is an important aspect of the patch.'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-05-01 22:30:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Darrell except that for a large number of the threadpool calls (the ones calling force_run_in_thread) are just going to pop it on to an eventlet tpool anyways if it runs out of threads, so you are already going to have that issue there.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-01 22:39:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

So, as far as the DELETE thing goes, that's an oversight on my part that needs fixing. Thanks for spotting it.

With respect to the per-disk threadpool, I did it that way to minimize the impact of a slow disk on requests served by other disks. If you had just one big threadpool, they'll end up spending most of their time blocked on IO to the slow disk.

As far as force_run_in_thread, that won't pop stuff out to eventlet.tpool *unless* the threadpool is configured with 0 threads. If a threadpool is configured with 5 threads, it'll only ever have 5 threads, and tpool doesn't enter into it. The only reason tpool is even mentioned is to preserve the old performance characteristics when not using the per-disk threadpools.

(And as you noted, the behavior can be effectively disabled by setting threads_per_disk=0.)"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-01 22:39:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

Missed a couple spots.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-01 23:31:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-02 00:17:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

So I'm not sure what to do with this patch.  It seems to work, but is difficult to effectively test.  In testing on my SAIO, with a plain swift bench, PUTs and DELs are about 5% slower and GETs.  I then ran two swift bench tests concurrently to get mixed GETs and PUTs.  With the Thread pool, PUTs were a little better,  but GETs were substantially worse."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-05-03 21:19:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Try again:

So I'm not sure what to do with this patch. It seems to work, but is difficult to effectively test. In testing on my SAIO, with a plain swift bench, PUTs and DELs are about 5% slower and GETs were about 25% faster. I then ran two swift bench tests concurrently to get mixed GETs and PUTs. With the Thread pool, PUTs were a little better, but GETs were substantially worse."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-03 21:34:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Yeah, it'll end up being worse on an all-in-one if you're really using threads. The overhead of using a threadpool is going to chew up CPU for no real gain in that case.

The performance benefits don't really show up until you have multiple spindles / disks / separate IO domains. On a SAIO, with the loopback-mounted stuff all on the same disk, you're not going to see much in the way of gains, especially if you're running 4 object servers on 4 loopbacks on 1 disk in a dinky VM with 1 CPU (which describes my SAIO perfectly; not sure about yours)."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-06 18:53:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-14 21:52:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

If you're in a really CPU-limited environment, then the extra overhead of doing all your IO in a separate thread could well make Swift slower.

Also, there's always the possibility of bugs, and this threadpool code is quite new. I've run a cluster with it and done some testing without problems, but if there are cases that cause deadlocks, livelocks, or other horrible thread problems, then it'd be nice for operators to be able to turn it off."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-15 01:33:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I agree with Sam that it should be configurable w/default == off.

In other news, still working on getting some before/after numbers from a little dinky cluster that's at least bare-metal with spinning disks..."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-17 16:41:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Now with NUMBERS: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/pub?key=0AqVdgVLO4IoCdDBBa3phZGVKYkxsSTV2bFIyYzI2U1E&output=html

You can comment here, or better yet, get ahold of me in IRC if you want to discuss the results of this benchmarking or the methodology.

Note that the thread-pooling does raise CPU utilization across the board, but more work is also being done per unit time.  It's hard to measure how much of that additional CPU consumption is due to the threading/queue overhead vs. actually getting more work done.  But eyeballing some per-process-category CPU graphs, the tradeoff seems reasonable."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-20 17:13:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-20 17:57:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-26 18:20:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-26 18:25:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Patch set 11 just adds a little grouping of the chunk writing in swift.obj.server.DiskWriter.write(). Since there was already a loop to write out the whole chunk, it made sense to move that whole unit into a threadpool call instead of making a bunch of smaller threadpool calls.

In the default case, this doesn't result in any change in when fdatasync() gets called, as the default network_chunk_size divides the default bytes_per_sync. If you've configured different values, this may move the fdatasync() call by up to one network_chunk_size. However, this lets me avoid having a threadpool call make another threadpool call, which would open a big can of deadlocks."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-26 19:05:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-04-18 18:37:34.000000000', 'message': "Use threadpools in the object server for performance.

Without a (per-disk) threadpool, requests to a slow disk would affect
all clients by blocking the entire eventlet reactor on read/write/et
cetera. The slower the disk, the worse the performance. On an object
server, you frequently have at least one slow disk due to auditing and
replication activity sucking up all the available IO. By kicking those
blocking calls out to a separate OS thread, we let the eventlet
reactor make progress in other greenthreads, and by having a per-disk
pool, we ensure that one slow disk can't suck up all the resources of
an entire object server.

There were a few blocking that were done with eventlet.tpool, but
that's a fixed-size global threadpool, so I moved them to the per-disk
threadpools. If the object server is configured not to use per-disk
threadpools, (i.e. threads_per_disk = 0, which is the default), those

commit_message:
Use threadpools in the object server for performance.

Without a (per-disk) threadpool, requests to a slow disk would affect
all clients by blocking the entire eventlet reactor on
read/write/etc. The slower the disk, the worse the performance. On an
object server, you frequently have at least one slow disk due to
auditing and replication activity sucking up all the available IO. By
kicking those blocking calls out to a separate OS thread, we let the
eventlet reactor make progress in other greenthreads, and by having a
per-disk pool, we ensure that one slow disk can't suck up all the
resources of an entire object server.

There were a few blocking calls that were done with eventlet.tpool,
but that's a fixed-size global threadpool, so I moved them to the
per-disk threadpools. If the object server is configured not to use
per-disk threadpools, (i.e. threads_per_disk = 0, which is the
default), those call sites will still ultimately end up using
eventlet.tpool.execute. You won't end up blocking a whole object
server while waiting for a huge fsync.

If you decide not to use threadpools, the only extra overhead should
be a few extra Python function calls here and there. This is
accomplished by setting threads_per_disk = 0 in the config.

blueprint concurrent-disk-io
Change-Id: I490f8753d926fdcee3a0c65c5aaf715bc2b7c290

So, the nice thing that you got before was a correlation between token and user. This change loses that correlation; as far as I can see, the user doesn't then get logged anywhere.

Log line from master on my SAIO:

Jun  7 08:17:42 saio proxy-server 192.168.22.1 192.168.22.1 07/Jun/2013/15/17/42 GET /v1.0/AUTH_test/foocon/etc/proxy-server.conf-sample HTTP/1.0 200 - - test%2CAUTH_tk4241a31724a249dba2b99563b3897ec4 - 15952 - tx0f25bfcd9c4f4732aa026-0051b1f996 - 0.0615 -

I think you can remedy this by logging something that has the token, username, and transaction ID in it; that way people can still see what's going on."}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-11 15:16:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-11 15:17:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Chuck

If trans_id is never set by anyone before in the pipeline, it cannot be printed by tempauth. 

Do you prefer to see tempauth changed to create trans_id if such is not created previously in the pipeline?

@Sam, Check: I think we better off without trans_id as this entire exercise is for SAIO use only (unless someone is using tempauth for real..) and we can correlate the token to the user without needing trans_id.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-11 17:53:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

That's weird. The catch_errors middleware sets trans_id, and it should be the first thing in your middleware pipeline.

Chuck: is the above true for the machine on which you are testing?"}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-11 19:11:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Tempauth - remove change made to HTTP_X_AUTH_TOKEN

tempauth changes HTTP_X_AUTH_TOKEN although not required by function
preventing swift extendability.
(prevents other middleware to rely on HTTP_X_AUTH_TOKEN representing
the token sent by the client).

Change-Id: I7ed6f9b5d0a5a203326a3912ef27cf29d2d4e9ce
Fixes: Bug #1189410

Performance Note:

The following simple python program illustrates the performance
advantage of not attempting to invoke startswith() method of a string
when we know the argument is an empty string.

    import time

    curs = []
    for i in range(10000):
        curs.append(['nameofthing%d'%(i), 1, 2, 3, 4])

    beg = time.time()
    for i in range(1000):
        x = [r for r in curs]
    end = time.time()
    print "without: %.2f" % (end - beg)

    beg = time.time()
    for i in range(1000):
        y = [r for r in curs if r[0].startswith('')]
    end = time.time()
    print "with: %.2f" % (end - beg)

    # Output:
    # $ python ~/test_startswith.py
    # without: 0.60
    # with: 2.73

Change-Id: I1ac72cd7932953b0efe7db8ff591829b985b8d73
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Add non-slash delimiter tests

Also expand the logic following the select statement in
list_objects_iter and list_containers_iter to document the state
following the prefix and delimiter tests.

Also remove doc strings which obscure test names when run with
"./.unittests" script.

Performance Note:

The following simple python program illustrates the performance
advantage of not attempting to invoke startswith() method of a string
when we know the argument is an empty string.

    import time

    curs = []
    for i in range(10000):
        curs.append(['nameofthing%d'%(i), 1, 2, 3, 4])

    beg = time.time()
    for i in range(1000):
        x = [r for r in curs]
    end = time.time()
    print "without: %.2f" % (end - beg)

    beg = time.time()
    for i in range(1000):
        y = [r for r in curs if r[0].startswith('')]
    end = time.time()
    print "with: %.2f" % (end - beg)

    # Output:
    # $ python ~/test_startswith.py
    # without: 0.60
    # with: 2.73

Change-Id: I1ac72cd7932953b0efe7db8ff591829b985b8d73
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add policy checking for transfer create/accept.

This patch adds policy checks for transfer create/accept
as well as adding the associated default policy.  In addition
we add the wrap in the volume/api accept_transfer method.

Fixes bug: 1187910

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: I729ed2f646aa514fbb7b7dfc4a070df2f7b27ff4

commit_message:
Add deleted flag to NovaObject base

This is present in NovaBase for the SQLAlchemy objects, and is
expected to be in the NovaObjects as well.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I1698d5a986d17899dfcefb9ec65d6b2623af2da3

"}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-05-09 16:10:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

"do you have timing numbers for how much time this saves in a normal run? if it causes new flakiness for not much time savings, it will make the average gate time longer."

We call the wait functions many hundred time, so it will give us many hundred of seconds.

Everything expected to work with 1 build interval, in the past we just increased this value without investigating the root cause. 

The flakiness issues will happen again by just adding new test cases. We should find the real issues instead of hiding them and increasing the gate time.

We must hunt these issues before we go for parallel.

Looks like this volume issue is stabil, so we can solve a gating issue.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-17 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-17 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

commit_message:
Decrease the tempest build interval

Decreasing the build interval leads to faster state change detection,
so it will speed up the gating jobs.

It may increase the possibility of a "hidden" issues causes
indeterministic test results.

Change-Id: Ida5e7296e4ea53d761e0efef34376699337d8377

[{'created': '2013-06-10 00:28:09.000000000', 'message': 'Correct InvalidInstanceID.NotFound test.

* exercises/euca.sh: The match filtering InvalidInstanceID.NotFound
is cleaned up to eliminate numerous leaning toothpicks, and now also
actually works. The previous version was incorporating literal
square brackets into the pattern where I think a character list
match may have been intended instead, but was not actually necessary
anyway.

Change-Id: I765a20000e7b6ba6deadce8cad3bbc9559fcdd0d
'}]
commit_message:
Correct InvalidInstanceID.NotFound test.

* exercises/euca.sh: The match filtering InvalidInstanceID.NotFound
is cleaned up to eliminate numerous leaning toothpicks, and now also
actually works. The previous version was incorporating literal
square brackets into the pattern where I think a character list
match may have been intended instead, but was not actually necessary
anyway.

Change-Id: I765a20000e7b6ba6deadce8cad3bbc9559fcdd0d

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: I04fb8c9ebc7c8dbab7fb027865da2ffbfaa3c229

subject: Add -l and --lh switches to swift 'list' command

I also thought of adding it to the help, but the help for list is already pretty verbose.  How about adding an example showing the list command, something like this:

  # list container metadata, which adds additional overhead

But then it's only for "human" sizes, so it's probably ok....

I agree with Darrell's question in patch 8, so 0 for now.

I see you corellated tenses in the commit message, too, thanks.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-08 17:18:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-11 17:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

Rounding still seems funny (see inline).'}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-11 17:31:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

I read your comments about ls -lh converting 1059 to 1.1K agree it is doing something very unusal, I'd claim it's a bug.  Also sounds like it might be doing its own version of rounding.  If it reports 1230 as 1.3K sounds like it's simply rounding up.

I'm simply letting %d/%f do my rounding for me and it seems to do it the way one would expect, rounding up when the fractional part is 5 or more.

As you can see from my code I'm simply doing successive divisions of 1024 as I've always felt things that talk about sizes are typically multiples of powers of 2 wheres counts of things are powers of 10.  When I write a file that's 1024*1024 bytes, ls -lh reports it as 1M.

I'm not sure how one actually resolves this.  Personally my vote would be to keep things as powers of 2 and would even clarify with comments in the code.  It feels like the help text is already longer than one might prefer but how about I change it to read:

-l produces output formatted liks'ls -l' and --lh as multiples of 1024 like 'ls -lh'"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:00:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Are you planning on changing the rounding at all?  I guess "ls -lh" always rounds fractions up.  Are you more interested in more intuitive rounding or getting the same output that "ls -lh" would give, given the same object/file byte counts?

I wasn't suggesting you change away from powers-of-2 (1024-based).  You're trying to emulate output from an existing tool whose "human readable" formatting both defaults to being powers-of-two-based and ambiguously labels the result ("1 MB" is 1,000,000 bytes and "1 MiB" is 1073741824 bytes; see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mebibyte).

Neither you nor I can fix all the /bin/ls binaries out in the world to be how I'd prefer them to be ;).  I think the best you can do is faithfully emulate what "ls -lh" does so that folks familiar with "ls" will feel at home.

Note that "ls" has a --si flag which formats -h output with powers of 10... so adding "--si" as an option to "swift list" might be handy, but I'd +2 this without that change.'}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:11:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

re rounding - my vote it not duplicate all the quirks of ls -lh as I bet most people believe it uses powers of 2 and only treat the output as an approximate value anyway.  I think ls -lh users will be very comfortable with what I've done and suspect you're one of only a handful to even notice its irregularities.  Should make for some good trivia questions ;)

re si - it'd be interesting to see if anyone feels a great need.  I'd be inclined to doubt it.

In other words, I don't plan on changing anything more unless people feel strongly that I should."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-11 19:15:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-11 22:02:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Seems good. I'm okay with not having the rounding exactly match "ls -lh", since it's pretty close here, and I'm not really sure what the heck ls is doing anyway.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 22:02:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 22:03:34.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 22:03:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Verified

'}]

[{'created': '2013-06-04 20:09:49.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint amqp-rpc-fast-reply-queue

As part of the Grizzly code review for the above blueprint (Idb09a714), the Grizzly
code base is "aware" of this feature in terms of receiving RPCs and provided with
an option for enabling it on the RPC send side.  It was decided that in Havana
the option would be removed, RPCs would only be sent using the new functionality
yet awareness of prior functionality be retained for the receiving of RPCs.
This code change implements the Havana piece.

Change-Id: I5f2a8e432cf84a637c1aa813656c1cbc8db6e7eb

commit_message:
Remove the amqp_rpc_single_reply_queue option from Havana

blueprint amqp-rpc-fast-reply-queue

As part of the Grizzly code review for the above blueprint (Idb09a714), the Grizzly
code base is "aware" of this feature in terms of receiving RPCs and provided with
an option for enabling it on the RPC send side. It was decided that in Havana
the option would be removed, RPCs would only be sent using the new functionality
yet awareness of prior functionality be retained for the receiving of RPCs.
This code change implements the Havana piece.

Change-Id: I5f2a8e432cf84a637c1aa813656c1cbc8db6e7eb

The socket_type and bind constructor args are never used.

We always supply a value for the envelope argument.

'}]
commit_message:
zmq: remove someone unused code from ZmqClient

The socket_type and bind constructor args are never used.

We always supply a value for the envelope argument.

Change-Id: Ide2e11170a3415ef347f85bfcce759cdd55d1225

commit_message:
Add can_send_version() to RpcProxy.

Add a helper method to the RpcProxy class.  This is a little nicer to
use for checking to see if a given message is copmatible with the set
version cap.

Change-Id: Ic44d76f4181351dff367f2d1181a3d508a11db78

Installing trunk python-quantumclient fixes bug #1182737 - an
undeclared dependency of quantum on trunk python-quantumclient.

commit_message:
correctly set iface-id in vmware driver

bug 1183452

Commit 70c659059b8fbef811ce79700aecb01c60242ebd updated the vmware
driver to use the new vif model, but was incorrect in how it tried to
grab the iface-id and set it in the vmx file spec.  This patch fixes
that issue and adds a check for this in the existing unit tests.

Change-Id: I756539871d1844a828f9a0a295fc9fa3e59610f7

Well, what I see is a completely empty response, which doesn't seem right to me; I would expect at least some content.  That could indicate that the samples are orphans—i.e., that they're no longer generated by the code you have now—or it could indicate that something should be returning a 204 No Content response instead of a 200.

The other issue is that we have two sets of samples; one is the templates that you have currently, but the other is for use of the documentation, and those live in another directory (/doc/api_samples).  I thought there was a test to ensure that these samples existed, but it's possible that test isn't triggering because the templates are empty.

Does that help?"}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-05-08 17:58:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

'}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-05-17 17:53:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Not sure that people will agree with me, but I'm going to offer my point of view on this again, 2 reasons to my -1:

1 - The code of the new extension is invading the code of the old one, for that same reason we're proposing a new extension framework to API-v3 with hooks (yes I know it help to reuse the code, but that hurts the code IMHO)

2 - This is a classical example that should be calling a show method. I mean a GET against v2/{tenant_id}/limits/{customer_project_id} instead of passing the parameters in the query string.
I know that used_limits already does it using index method, but that kind of make sense since no member is passed (and here we're passing the member in the query string)."}, {'account_id': 7490, 'date': '2013-05-20 05:27:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Hi Mauro,
I agree with you but we implemented it in this way because
a) It avoids code duplication
b) Adding a new route may confuse the end user
c) There is another extension 'ExtendedFloatingIps' (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26113/15/nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/floating_ips.py )  which is doing a similar thing i.e modifying the behavior of an existing API by an extension.

I am just concerned about if we implement similar things(e.g-Extended floating IP extension) in multiple ways that might confuse developers. Please let me about your opinion and then I can start implementing the way you suggested."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-27 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-27 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 7393, 'date': '2013-06-04 17:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Restored'}, {'account_id': 5174, 'date': '2013-06-04 17:21:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: No score

'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-06-06 05:15:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I think this is ok for the V2 API. However, if it's something that could be delayed to the V3 API and then implemented with a proper GET method rather than parameters I think that would be much better.  The V3 API should be released in Havana."}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-06-06 15:57:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Return Customer's Quota Usage through Admin API

DocImpact: This patch adds an extension 'UsedLimitsForAdmin'. If this
extention is enabled then it extends the used limits API behavior, such
that admin can fetch the details of any customer's quota usage by passing
the customer's tenant id in query parameters.The API signature for the
same is 'v2/{tenant_id}/limits?tenant_id={customer_tenant_id}'

Change-Id: I89b8b5083e46b899458407426c89a3865e960faa
Implements: blueprint customer-quota-through-admin-api

commit_message:
Add the boilerplate setup.py file.

The setup.py in each project winds up being boilerplate. We also
need to have slightly more bootstrap code to deal with old versions
of setuptools.

Change-Id: I44fb72a679a17782b7098fcf86d09f322e902268

commit_message:
Add quantum-network-node element for network-node.

The network-node is separate from the quantum-server and is used
to enable communication between vms and external networks.

Fixes bug #1182283
Fixes bug #1182704
Fixes bug #1185977
Fixes bug #1185980

Change-Id: Ie5674e4004ba935e9e4b7060830dcbc69a122ac7

commit_message:
nova.conf configurable gzip compression level

Defaults to -6, which is gzip's default mode, so unlikely to
unexplicitly affect current installs.

Added comments saying Xen only.

Change-Id: Ibf53ba7158bc2f0ad8ab842a75550390b388b918

commit_message:
Stop apt-get installing qemu-img.

This is simply a prerequisite and we should not try to
apt-get install it inline.

Remove this code and exit with an error if qemu-img is
not found.

Change-Id: I52d47a95d24d4bfe801ba664200604bd385dc67f

commit_message:
Rename functions in nova.compute.flavors from instance_type

Second step in removing references to instance_types. Remove all
references to instance_type in nova.compute.flavors.
Also update compute devref to reflect changed name.
Partially implements bp flavor-instance-type-dedup

renamed:  nova/tests/test_instance_types.py -> test_flavors.py

Change-Id: I7413bf832c61d04ab90ec8b1370d3f01372c4172

Update cliff requirement to 1.4

distribute.

Change-Id: Icf68295376f884b1a3ba1891dbb9fbb3dd13c201

subject: Local read affinity for GET/HEAD requests.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 330, 'name': 'John Dickinson', 'email': 'me@not.mn', 'username': 'notmyname'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2622, 'name': 'Samuel Merritt', 'email': 'sam@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'torgomatic'}, {'_account_id': 2696, 'name': 'Darrell Bishop', 'email': 'dbishop@nvidia.com', 'username': 'darrellb'}, {'_account_id': 6198, 'name': 'Peter Portante', 'email': 'peter.a.portante@gmail.com', 'username': 'peter-a-portante'}, {'_account_id': 7848, 'name': 'Caleb Tennis', 'email': 'caleb.tennis@gmail.com', 'username': 'ctennis'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-07 01:48:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Note that there's also another patch working on the same thing, located at https://review.openstack.org/30445.

I wrote this up because I had some ideas about how to do things differently than the other one, and rather than tediously describing the differences in English, it was much easier to write some code and chuck it in Gerrit for all to see."}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-06-07 02:03:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Can somebody explain more about how all these changes are supposed to come together?"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-07 03:38:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The ultimate goal here is to be able to support a single Swift cluster with machines in several far-apart places, e.g. Hong Kong, Dallas, and Paris.

This piece is the read-locally piece. By that, I mean that a proxy should try to service GET requests from the backend server that's closest to it, because that way the response is faster and it causes less traffic on your expensive WAN links.

However, I coded this one up in such a way that you can use it for zones as well as regions. For example, if you've got cluster nodes in 3 distinct DC rooms (each one a zone in the ring), you can set the proxies in zone 1 (room 1) to prefer backend servers in zone 1 and so on. That way, when servicing a GET request, the proxy will go to the backends in its own DC room before the ones in the other rooms.

The nice thing about this one is that not only is it a piece of the wider "global clusters" story, it's a nice standalone piece too. Swift clusters can use this today to make the proxy-to-backend traffic patterns match the actual network patterns a little more closely, at least for reads. Even if everybody decided next week to give up on global clusters, this changeset would still (IMHO) be useful.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-07 03:39:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-06-07 03:40:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-07 04:37:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Local read affinity for GET/HEAD requests.

Now you can configure the proxy server to read from "local" primary
nodes first, where "local" is governed by the newly-introduced
"read_affinity" setting in the proxy config. This is desirable when
the network links between regions/zones are of varying capacities; in
such a case, it's a good idea to prefer fetching data from closer
backends.

The new setting looks like rN[zM]=P, where N is the region number, M
is the optional zone number, and P is the priority. Multiple values
can be specified by separating them with commas. The priority for
nodes that don't match anything is a very large number, so they'll
sort last.

This only affects the ordering of the primary nodes; it doesn't affect
handoffs at all. Further, while the primary nodes are reordered for
all requests, it only matters for GET/HEAD requests since handling the
other verbs ends up making concurrent requests to *all* the primary
nodes, so ordering is irrelevant.

Note that the default proxy config does not have this setting turned
on, so the default configuration's behavior is unaffected.

blueprint multi-region

Change-Id: Iea4cd367ed37fe5ee69b63234541d358d29963a4

subject: Fixed Bug 1187200
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-03 23:59:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

One thing I'm torn on with this is the upgrade procedure. I think most folks usually upgrade the object servers before the proxy servers. If done in this order, any new expiring objects coming in would 5xx after the object servers got upgraded but before the proxy servers got upgraded. I really don't like this.

But, if make it to where the object servers continue to behave the way they did, then the upgrade would go smoothly but if a bug creeps in in the future where the proxy server doesn't send the X-Delete-At-Container header, we wouldn't know right away.

Perhaps I should make it fall back to the old potentially broken method until after the next release and then make the 5xx on a problem change?"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-04 00:20:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-04 00:24:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think I made up my mind now. The seamless upgrade is pretty important, so this will just issue warnings when it is guessing at the container name for now. Later we can change it to raise an exception to bring our attention to any regression.

I'd guess the vast majority of folks are just using the defaults or have a properly configured expiring_objects_container_divisor anyway. Those that don't already have the bug and would just have it with the warning during the upgrade."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-04 01:00:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Fixed Bug 1187200

See Bug 1187200 for a full description of the problem.

Part 1:

X-Delete-At-Container added to X-Delete-At-* info

This fixes the bug by passing the expiring-objects-account's
container name onward to the backend object servers. This is in case
the object servers' expiring_objects_container_divisor happens to be
different than the proxy server's, we want to make sure the host,
partition, and device match up with the container name. Different
container names would be fine, but not with mismatched host,
partition, and device info.

Part 2:

The db_replicator now double checks the disk path's partition against
the partition the ring gives back. If they don't match, it logs the
problem but continues to replicate the database to where it should be
and, on success to all proper nodes, removes the local out of place
database.

Bug 1187200

Change-Id: Id0873a3f2198ce285fe0b0c777738eff38bc2438

commit_message:
Add availability zone checking in the api service

This patch adds availability zone checking for api request period.
If the availability zone the request specified isn't exist in the
Cinder services, the response returned to the user will give an
error immediately.

Fixes bug: 1185714

Change-Id: I842eec7b500c3ff6a7e5d8fc5e397d61617b0eea

commit_message:
Use internal IPs in /etc/hosts.

* internal IP is now extracted from instance
* /etc/hosts is now generated using internal IPs.

Change-Id: I96d8eb8b178c36d9222574e42f1b284dcd45d1c8

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: Ic83dca8c17799335b76311d1d657adcd1dc94f01

Enable hacking H404 test.

H404 - multi line docstring should start with a summary.

'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:42:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Following my comments on irc, I think the only issue left is there's a few items here that are specific to HP. Rather than put them here, I think a better idea is to make the exists events code more flexible.

I'll just copy and paste my IRC comments below:

So here's my issue: this looks like its based a lot on needs that are internal to HP rather than simply general things "Reddwarf", the OS project, needs to do. 

Now, we can't use this event exists loop for our billing code. It's close to, but not an exact match, with what we need.

So, I want to just merge it, so I won't impede you, and since at Rackspace we'll be turning it off anyway.

But, maybe it's better to figure out a way to make it more flexible so HP can easily tweak it to meet the needs of their billing team, but we can keep the basic implementation simple and fast for basic users.

That sounds bad, but this could be as simple as adding a flag to determine which class to use for this exists event loop.

In the public, a class would run that just grabs instance info from the database and sends events based off that.

Then at HP you could extend the class to grab the mgmt instance API call instead and tweak how it's processing.

Here's psuedo code of what this would look like: https://gist.github.com/TimSimpsonR/aef713b904b737ea0715

This has some advantages- note that you can turn off the whole thing by changing the flag to a dummy class that would do nothing. Also if things come up it allows some wiggle room.'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:42:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Sounds good.'}, {'account_id': 694, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:42:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script.'}, {'account_id': 971, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:42:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: No score

Thats a great point Tim.  I like where that idea is headed.'}, {'account_id': 971, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:42:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1925, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:42:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6156, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:42:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 6156, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:42:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Mr Simpson,

I'll go ahead and make this change but I'll create two implementations as you suggestion: one called Basic or some such which just sends info from the database; the other called Detailed or Composite which pulls data from reddwarf and nova.

How about that?

Justin"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 18:42:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Doesn't seem to work

Part of bug # 1187133

commit_message:
Move coverage output dir for Jenkins.

* tox.ini: Set the coverage html output dir to {toxinidir}/cover so that
Jenkins can find it and upload the coverage to the log server.

Change-Id: I231485ce46b1ef91eb219e63552203b86d6d65c2

I don't really understand the fix. Maybe it's good, but I don't see any new test exhibiting the bad current behavior at least. :("}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2013-06-04 19:40:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Julien, i didn't notice this before but the api tests use /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf to build CONF opts and if you have database_connection defined in ceilometer.conf, it will override whatever value [database]connection uses for tests. this shouldn't affect CI tests but if you run tests locally with database_connection defined in ceilometer.conf, tests will fail."}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2013-06-04 20:42:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-04 20:50:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
fix session connection

previous session flushing fix caused conflict between database_connection
and [database]connection values. correct the behaviour in this fix.

also, remove empty return statement at end of record_metering_data function.

Change-Id: I3b2525cec05f5ee2ee8277bfbdca52b9a768974b

commit_message:
xenapi: ensure instance metadata always injected into xenstore

It is possible to use the agent, cloud-init and config drive
together on a single server. In this case we should still
be injecting the instance metadata.

The current code is inconsistent between spawn and migrations.

The correct approach is to always inject the data into xenstore.

fixes bug 1188618

Change-Id: I253b34234544cff353985a5b53ec084ea332535a

commit_message:
Raise a DeprecationWarning when openstack.common.deprecated is imported

We now have a deprecated package in Oslo where deprecated modules /
packages will be moved. In order to make this more clear and warn users,
this patch adds a warning in deprecated's __init__.py module.

Change-Id: Id7097da1b034499fec1b6d44a358223476d9ba83

commit_message:
Integrate oslo's periodic tasks.

Cinder use old style invocation of periodic tasks, which not based on oslo library.
It will be better to use main idea of periodic tasks for all services.

Blueprint: oslo-periodic-tasks

Change-Id: I6ac1ca28abefcc9d0bbfd41873c8f57d40b4a97a

This no longer requires python-openssl to be installed. If it is installed the 'do not compress' functionality will opportunistically be enabled.

Here is an example performance difference (using HP's public cloud) of a 400 Meg download:

$ swift --os-auth-url=https://region-a.geo-1.identity.hpcloudsvc.com:35357/v2.0 --no-ssl-compression download tmp dd.out -o /dev/null
dd.out [headers 0.195s, total 4.026s, 104.183s MB/s]

$ swift --os-auth-url=https://region-a.geo-1.identity.hpcloudsvc.com:35357/v2.0 download tmp dd.out -o /dev/null
dd.out [headers 0.236s, total 23.577s, 17.790s MB/s]"}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-05-17 14:00:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-17 14:00:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me
