Thanks for your comments -- all addressed in latest patch set.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-05-21 19:12:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

In my testing, I'm not seeing much difference in CPU time or transmitted-bytes-to-SSL-terminating-proxy.  Should I use larger files?  Could my pound be configured to not perform TLS compression (I don't see anything in the config file that looks relevant).

My setup is this patch python-swiftclient "swift" tool on my Mac with two all-in-one proxy nodes in two VMs on my mac, with a LVS-load-balanced VIP for the two-node cluster.  LVS just load-balances TCP port 443 and a pound instance on each node terminates SSL and reverse proxies to a local proxy-server process bound to 127.0.0.1:8080.

To track bytes to/from pound, I ran

  run_on_nodes 'sudo tcpdump -i eth1 port 443 -s 0 -w /tmp/pound_traffic.dmp'

On both nodes, and then counted total packet payload bytes with this

  run_on_nodes 'sudo tcpdump -r /tmp/pound_traffic.dmp' | perl -ne '$c += $1 if /, length (\d+)/; END { print "total bytes: $c\n" }'

  $ ls -l
  -rw-r--r--   1 darrell  staff  20971520 May 21 11:33 random1
  ...
  -rw-r--r--   1 darrell  staff  20971520 Apr 30 12:12 zeroes1
  ...

I confirmed that the contents of zeroes{1,2,3,4} were null bytes and random{1,2,3,4} were random bytes.

  3 Runs of uploading 4 20MB /dev/urandom files without no-ssl-compression flag (with compression):
  total bytes (seen by pound on both proxies on port 443): 181154368
        6.29 real         1.11 user         0.20 sys
        5.80 real         1.11 user         0.18 sys
        6.28 real         1.13 user         0.19 sys

  3 Runs of uploading 4 20 MB /dev/urandom files WITH no-ssl-compression flag (without compression):
  total bytes (seen by pound on both proxies on port 443): 195286257  (is indeed larger w/o compression)
        6.50 real         1.11 user         0.19 sys
        7.59 real         1.13 user         0.21 sys
        7.47 real         1.15 user         0.18 sys



  3 Runs of uploading 4 20MB /dev/zero files without no-ssl-compression flag (with compression):
  total bytes (seen by pound on both proxies on port 443): 206851653
  CPU times for 3 runs:
        7.93 real         1.15 user         0.23 sys
        6.87 real         1.14 user         0.21 sys
        6.96 real         1.17 user         0.24 sys

 3 Runs of uploading 4 20 MB /dev/urandom files WITH no-ssl-compression flag (no compression):
 total bytes (seen by pound on both proxies on port 443): 225431362  (larger w/o compression, but not by expected margin?)
 CPU times for 3 runs:
        6.06 real         1.11 user         0.20 sys
        8.30 real         1.19 user         0.25 sys
        6.84 real         1.17 user         0.20 sys'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-05-22 09:31:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Darrell,

So, like you, I think this is probably the server not supporting compression. We can
verify by watching the compression part of the ssl handshake.

The following is what I've been doing to monitor what's been happening w.r.t compression during the client/server ssl handshake. It should tell us if the client no longer advertises compression when the --no-ssl-compression flag is used.

I use 'tshark' to monitor the port in question, so for example:

In one terminal start tshark:

$ tshark -i eth0 -R "ssl" -d tcp.port==443,ssl -V > /tmp/out.with.comp.txt

In another terminal do a swift stat (you don't need a hp cloud account for this -- the swift command will return an error because you didn't authenticate, but that happens after the ssl handshake so its ok for our purposes):

 $ swift --os-auth-token XXX --os-storage-url https://region-b.geo-1.objects.hpcloudsvc.com:443 stat

Now vi or grep the tshark output to see what happened w.r.t compression.

 $ grep -i compr /tmp/out.with.comp.txt
            Compression Methods Length: 2
            Compression Methods (2 methods)
                Compression Method: DEFLATE (1) <<< client is telling server it supports compresssion
                Compression Method: null (0)
                    EC point format: uncompressed (0)
                    EC point format: ansiX962_compressed_prime (1)
                    EC point format: ansiX962_compressed_char2 (2)
            Compression Method: DEFLATE (1) <<< client/server agree to use compression (DEFLATE is the same algorithm used by gzip)

If your client isn't using compression (perhaps due to a system wide setting) you will see that 'Compression Method: Null' was negotiated.

**********

Now repeat, but this time using the --no-ssl-compression flag:

 $ swift --os-auth-token XXX --os-storage-url https://region-b.geo-1.objects.hpcloudsvc.com:443 --no-ssl-compression stat

This time around you should see that the client does not advertise compression:

 $ grep -i compr /tmp/out.no.comp.txt
            Compression Methods Length: 1
            Compression Methods (1 method)
                Compression Method: null (0) <<< client is telling server it only supports the 'null' compression algorithm, ie that it doesn't support compression
                    EC point format: uncompressed (0)
                    EC point format: ansiX962_compressed_prime (1)
                    EC point format: ansiX962_compressed_char2 (2)
            Compression Method: null (0) <<< client/server agree to *not* use compression

Let me know how you get on.'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-05-22 11:05:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Alternatively, if your client always uses compression, even when the --no-ssl-compression flag is used, it probably means its not able to find pyOpenSSL. You can check this by putting a print statement in https_connection.py just before this line:

self.context.set_options(0x20000)

to check whether you are going through that code path or not.'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-05-22 12:53:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Oh, and I could see a difference with a 20 MB object (about 2x), but with a 200MB object the difference was much greater (about 4x).'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-05-29 18:11:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I get a unit test failure. Am I doing something wrong?

_StringException: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/swift/python-swiftclient/tests/test_swiftclient.py", line 185, in test_http_connection
    self.assertTrue(isinstance(conn, c.HTTPSConnectionNoSSLComp))
AssertionError: False is not true'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-05-31 14:57:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi John, just spotted your comment now. I'll need to check but perhaps if you don't have pyopenssl installed you may hit that. I'll take a look..."}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-05-31 15:05:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

John, I tried running with/without python-openssl installed but couldn't reproduce.

Would you be able to print out conn.__class__ so we can tell what it got instantiated as? Thanks."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-05-31 18:12:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I get the same unittest failure as john with my saio"}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-06-03 14:46:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi Chunk,

Thanks for the additional info.

Any chance you'd be able to print out what the value of conn.__class__ is -- to help get a handle on what's going on?

Or alternatively/additionally some more details on your setup? (I'm having trouble reproducing this on devstack.)

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-06-03 15:35:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hey Stuart,

I'm running a fairly standard SAIO following these directions:

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/development_saio.html

Full output is:

$ nosetests test_swiftclient.py:TestHttpHelpers.test_http_connection
F
======================================================================
FAIL: tests.test_swiftclient.TestHttpHelpers.test_http_connection
----------------------------------------------------------------------
_StringException: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/cthier/python-swiftclient/tests/test_swiftclient.py", line 185, in test_http_connection
    self.assertTrue(isinstance(conn, c.HTTPSConnectionNoSSLComp))
AssertionError: False is not true


----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.002s

FAILED (failures=1)

I added a print conn.__class__ in that test right before the failure, and it printed:

httplib.HTTPSConnection'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-06-04 12:27:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Chuck -- thanks, very helpful.

I should be able to push up another patch v. soon.'}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-06-04 16:33:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-04 16:34:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/20029/6/check/gate-python-swiftclient-pep8/308 : SUCCESS in 38s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/20029/6/check/gate-python-swiftclient-docs/258/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 47s
- http://logs.openstack.org/20029/6/check/gate-python-swiftclient-python26/306 : SUCCESS in 1m 00s
- http://logs.openstack.org/20029/6/check/gate-python-swiftclient-python27/306 : SUCCESS in 43s
'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-06-04 19:41:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Everything passes now, and I was able to successfully use it.  Interestingly I couldn't find a performance difference one way or another."}, {'account_id': 455, 'date': '2013-06-04 21:08:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

That's great Chuck -- many thanks.

You may not see a performance difference for a few reasons:

1) ssl compression may already not have been being negotiated between the client/server on your system before this patch (if you're interested the tshark instructions above will tell you if this is the case.)

2) depending on whether you have python-openssl installed the new --no-ssl-compression flag may actually do nothing (try putting in a print statement to verify it hits the all important self.context.set_options(0x20000) line in https_connection.py)

3) vm network -- if you're running in a vm your network bandwidth may be limited, if so this may mask any improvement

(also -- obviously this patch only affects https and not http!)"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-11 16:36:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

So I instrumented:

  --- a/swiftclient/https_connection.py
  +++ b/swiftclient/https_connection.py
  @@ -56,6 +56,7 @@ class HTTPSConnectionNoSSLComp(HTTPSConnection):
           """
           self.context = OpenSSL.SSL.Context(OpenSSL.SSL.SSLv23_METHOD)
           # Disable SSL layer compression.
  +        import sys; print >>sys.stderr, ' **** Setting SSL_OP_NO_COMPRESSION ***** '
           self.context.set_options(0x20000)  # SSL_OP_NO_COMPRESSION
   
       def connect(self):

And then ran like so:

  $ PYTHONPATH=. bin/swift -A https://192.168.22.100/auth/v1.0 -U dev -K admin stat --no-ssl-compression
   **** Setting SSL_OP_NO_COMPRESSION *****
     Account: AUTH_dev
  Containers: 5
     Objects: 42
       Bytes: 943808872
  Accept-Ranges: bytes
  X-Timestamp: 1370871013.20094
  X-Trans-Id: txccf8309916014fc682478-0051b7506b
  Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8

And got this from tshark:

            Compression Methods Length: 2
            Compression Methods (2 methods)
                Compression Method: DEFLATE (1)
                Compression Method: null (0)
                    EC point format: uncompressed (0)
                    EC point format: ansiX962_compressed_prime (1)
                    EC point format: ansiX962_compressed_char2 (2)
            Compression Method: DEFLATE (1)
            Compression Methods Length: 1
            Compression Methods (1 method)
                Compression Method: null (0)
                    EC point format: uncompressed (0)
                    EC point format: ansiX962_compressed_prime (1)
                    EC point format: ansiX962_compressed_char2 (2)
            Compression Method: null (0)

So is that one handshake for Auth which is not using the "no ssl" flag (i.e. is using DEFLATE)?  And then a handshake for data which is correctly not using compression?  If so, would it be easy to make Auth have the same behavior (i.e. a tshark with my test setup would show two connections not using DEFLATE)?

Adding only a +1 as I want to take another look at the patch now that I'm confident it succeeds at what it tries to do :)'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-11 16:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

More good news.  Quite noticeable difference in client CPU consumption uploading very compressible files (all zero bytes).  With compression, much less CPU is used because so many fewer bytes are transferred by the client.

WITH compression (no flag):

  real    0m15.939s
  user    0m2.320s
  sys     0m0.828s
  ...
  real    0m15.449s
  user    0m2.512s
  sys     0m0.756s

WITHOUT compression (with flag).  I still had my instrumentation in and did see one "**** Setting SSL_OP_NO_COMPRESSION *****" per each of the 4 files uploaded.

  real    0m23.939s
  user    0m5.100s
  sys     0m1.648s
  ...
  real    0m25.448s
  user    0m5.072s
  sys     0m1.732s'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-11 16:55:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm; I feel the unit test coverage is a little weak, but I can't think of how to improve it.  The conditional import business makes it tough to test.  A manual functional test worked great, though."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-11 16:55:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Approved

Belatedly noticed I'm the second +2..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 16:55:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: No score

Starting gate jobs.

commit_message:
Add option to disable SSL compression

Allows optionally disabling SSL compression. This can significantly
improve HTTPS upload/download performance in some cases -- in particular
when the object is not compressible and you have very high network
bandwidth.

Implements blueprint ssl-compression.

Change-Id: I1260055f9c2e83cdabfeb51aed11b3899bed4d55

[{'created': '2013-03-25 17:46:58.000000000', 'message': 'Allow keystoneclient to work with older keystone installs

Older keystone installs may return 501 for GET / instead of 300
like today. We should be able to assume that if 501 is returned the
server will support v2.0 only.

Fixes bug 1159911

Change-Id: If264840d8678a490264f1bdb62f1b51c362619e1
'}]
commit_message:
Allow keystoneclient to work with older keystone installs

Older keystone installs may return 501 for GET / instead of 300
like today. We should be able to assume that if 501 is returned the
server will support v2.0 only.

Fixes bug 1159911

Change-Id: If264840d8678a490264f1bdb62f1b51c362619e1

Updates to msgpack have changed the API and removed
the "packs" function, which is being registered by
the version of kombu we're currently using. This breaks
ceilometer and nova, if the wrong version of msgpack
ends up installed.

There is a related fix to pin the version in the
requirements project: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32022/

bug #1134575

Change-Id: I473e87e2542096c99137ebf5aa4514422b210ac9
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Pin the version of msgpack

Updates to msgpack have changed the API and removed
the "packs" function, which is being registered by
the version of kombu we're currently using. This breaks
ceilometer and nova, if the wrong version of msgpack
ends up installed.

There is a related fix to pin the version in the
requirements project: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32022/

bug #1134575

Change-Id: I473e87e2542096c99137ebf5aa4514422b210ac9
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Pin the version of msgpack

Updates to msgpack have changed the API and removed
the "packs" function, which is being registered by
the version of kombu we're currently using. This breaks
ceilometer and nova, if the wrong version of msgpack
ends up installed.

bug #1134575

Change-Id: I337a2ec5919dffd6ff5ee4ec0a517938730776da
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Added policy check for backup operations

This patch adds policy checks for operations in the backup extension
consisting of create, delete, restore, get and get_all.  It also adds
policies into the policy.json files in the tests and etc directories.

Fixes Bug: 1188386

Change-Id: I847640051c5d25cebf06b8658b27d4b82603d796

Corrected two PEP8 errors

Corrected blank line spacing and import order issues highlighted
by the PEP8 check.  Both changes were purely cosmetic and didn't
change functionality.

Related to change in Bug #1188386

Change-Id: I8fbbbd5d1aff8550fd7dae5ebce4868c2467801c

commit_message:
Remove explicit depend on distribute.

Things in the world are moving towards setuptools 0.7, and
there is not a path between distribute and setuptools. Our explicit
dependency on setuptools is causing us to have to write patches to
try to jump through additional hoops to get it to install in the
right contexts.

Fixes bug 1189941

Change-Id: Id7a749c02203100dab52160a551d3548c8a48fd6

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-11 15:50:12.000000000', 'message': 'improve VMware Nova docs, including most new grizzly items.

bug #1106404
bug #1100147

The existing VMware Nova docs were very outdated, incomplete,
and in a few cases, just plan wrong.  They also did not cover the new
VMwareVCDriver and associated updates that arrived in Grizzly.  This
commit removes a lot of stale content (and even graphics) and adds the
basic instructions for both the VMwareVCDriver and the VMwareESXDriver.

I filed an additional bug for some topics (disk details, vnc) that
I did not already cover (bug #1175000)

Cherry-pick from https://review.openstack.org/28241

Change-Id: Id6a4c9022e07f82622aa40eedd0449956f0475e8
'}]
commit_message:
improve VMware Nova docs, including most new grizzly items.

bug #1106404
bug #1100147

The existing VMware Nova docs were very outdated, incomplete,
and in a few cases, just plan wrong.  They also did not cover the new
VMwareVCDriver and associated updates that arrived in Grizzly.  This
commit removes a lot of stale content (and even graphics) and adds the
basic instructions for both the VMwareVCDriver and the VMwareESXDriver.

I filed an additional bug for some topics (disk details, vnc) that
I did not already cover (bug #1175000)

Cherry-pick from https://review.openstack.org/28241

Change-Id: Id6a4c9022e07f82622aa40eedd0449956f0475e8

commit_message:
Protect PoolStats table from negative values.

So the first thing we do is we pick all the images the user is allowed to see  and then the paginate fn will order it and filter it in order to make sure that it behaves like the previous query. If you have ideas for testing let me know.'}, {'account_id': 4463, 'date': '2013-06-10 21:09:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2013-06-11 14:23:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Awesome, this took entirely too long to make sense to me :P

I think I see some potential for some more tweaks around what we have indexed and how we filter, but they may depend more on what use cases are most common for different deployers rather than being improvements without tradeoffs. So if there is a deployer doing weird stuff out there then for now *they* can tweak their indexes. /rant

Thanks for this!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 14:23:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-10 14:57:03.000000000', 'message': 'Sql query optimization for image detail

Current the image detail call uses left outer joins
for its queries, which makes it neglect the index on the
images table. The approach used in this patch, splits up
the querying into two parts and then does the join,
so that we can make use of the index

Change-Id: I65df0be5f156959c1e70ad9cb1a8b7eceebb4d8a
'}]
commit_message:
Sql query optimization for image detail

Current the image detail call uses left outer joins
for its queries, which makes it neglect the index on the
images table. The approach used in this patch, splits up
the querying into two parts and then does the join,
so that we can make use of the index

Change-Id: I65df0be5f156959c1e70ad9cb1a8b7eceebb4d8a

commit_message:
Fix Ceilometer dependencies

Following openstack-requirements, and removing useless dependencies,
that should fixes our CI.

Change-Id: Ide9b98a32f6ec3d1e2ad3f1a7ca2cc642a60acca
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

arguments into oslo.config.

commit_message:
engine : remove GreenletExit workaround

Both heat and oslo now require the version of greenlet containing
the fix (greenlet>=0.3.2) so we no longer need this workaround

Change-Id: I42af8e020f08480dda08f4b4879c2840e741ea59

commit_message:
Use pip instead of easy_install for installation.

If we're running the installation of dependencies for installation
ourselves anyway - just use pip and be done with it. This means
that our requirements will get installed consistently regardless of
whether we're using pip, python setup.py install or a tox environment.

Change-Id: If92557a33a76553ad36bd136fa87780857a894b1

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-04 19:06:21.000000000', 'message': "Add call to vol driver when accepting a transfer

Some back-ends have the notion of tenancy on volumes
and set ownership in the driver.  The update of the DB
alone when doing volume transfers isn't enough, we need
to be able to propogate the update info all the way
down to the driver level.

This patch introduces the volume api/manger/rpc calls
and implements a stub in the base driver that can
be over-ridden for those that need to take some action.

Change-Id: Ica6ae368084c44b32af5d08df14bb3745f3a37ee
"}]
commit_message:
Add call to vol driver when accepting a transfer

Some back-ends have the notion of tenancy on volumes
and set ownership in the driver.  The update of the DB
alone when doing volume transfers isn't enough, we need
to be able to propogate the update info all the way
down to the driver level.

This patch introduces the volume api/manger/rpc calls
and implements a stub in the base driver that can
be over-ridden for those that need to take some action.

Change-Id: Ica6ae368084c44b32af5d08df14bb3745f3a37ee

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-11 12:40:12.000000000', 'message': "Revert dependency on oslo.config 1.2.0

Fixes bug #1185174

This reverts commit b8b2c4e, 2f13345, 362bd7f and 8da2fb7.

We don't yet have the infrastructure in place to use latest oslo.config
in the gate or even get the correct metadata for it in our packaging.

The gory details are here:

  http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/009586.html

Change-Id: Idf89ca418df158e6f94279c9c5fa44f23073a9d7

commit_message:
Revert dependency on oslo.config 1.2.0

Fixes bug #1185174

This reverts commit b8b2c4e, 2f13345, 362bd7f, 8da2fb7 and 956b873.

We don't yet have the infrastructure in place to use latest oslo.config
in the gate or even get the correct metadata for it in our packaging.

The gory details are here:

  http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/009586.html

Change-Id: Idf89ca418df158e6f94279c9c5fa44f23073a9d7

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-07 05:21:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Are you going to set a default for this in Quantum or leave it up to the user?

i.e. is the current default the appropriate default for Quantum? If not, is it the appropriate default for any project?

Do individual projects need to be able to change the default? If so we can add a set_defaults() API for it'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-06-09 09:22:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi,
I think it would be best to have let each project select the values that are most suitable to them. It would also be nice if we could document that there is a way to tackle:
"TimeoutError: QueuePool limit of size 5 overflow 10 reached, connection timed out, timeout 30"
In Quantum I think that it would be best if we reduced the timeout and increased the pool sizes. I am not sure if this is relevant to other projects as I am not really familiar with the database implementations.
Regarding Nova I have seen - https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/nova/+bug/1144108
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-06-11 05:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The current default is None so I guess it won't change the current behavior?
I agree we should have set_defaults able to change the timeout default. To have bw compat, maybe we should have each arg default to None and do "if X is not None:" before we update the default values.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-06-11 09:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 09:34:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-11 11:04:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I'm not delighted we'll have different defaults for these per-project ... it makes tuning an openstack system much more difficult if each project has different requirements. Taking your word that quantum needs to do this, though, since I don't fully understand the issue."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 11:04:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

commit_message:
Enable user to configure pool_timeout

Fixes bug 1160442

In addition to this there are the following changes:
1. The set_default method can configure the QueuePool parameters
2. The max_pool_size is defaulted to the QueuePool default

Change-Id: Ie99f7fc4edba68127c4af508290d8074d7094be9

commit_message:
Handle security group quota exceeded gracefully

Handle the security group quota exceeded more gracefully so a
traceback is not generated in the log files when this error
occurs. This does not change the API as the HTTP status code
returned remains the same.

Fixes bug 1182859

Change-Id: Id3ac513048751759f01b328482b4f02e26ff66ee

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-02 18:07:02.000000000', 'message': 'Normalize path for finding api_samples dir

When nova/tests/integrated and doc/api_samples are installed
in different subtrees and are only combined via symlinks,
running test_api_sample fails due to traversing into the
wrong tree. Use path normalization to avoid this problem.

Fixes: LP Bug #1186775

Change-Id: Ibe9e2442dc9bf3ba7bcb429cbac124dcaeea2cef
'}]
commit_message:
Normalize path for finding api_samples dir

When nova/tests/integrated and doc/api_samples are installed
in different subtrees and are only combined via symlinks,
running test_api_sample fails due to traversing into the
wrong tree. Use path normalization to avoid this problem.

Fixes: LP Bug #1186775

Change-Id: Ibe9e2442dc9bf3ba7bcb429cbac124dcaeea2cef

'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-06-08 15:26:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I have a question or two inline... also I'm kinda mixed on the need for this and will be curious to get feed-back from others.

It is a nice convenience function, until multi-backend however all you needed was "host" and you were pretty much set.  Multi-back-end does introduce a new twist here so it may be useful to have some additional info.  

I'm wondering however, why not just add a backend_name column to the volumes table and be done with it?  Seems like an awful lot of work/code for a minimal amount of info.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-06-08 15:30:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I'm not sure my response above is very clear and makes sense.  In essence this does implement what I was saying, it just seems like there's something a bit convoluted here.  I'll step away for a while and come back, maybe I'm just overwhelemed by all the tests :)"}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-06-09 07:35:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I agree that it's a bit much in terms of code, but I don't know if there's a simpler way.  I modeled (a nice word for copied) this code after cinder/api/contrib/volume_tenant_attribute.py, along with its tests."}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:34:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(4 inline comments)

My only though is I'm a bit worried with the the volume object getting complex and kind of see optional features such as this being metadata if it's not a first class feature."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:47:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Something I thought of and mentioned to Mike, this traditionally is implicit based on the existing host column in the volumes table.  We sort of made this more difficult with multi-backend, but...

Why couldn't we solve it the same way we implemented multi-backend to begin with?  So for example rather than add columns and such, what if we modified the contents of the host column to include the back-end name suffix like we do for the scheduler?

So we'd have something like:  "host = volume-server@back-end-name"

Or even "host = back-end-name@volume-server"

We have to fix our delimiter for ZMQ still anyway so whatever we go with make it consistent. This way we're just extending the volume_host_attributes extension without adding anything unnecessary anywhere else.

Thoughts...?'}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-06-11 06:12:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Good points all around - thanks!  I'll rework this."}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-06-11 10:29:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

Will come back to this later.'}]

commit_message:
Expose volume backend information to admins.

This patch exposes a volume's backend name and class to admins. This is
useful for several scenarios, one of which is an admin interface for
volume migration (i.e., admin says "migrate this volume to that
back-end").

blueprint expose-backend-to-admin
DocImpact

Change-Id: I03ee543227b69e24f70dee74dd1c8d41122b03ee

It allows to (re)build .zip file from module sources.
This .zip file will be used in image builder later.

commit_message:
Change the rootfs label in fedora's /etc/fstab.

The images produced by the diskimage-builder have their filesystem with
a label of "cloudimg-rootfs", so we need to change the default /etc/fstab
on fedora to reflect that.

Change-Id: Id1bb00cb81cb200a114f500e26272624be577da0

[{'created': '2013-06-11 08:41:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add dracut-network element.

This element will install the network modules for dracut and regenerate
the initramfs. The network support would allow us to configure the network

Change-Id: I829405127e77aec80b99ac8dd2032cb0c6d81063
'}]
commit_message:
Add dracut-network element.

This element will install the network modules for dracut and regenerate
the initramfs. The network support would allow us to configure the network
of the image via kernel cmdline instead of injecting files into the image.

Change-Id: I829405127e77aec80b99ac8dd2032cb0c6d81063

commit_message:
Add missing tests for s3_image_* methods

There was no tests in test_db_api for s3_image_*
methods.

Add tests to ensure that all works.

blueprint db-api-tests

Change-Id: I906025f4c5178b26c222fb28d5c3b220e00ae79c

Fixes bug 1185501

commit_message:
MatchMakerStub - make it work & add test

The super() in MatchMakerStub.__init__ was
referencing the wrong class due to copy/paste.

I've also added a test for this class.

Fixes bug 1185501

Change-Id: I298c8c1df4dcb3d3e905ecbb5400d16b3383fdf9

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 23:51:41.000000000', 'message': 'Move wsgi module to deprecated package

As we are planning to deprecate the wsgi module, move it
out of the main openstack/common folder to the new
"deprecated" folder.

Move some of the middleware classes into the middleware
package, since those are still useful and should be
maintained.

There's still work to do to remove the dependency of the
size limit middleware on the Request class in the now
deprecated wsgi module.

Change-Id: I05ff583ef37174835393905a3066390f400ffdcf
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-05-30 00:02:26.000000000', 'message': 'Move wsgi module to deprecated package

out of the main openstack/common folder to the new

commit_message:
Move wsgi module to deprecated package

As we are planning to deprecate the wsgi module, move it
out of the main openstack/common folder to the new
"deprecated" folder.

Move some of the middleware classes into the middleware
package, since those are still useful and should be
maintained.

There's still work to do to remove the dependency of the
size limit middleware on the Request class in the now
deprecated wsgi module.

Refer to the mailing list thread at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-May/009666.html
for additional details.

Change-Id: I05ff583ef37174835393905a3066390f400ffdcf
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Bump django-openstack-auth version

Prerequisite for blueprint multiple-service-endpoints in Horizon.

The packaging on version 1.0.10 was incomplete.

Change-Id: Iec78d2f37597d03545a3e4c59e96ac0b7df21d87

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-07 22:37:38.000000000', 'message': "Commit transaction in migration

Some databases (e.g., DB2) would deadlock on migration 16 because a
lock was held on the domain table for an uncommitted alter and then
SQLAlchemy queried the domain table info in a separate transaction.

The fix is to commit the ALTER statements to release the lock so
that the domain table schema query will not block.

I've run this with sqlite, mysql, and postgresql and they all worked.

Part of fix for bug 1188785

Change-Id: Ic540a6cb09a0c525df7aaea55b64af96f0dd87c7
"}]
commit_message:
Commit transaction in migration

Some databases (e.g., DB2) would deadlock on migration 16 because a
lock was held on the domain table for an uncommitted alter and then
SQLAlchemy queried the domain table info in a separate transaction.

The fix is to commit the ALTER statements to release the lock so
that the domain table schema query will not block.

I've run this with sqlite, mysql, and postgresql and they all worked.

Part of fix for bug 1188785

Change-Id: Ic540a6cb09a0c525df7aaea55b64af96f0dd87c7

commit_message:
add ca_key to sample configuration

this gives end-users a clue that they also have to set
ca_key for using ssl certificates other than the default
place /etc/ssl.

Change-Id: I41c4118d02723730c0ba183add866a0e0fa67e7b
Fixes: Bug #1188956

commit_message:
Enable existing loggers while setting up logging

Ensure nova logs are not insufficient by enabling existing loggers,
if any while setting up logging in Nova.

Fixes bug #1186222

Change-Id: I592f1bac21c65e3399cc92fa38f448215b56ac57

commit_message:
Implenting actions for tracking api actions and events.

* Created models / tests.
* Created decorator / tests.
* Updated the context to hold action_uuid since it
  gets sent across the amqp wire and local.store does
  not
* Updated base models for a uuid strategy in the event
  that one is not needed or a different one is needed from
  the standard uuid generation.
* Taskmanager instance methods decorated
* Fixing tox tests

partially implements blueprint reddwarf/reddwarf-actions

Change-Id: I263a1a11420a0856dd0d919477200f68a7f8f294

[{'created': '2013-05-30 04:56:29.000000000', 'message': 'Changed the value from "none" to "None"

While calling nova.flavors.list() in novaclient with
is_public=None, nova side was throwing an error:
"Invalid is_public filter None". This error was
comming because of invalid comparision of _is_public
to "none" instead of "None". So modified variable

Fixes: bug #1184966
Change-Id: Ia553361f746563ed6c1fe9e3e4d0fe1e3cc9d80c
'}, {'created': '2013-06-03 05:21:06.000000000', 'message': 'Changed the value from "none" to "None"

While calling nova.flavors.list() in novaclient with
is_public=None, nova side was throwing an error:
"Invalid is_public filter None". This error was
comming because of invalid comparision of _is_public
to "none" instead of "None". So now lowercased the
variable _is_public and comparing it with "none".
Added a new testcase to test the "None" as well.

Fixes: bug #1184966
Change-Id: Ia553361f746563ed6c1fe9e3e4d0fe1e3cc9d80c
'}]
commit_message:
Changed the value from "none" to "None"

While calling nova.flavors.list() in novaclient with
is_public=None, nova side was throwing an error:
"Invalid is_public filter None". This error was
comming because of invalid comparision of _is_public
to "none" instead of "None". So now lowercased the
variable _is_public and comparing it with "none".
Added a new testcase to test the "None" as well.

Fixes: bug #1184966
Change-Id: Ia553361f746563ed6c1fe9e3e4d0fe1e3cc9d80c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-07 14:53:16.000000000', 'message': 'Remove GET /roles/{role_id}/users (bug 1183433)

This resources was unimplemented in grizzly, and the semantics of the
call need to be carefully considered (and perhaps redesigned) prior to
implementation.

Change-Id: I5c26a5d248c774143dae0e648090e209bc94899e
'}]
commit_message:
Remove GET /roles/{role_id}/users (bug 1183433)

This resources was unimplemented in grizzly, and the semantics of the
call need to be carefully considered (and perhaps redesigned) prior to
implementation.

Change-Id: I5c26a5d248c774143dae0e648090e209bc94899e

[{'created': '2013-06-07 01:40:58.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup nova exception message conversion

Fix cases where setting the explanation for an HTTP exception
based on a Nova exception was done using str(ANovaException)
rather than using ANovaException.format_message()

Change-Id: Ia8a361fcb088dcf3c17be0d296aee494b9f063d7
'}, {'created': '2013-06-08 01:31:22.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup nova exception message conversion

Fix cases where setting the explanation for an HTTP exception
based on a Nova exception was done using str(ANovaException)
rather than using ANovaException.format_message()

Change-Id: Ia8a361fcb088dcf3c17be0d296aee494b9f063d7
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup nova exception message conversion

Fix cases where setting the explanation for an HTTP exception
based on a Nova exception was done using str(ANovaException)
rather than using ANovaException.format_message()

Change-Id: Ia8a361fcb088dcf3c17be0d296aee494b9f063d7

commit_message:
NFS drivers don't honor vm size with volume from an image

The bug has been encountered with the NFS generic driver
(cinder.volume.nfs.NfsDriver) and the NetApp NFS driver
(cinder.volume.drivers.netapp.nfs.NetAppDirectCmodeNfsDriver). I believe
that drivers based on distributed filesystem such as GlusterFS, nexenta
and scality are also impacted however I didn't test it those backends.
However since most of them already inherit from the RemoteFsDriver
class, this should be fine.

Change-Id: I14575da69a2c99c7cbcece27b40a171153371ee3
Fixes: bug #1183459

commit_message:
Create an image BDM for every instance

This patch makes every boot create a block device mapping if the
instance was started with an image.

These block devices are not used anywhere at the moment but will be used
in the future as part of a more flexible block device API.

This patch also makes sure they are deleted once the instance is deleted
as well.

Change-Id: Ia89d531be71c460f1f82fcfce34b270639a23061
blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-15 15:41:15.000000000', 'message': "DB migration to the new BDM data format

This patch migrates the DB to the new data format. In addition it also
utilizes routines introduced in the change: in a way that will allow us
to transition into using the new data in Nova logic one step at a time.

This is accomplished in a following manner in the DB/conductor layer,
which is supposed to allow for subsequent changes to be as granular as
possible:

* Read operations - data is always read as is found in the DB - meaning
in the new format, and transformed after every call. This will allow us
to make granular changes in the API/Compute layers.

* Data is converted inside the DB methods that do writes, and an
additional 'legacy' flag is added (set to True by default). It is up to
the calling method to make sure it supplies the DB layer with the format
it is intending to write, to avoid guessing.

This patch also fixes some of the block device fixtures in tests, when it was
required to be aware of the new data structure (mostly when mocking DB
methods that return the new data format).

This patch is not supposed to provide any new functionality to Nova.

blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Change-Id: If30afdb59d4c4268b97d3d10270df2cc729a0c4c

block_device_mapping_get_all_by_instance conductor method and bumps the

methods that return the new data format).

commit_message:
DB migration to the new BDM data format

This patch migrates the DB to the new data format. In addition it also
utilizes routines introduced in the change
I9370333059b8c9aaf92010470b8475a913d329b2 in a way that will allow us
to transition into using the new data in Nova logic one step at a time.

This is accomplished in a following manner in the DB/conductor layer,
which is supposed to allow for subsequent changes to be as granular as
possible:

* Read operations - data is always read as is found in the DB - meaning
in the new format, and transformed after every call. This will allow us
to make granular changes in the API/Compute layers.

* Data is converted inside the DB methods that do writes, and an
additional 'legacy' flag is added (set to True by default). It is up to
the calling method to make sure it supplies the DB layer with the format
it is intending to write, to avoid guessing.

An exception to the above is when using conductor due to rpcapi
versioning, so this patch adds a 'legacy' flag to the
block_device_mapping_get_all_by_instance conductor method and bumps the
version of the API.

This patch also fixes some of the block device fixtures in tests, when it was
required to be aware of the new data structure (mostly when mocking DB
methods that return the new data format).

This patch is not supposed to provide any new functionality to Nova.

blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Change-Id: If30afdb59d4c4268b97d3d10270df2cc729a0c4c

Looks good to me, but I wish I understood more about why the original change was made. See https://github.com/openstack/swift/commit/9efa9be167b972a234ecccd9ba37bdd8a949381e

It appears the original was authored by David Haddas.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2013-05-30 19:48:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The review history in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/14676/ (the original patch that changed this) may offer some insight. Of course, it may have been an oversight too.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-05-30 20:24:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I can see that David wanted to get rid of the duplicated loadapp first, but Greg suggested that he'd restored it back. At that point the vestigual return into an unusued app got stuck.

I think my fix only addresses the regression and should not damage running of proxy under Apache. But I'll try to add David to reviewer's list and see what he says."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-05-30 21:11:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm not sure what advantage having the loadapp in init_request_processor gives.  It should be done after dropping privledges so that it runs the same way as the actual server will, and thus catch errors if there are any."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-30 23:07:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

LGTM, but I'm holding off on the approval for a little while to give David Hadas (or another Apache user) a chance to say if this change breaks Swift+Apache or not."}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-05-31 05:57:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Will be looking at this soon'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-05-31 06:29:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(6 inline comments)

This breaks the Apache interface"}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-05-31 13:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

See inline.'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-05-31 15:16:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

So the main issue is both run_wsgi and apache integration both using init_request_processor but needing different behavior.

The simplest fix would be to add a load_app arg to init_request_processor, and skip loading if it is False.  I'm fine with the default being True since that would require no changes to the apache docs.

A better long term refactor, would be to create a separate function to be used by other wsgi servers call it something like load_wsgi that run_wsgi doesn't depend on."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-31 17:02:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

"}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-05 11:02:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Guys I am not sure what is the confusion here. 

Pete created a patch that changes run_wsgi which I do not object. While doing that he decided to also change init_request_processor(). 

This second change is not needed for what Pete is trying to achieve but breaks the Apache code. 

Pete, 
why not send a modified patch with the change you need to run_wsgi and without changing the signature of init_request_processor().

This would be a +1 for me.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-06-05 14:13:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks, David. I understood the problem, just need to get around to it.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2013-06-05 22:28:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-05 23:16:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 16:23:40.000000000', 'message': 'Restore loadapp checking

This problem surfaced when our QA started installing Grizzly and
found a clear regression from Folsom. If something is wrong with
permissions (it may be SElinux, or any other problem), the servers
in 1.8.0 enter a loop spamming logs with huge tracebacks at a rate
of a one to two each second, depending how many workers are there.
In 1.7.4, the server exited with an error message.

The offending commit is 9efa9be167b972a234ecccd9ba37bdd8a949381e,
"Separate wsgi init from web-front-end activation". It relocates
the probing invocation of loadapp() in front of drop_privileges().
But in such case, it runs as root and thus may succeed while the
rest of the server fails.

It seems easiest just restore the code to what it was in Folsom,
with adjustments to Clay's conf.d changes. The app returned from
initi_request_processor() does not seem to be used for anything.

Change-Id: I166332eb9375229aefed6b9c3ef1a992a3e4efd0
'}, {'created': '2013-06-05 22:28:34.000000000', 'message': 'Restore loadapp checking

"Separate wsgi init from web-front-end activation". It relocates
the probing invocation of loadapp() in front of drop_privileges().
But in such case, it runs as root and thus may succeed while the
rest of the server fails.

The fix is to return loadapp to the place it was in Folsom. Since
the init_request_processor() is used when running under Apache,
preserve that API too.

Change-Id: I166332eb9375229aefed6b9c3ef1a992a3e4efd0

'}]
commit_message:
Restore loadapp checking

This problem surfaced when Red Hat QA started installing Grizzly
and hit a regression from Folsom. If something is wrong with
permissions (it may be SElinux, or any other problem), the servers
in 1.8.0 enter a loop, spamming logs with huge tracebacks at a rate
of a one to two each second, depending how many workers are there.
In 1.7.4, the server exited with an error message.

The offending commit is 9efa9be167b972a234ecccd9ba37bdd8a949381e,
"Separate wsgi init from web-front-end activation". It relocates
the probing invocation of loadapp() in front of drop_privileges().
But in such case, it runs as root and thus may succeed while the
rest of the server fails.

The fix is to return loadapp to the place it was in Folsom. Since
the init_request_processor() is used when running under Apache,
preserve that API too.

Change-Id: I166332eb9375229aefed6b9c3ef1a992a3e4efd0

just include it in our code.

commit_message:
Add a first function

This is inspired by: https://github.com/hynek/first
and is API compatible with it.

After some resistance to including it in requirements, the
fact it is so small and as suggested by the Author - lets
just include it in our code.

Change-Id: Id5c1f3ba87601f49f1be7671c55c2408c664e3bb

commit_message:
Return empty string when Fn::Select target is None.

This can happen when a resource is not in the required state
to resolve its FnGetAtt.

Change-Id: I4d104b3577fbd94b920ff172c00d60914d7acd45

I'm not that fond of Fn::Variables as a name, so I'm open to suggestions.

Alternatives that I rejected at the time for seeming worse:

- Fn::Template
- Fn::Replace
- Fn::Vars
- Fn::Variable"}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-05 02:01:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-06-05 11:38:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Hmmm, it's unfortunate that this format conflicts with the format for shell scripts, so that all of the input has to be correctly escaped to use this. I think I would prefer a format like:

  "%var1% is %var2%"

though that has its own issues. At a minimum, though, I think we should use safe_substitute() instead of substitute().

BTW my entry in the naming sweepstake is Fn::Substitute. What was wrong with Fn::Replace?'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-05 22:51:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Although in our glorious imperative future there will be no shell scripts ;)

But seriously, there will be less need to assign bash variables in the first place (and thus escape $) since the values can just be substituted directly wherever needed.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-06 00:38:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Actually I'm warming up to the idea of a Fn::Replace  that does a straight str.replace on each key."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-06-06 02:08:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-06 02:11:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

[{'created': '2013-06-05 01:53:39.000000000', 'message': 'Add Fn::Variables template function.

This is implemented with python template strings
http://docs.python.org/2/library/string.html#template-strings

For yaml templates, this should be used as a better alternative to
Fn::Join: ['', [...]]

For json templates, the following common pattern:
"Fn::Join": ["", ["line 1\n", ... "line 2\n"]]
could now become more maintainable as:
"Fn::Variables": [{...}, "Fn::Join": ["\n", ["line 1", ... "line 2"]]]

Implements blueprint template-string-function
Implements blueprint bash-environment-function

commit_message:
Add Fn::Replace template function.

This is implemented with python str.replace

For yaml templates, this should be used as a better alternative to
Fn::Join: ['', [...]]

For json templates, the following common pattern:
"Fn::Join": ["", ["line 1\n", ... "line 2\n"]]
could now become more maintainable as:
"Fn::Replace": [{...}, "Fn::Join": ["\n", ["line 1", ... "line 2"]]]

Implements blueprint template-string-function
Implements blueprint bash-environment-function

Change-Id: Ie4817b1d98dd6d6390e086da9b582d33415a0d9f

non-deprecated except x as y: construct which
works with any Python version >= 2.6

@Dan - I'm with you, but capturing the variance we need isn't harmful. As for disable vs not, we're aiming at production. I can ask around to see if most prod clouds disable ratelimiting, but I suspect the answer is 'no'.

So, lets land this, and as soon as someone puts up a delta based system, this becomes a delta rather than an edited file."}, {'account_id': 6449, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:41:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:41:14.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-10 23:41:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Increase nova API ratelimit levels.

Increase the API rate limiting to something more appropriate for
overcloud testing/usage.

commit_message:
Refactors scheduler.chance.select_hosts to raise NoValidHost

This change is intended to refactor the method to be consistent
with the filter_scheduler.select_hosts implementation.

This method is called by scheduler.manager and it is exposed
through the scheduler.rpcapi. Thus, both implementations should
behave the same.

This change is needed by others that will move cold migration
to conductor.

Partially implements bp cold-migrations-to-conductor

Change-Id: I0f6fef43324cf829cdb26633874c537572423f77

commit_message:
Fix db.models.Service description

DB models definition should be up-to-date with DB schema obtained after applying of
migrations. Currently, there are no tests enforcing this and it's really hard to
analyze what indexes should be added, and what indexes we have at the moment.

So the first step is it to fix all models, and add missing descriptions about
Indexes and UniqueConstraints in __table_args__ and use explicit 'nullable'
parameter in columns description.

Add missing 'nullable' parameters to all Columns

Add empty __table_args__ parameter to Table

There is no indexes and no unique constraints in this table at this moment.

blueprint db-sync-models-with-migrations

Change-Id: I9b31e8976f514e370d6b46076b469fe5e5c8e0f1

What's to guarantee that all devices will be listed at detach time? Related, what's the benefit of getting the list at startup if it can be partial?"}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-05-28 16:16:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The code LGTM, but I'd also like to hear the answers to Padraig's questions about the design."}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2013-05-29 20:02:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

There is no guarantee all the devices will be listed at any time.   The best we can do is get the list at detach time, which most likely will be better than at attach time.  The reason I left the list in at attach time, was to try and be backward compatible with Grizzly.  Grizzly puts the list in at attach time and detach looks for that list first.  The alternative is to simply put the multipath_id entry in the metadata and fetch the list only at detach time.  The only downside is if a user upgrades from Grizzly to Havana, the multipath_id won't be there and the detach won't work."}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-05-30 14:43:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Fix dangling LUN issue under load with multipath

This fixes an issue where not all of the LUNs are seen
by the kernel at attach time, but later become available.
We now rescan the list of devices seen by multipath at
detach time.

Also added another unit test case.

Fixes Bug: #1175366

Change-Id: Id5b313b17454ec32672373b7b564b9450466b7a2

commit_message:
Remove GET /users/{user_id}/roles (bug 1183430)

This resources was unimplemented in grizzly, and the semantics of the
call need to be carefully considered (and perhaps redesigned) prior to
implementation.

Change-Id: I8a5bb0330ff1d5273aed6924cedacac33e689588

it should look in the service catalog for the glance registry endpoint. This
stops authentication by glance registry client from needlessly looking for an

commit_message:
Pass configure_via_auth down to auth plugin

Pass down the configure_via_auth value to the auth plugin to say whether or not
it should look in the service catalog for the glance registry endpoint. This
stops authentication by glance registry client from needlessly looking for an
"image" service endpoint when the user may not have it in their service catalog.

Fixes bug 1187888

Change-Id: I1c4a726ff0d6a345a27446500135f4f27cea5e39

commit_message:
Update Quantum config to use DBQuotaDriver.

Use a quota driver that we can administer post-deploy. The default
(ConfQuota) cannot be altered by quantumclient.

commit_message:
Allow remote implementations to be overridden.

* Adds new config settings for default remote clients
* Removes monkey patching during test runs
* Add fake implementations to test config.

Implements: blueprint: custom-remotes

commit_message:
Install PyPi dependencies alongside apt ones for dib elements

The python-novaclient package in apt is really old (2012.1-0ubuntu1)
and has a pinned dependency on prettytable 0.5. All of the newer
clients have a dependency on prettytable 0.6 - 0.8. This is causing
issues on the guest agent.

This updates the dib elements so that dependencies from PyPi are
installed alongside apt dependencies.

Fixes bug 1189641

Change-Id: I5233aad2045cbec8610569c40e50bf26defe2dfa

subject: Use realpath to find path to $0, assists in locating relative resources
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:58:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30961/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-pep8/518 : SUCCESS in 8s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30961/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-python26/511 : SUCCESS in 31s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30961/1/check/gate-diskimage-builder-python27/512 : SUCCESS in 25s
'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:58:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Ack. You might want to click 'abandoned' to make it stop showing in the review queue."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:58:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

robertc@lifelesshp:/tmp$ vim f.sh
robertc@lifelesshp:/tmp$ chmod u+x f.sh 
robertc@lifelesshp:/tmp$ cd ~
robertc@lifelesshp:~$ PATH=/tmp:$PATH
robertc@lifelesshp:~$ echo $PATH
/tmp:....
robertc@lifelesshp:~$ f.sh 
/tmp/f.sh
robertc@lifelesshp:~$ cat /tmp/f.sh 
#!/bin/bash
echo $0'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:58:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

I think this needs a little more discussion; what are we fixing?"}, {'account_id': 7555, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:58:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I believe this is self-inflicted by using "sh -x disk-image-create" an better alternative is "disk-image-create -x"'}, {'account_id': 7555, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:58:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Summary: _LIB and SCRIPT_HOME should be relative to the script, not to $PWD

Installation instructions say to add the project's bin/ to PATH. This allows for invoking disk-image-create w/o a path, e.g. w/o bin/disk-image-create or /opt/blah/blah/bin/disk-image-create.

disk-image-create (and friends) use dirname/basename of $0 to locate resources, e.g. anything relative to _LIB.

However, unless invoked with a path, a script's $0 can be only the name of the script. As a result, _LIB ends up being relative to $PWD (specifically $PWD/../lib) instead of being relative to the script's location. This results in silent failures to source things such as die, img-defaults, common-functions, img-functions. Likewise for finding and invoking element-info.

Using realpath of $0 ensures that _LIB and SCRIPT_HOME are relative to the script instead of $PWD>"}, {'account_id': 7555, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:58:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Skip git-checkout related tests when .git is missing

When running tests from the released tarballs, the
AUTHORs related checks are failing due to missing .git
directory and the fallout caused by it.

Change-Id: Ic960863621f1b239ced299f892466537431d44d5

The packages can not be removed from files/apts/*.  If your goal is to not install them then add # NOPRIME to the end of the lines.  This will delay the installation until they are explicitly called.

[{'created': '2013-05-23 10:15:02.000000000', 'message': "Enhance group handling in extract_opts

When there's 2 options with the same name, the script gets confused and
doesn't know in which group it goes. This fixes it, and fixes also the
template generation which is broken for various reasons:

- gettext.install was missing
- nova-rootwrap when imported calls exit() because it doesn't find a valid
  configuration file, so let's exclude it entirely anyway
- eventlet/greendns needs to be ignored for this

Change-Id: Iaa4e9a806e79032ce1675b46a6b7a7628c3eff89
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Enhance group handling in extract_opts

When there's 2 options with the same name, the script gets confused and
doesn't know in which group it goes. This fixes it, and fixes also the
template generation which is broken for various reasons:

- gettext.install was missing
- nova-rootwrap when imported calls exit() because it doesn't find a valid
  configuration file, so let's exclude it entirely anyway
- eventlet/greendns needs to be ignored for this

Change-Id: Iaa4e9a806e79032ce1675b46a6b7a7628c3eff89
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Floodlight doesn't have L3 functionality

Document that, when using BigSwitch/Floodlight plugin with Floodlight,
you need to use quantum-l3-agent since Floodlight doesn't
provide L3 functionality.

Change-Id: Iaec2d58615530c21fdc0c6532a1f6786ff4f3a5a

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-10 20:06:48.000000000', 'message': ' Handle UnexpectedTaskState and InstanceNotFound exceptions

    UnexpectedTaskState and InstanceNotFound are thrown when a delete of the
    instance happens before the ongoing action is completed.
    These are to be handled gracefully.
    These exceptions have to be logged and not reraised, as they are false
    alarms.

    Fixes: bug #1186447

    Change-Id: I0647935c4452d4294f49a4c0d08e480584ebec7c

Change-Id: I2bd5c12bb50527d4ded468e0b6b18810f6105b33
'}]
commit_message:
Handle UnexpectedTaskState and InstanceNotFound exceptions

    UnexpectedTaskState and InstanceNotFound are thrown when a delete of the
    instance happens before the ongoing action is completed.
    These are to be handled gracefully.
    These exceptions have to be logged and not reraised, as they are false
    alarms.

    Fixes: bug #1186447

    Change-Id: I0647935c4452d4294f49a4c0d08e480584ebec7c

Change-Id: I2bd5c12bb50527d4ded468e0b6b18810f6105b33

commit_message:
Use strainer to isolate and test individual cookbooks

Included:
- Add strainer gem
- Update test-related gems
- Add Strainer file
- Remove run_tests.bash
- Update .gitignore
- Update README file
- Add tailor (ruby style check)

Partial fix for bug 1188345

Change-Id: Iae92a999cdfe230151795fcab5b597faa958274a

commit_message:
Wrap transport's app with keystoneclient's middleware

Instead of using paste and depending on the middleware chain, use
ceilomenter's strategy and wrap transport's app using the auth_token
middleware.

NOTE: Tests with successful auth are missing

Implements blueprint remove-paste
Change-Id: I61e7d1fae6b80114e22c0a43b4e391e2d5443123

commit_message:
Fix Cisco nexus plugin failure for first VLAN on phy interface

Fixes bug 1174852

This fix changes the command being sent to the Nexus switch for
enabling a VLAN on an interface such that the 'add' keyword is
included only when there are prior VLANs already enabled on that
interface.

(cherry picked from commit - 92ef293d02a7499850bc3becda413d6be22ae06c)

Change-Id: I53c1efcac92fa53d0a7ab5db4876539bdf2ed505

commit_message:
Fix Cisco nexus plugin failure for first VLAN on phy interface

Fixes bug 1174852

This fix changes the command being sent to the Nexus switch for
enabling a VLAN on an interface such that the 'add' keyword is
included only when there are prior VLANs already enabled on that
interface.

Change-Id: I466bcb839912b164b84be0e6721d87206c0e53eb

commit_message:
Query scheduler for host to build instance on

The first schedule call for building an instance will be a query to the
scheduler for a suitable host, and then conductor will send a
run_instance message to the compute.  A later patch will pull the
scheduling logic out of the compute manager.

Part of bp query-scheduler

Change-Id: I5d3ca2b7bec6e26eeb136f0c7a58150325c9a32d

commit_message:
Prepare repository for a Puppet Forge release

  Commit updates README.md with a more consistent template for documentation,
  removes travis.yml since we're on stackfoge now, updates the Modulefile
  for the new release, deletes TODO list, CHANGELOGs deleted in favor of
  summarized release notes in README.md, which will show up on Forge,
  and moves examples to tests to adhere with Puppet Labs Style
  Guide(http://docs.puppetlabs.com/guides/style_guide.html#tests)

Change-Id: Iffa30f6f35b996305f635317fc0770f908e9057e

commit_message:
Converts 'image' to json primitive on compute.rpcapi.prep_resize

The 'image' should be converted to primitive since it contains
complex structures. Today it works because it relies on
scheduler.rpcapi.prep_resize which does the conversion.

This is part of other changes that will move resize/cold migration
to conductor. scheduler.rpcapi.prep_resize will be moved and then
compute.rpcapi.prep_resize has to properly convert parameters.

Partially implements bp cold-migrations-to-conductor

Change-Id: Id89896bfb379ab9eb8bf13c3513b9290d88408fd

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-10 20:05:54.000000000', 'message': ' Handle UnexpectedTaskState and InstanceNotFound exceptions

    UnexpectedTaskState and InstanceNotFound are thrown when a delete of the
    instance happens before the ongoing action is completed.
    These are to be handled gracefully.
    These exceptions have to be logged and not reraised, as they are false
    alarms.

    Fixes: bug #1186447

    Change-Id: I0647935c4452d4294f49a4c0d08e480584ebec7c

Change-Id: I5eb489fb6153230fd92a2a445cee0165631f440a
'}]
commit_message:
Handle UnexpectedTaskState and InstanceNotFound exceptions

    UnexpectedTaskState and InstanceNotFound are thrown when a delete of the
    instance happens before the ongoing action is completed.
    These are to be handled gracefully.
    These exceptions have to be logged and not reraised, as they are false
    alarms.

    Fixes: bug #1186447

    Change-Id: I0647935c4452d4294f49a4c0d08e480584ebec7c

Change-Id: I5eb489fb6153230fd92a2a445cee0165631f440a

commit_message:
Update Chef dependency to Chef 11

Also add dependency on json <= 1.7.7, required by Chef 11.

Resolves problem: Bundler could not find compatible versions for gem
"json" (required for chef and berkshelf).

Partial fix for bug #1183540

Change-Id: I97ab10e492fa4799fb4e7ce81ff500621d0aa2fb

commit_message:
Fix dependency problem in class swift

Class swift requires class['ssh::server::install'], otherwise it will
complain and fail to compile the catalog.

Change-Id: Ieeef735cc3e78bb6a6b514c711e5b87a861ee31b

commit_message:
BDM class and transformation functions

This patch adds the utility functions that will help us switch
between versions of block device mapping data.

In order to accomplish this, and to have a more structured approach to
dealing with block device mapping data in the future, this patch
introduces a BlockDeviceDict class which is a thin wrapper around a
standard dict that makes it easier to reason about which fields are
present in the dictionary, and introduces said conversion routines.

blueprint: improve-block-device-handling

Change-Id: I9370333059b8c9aaf92010470b8475a913d329b2

[{'created': '2013-06-10 19:30:53.000000000', 'message': "Replace deprecated :rubygems source

Fix deprecation warnings thrown by bundler:

  The source :rubygems is deprecated because HTTP requests are insecure.
  Please change your source to 'https://rubygems.org' if possible,
  or 'http://rubygems.org' if not.

Fixes: bug #1175767
Change-Id: I1292dfca9b910c487a9bfd41366745e8b1684b64
"}]
commit_message:
Replace deprecated :rubygems source

Fix deprecation warnings thrown by bundler:

  The source :rubygems is deprecated because HTTP requests are insecure.
  Please change your source to 'https://rubygems.org' if possible,
  or 'http://rubygems.org' if not.

Fixes: bug #1175767
Change-Id: I1292dfca9b910c487a9bfd41366745e8b1684b64

commit_message:
Replace gunicorn with wsgiref

The patch replaces gunicorn with wsgiref since it doesn't make sense to
have gunicorn as dependency. Lets let deployers choose whatever the
prefer to use as container.

The patch also removes lib/* since marconi_paste is not needed anymore,
the wsgi app can now be accessed through:

    `marconi.transport.wsgi.app:app`

Backward incompatible change: bind refers now to the host and a new
config variable was introduced to specify the port it should bind to.

Fixes bug: #1187280
Implements blueprint: transport-wsgi

Change-Id: I9f7767ace5c6553e75e2f4587032d7d64b9537c4

commit_message:
Add H203: Check for Python 3.x compatible except

Python 3.x deprecated 'except x,y:'
Enforce 'except x as y:' instead.

Change-Id: I0bd89fa05d88de34ca62ce59f427468ede226126

[{'created': '2013-05-12 08:00:20.000000000', 'message': 'Add quantum configuration reference tables

This is the first attempt at automatically generated configuration
tables being added to documentation.
blueprint autogenerate-config-tables

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Blueprint-autogenerate-config-tables

Work is being conducted out-of-repo at :

https://github.com/fifieldt/autogenerate-config-docs

quantum has existing tables, which are out of date for Grizzly.
These new tables will need to be linked in, but first submitting these for
review without linking them in to a book yet, because feedback is needed.

Please provide feedback on:
* completeness (is every option and its description present)
* groupings (is every option in the right group)
* potential integrations (can you see where one or more of these
tables could be combined under a nice descriptive paragraph)
* relationships to config files (are these useful as is, or how to
best integrate them with examples)
* anything else you can think of

Change-Id: I396b04edb668c0a5a403ccfd3f6db90c78d29ce6
'}]
commit_message:
Add quantum configuration reference tables

This is the first attempt at automatically generated configuration
tables being added to documentation.
blueprint autogenerate-config-tables

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Blueprint-autogenerate-config-tables

Work is being conducted out-of-repo at :

https://github.com/fifieldt/autogenerate-config-docs

quantum has existing tables, which are out of date for Grizzly.
These new tables will need to be linked in, but first submitting these for
review without linking them in to a book yet, because feedback is needed.

Please provide feedback on:
* completeness (is every option and its description present)
* groupings (is every option in the right group)
* potential integrations (can you see where one or more of these
tables could be combined under a nice descriptive paragraph)
* relationships to config files (are these useful as is, or how to
best integrate them with examples)
* anything else you can think of

Change-Id: I396b04edb668c0a5a403ccfd3f6db90c78d29ce6

commit_message:
Adds check that the core V3 API is loaded

Adds infrastructure to be able to check that the core V3 API
plugins are present and raise an exception and abort if any are missing. The
list is deliberately hard coded though it is not yet complete and
will be expanded as the core APIs are ported and it is decided
exactly what will be considered to be the core API.

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-extension-framework

Change-Id: Ic2c1d5cd6836ee18819106558880682cf4cda487

commit_message:
Regenerate missing resized backing files

Fixes bug 1185588

The only way to reliably determine whether we are using a legacy
(pre-Grizzly) backing structure is to look at the backing file
reference for the instance/disk itself. Thus, if we determine the
backing file contains an underscore, we use the value following it
as our legacy_backing_size, which is then used to create the
necessary backing file.

Change-Id: I145f71068c972a604e5361ae79d6315286136786

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-06-04 14:49:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The idea is fantastic.  But I think the name "UnitTestCase" is too generic.  Something more explicit like "NoDBTestCast" would get the idea across better.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-06-04 15:24:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

David:

Yeah I thought about 'NoDBTestCase' as well. I opted for 'UnitTestCase' with the following ideas in mind, lemme know if they're convincing :-)

* 'Unit-test' is a bit of a murky term, different people have different definitions of what it is, but one fairly common requirement is that they shouldn't hit the database. So the class name was used to introduce this requirement, to shift the terminology in OpenStack from calling what we have unit-tests to just 'tests' and the new no DB style as 'unit-tests'.

It's a subtle thing, but I think getting a standard vocabulary here is a good thing, and using no-db as a requirement for the label 'unit' makes sense IMHO.

* Ultimately I'd like to create a 'unit/' directory parallel to 'functional' that has these new, fast unit-tests in them. Over time, we should migrate most of our tests into the 'unit/' directory.

* Since the DB needs testing as well, 'DBTestCase' would be created which permits DB access, and all tests hitting the DB would eventually be isolated in the 'db/' directory.

I haven't created a BP yet, b/c this is a really long-term kind of strategy and I wanted to see if the UnitTestCase change was getting any traction first.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-06-04 15:26:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Unit test already has a meaning within OpenStack, and it does *not* preclude hitting the DB.  Trying to redefine terms already in use within the project is asking for confusion.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-06-04 15:31:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

David:

Yeah, point taken, it's a little confusing.

Sucks we got the definition wrong (IMHO), but I guess we're stuck with it for the foreseeable future."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2013-06-06 23:48:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-07 00:32:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-25 01:06:41.000000000', 'message': "Speeding up scheduler tests

Database access is costly in tests and many tests don't actually need it. This
patch provides a simple way we can speed up the Nova tests by providing a new
base class, `UnitTestCase` which allows us to white-list tests not needing
database access.

The following speedup was observed against `test_scheduler.py` with the only
change needed being a stubbing of `get_instance_type`:

With TestCase: Ran 47 tests in 4.736s
With UnitTestCase: Ran 47 tests in 1.320s

Change-Id: Ic34c4c39d7f680ac501efb459fdeaa51331ffe1c
"}, {'created': '2013-05-25 03:02:42.000000000', 'message': "Speeding up scheduler tests

Database access is costly in tests and many tests don't actually need it. This
patch provides a simple way we can speed up the Nova tests by providing a new
base class, `UnitTestCase` which allows us to white-list tests not needing
database access.

The following speedup was observed against `test_scheduler.py` with the only
change needed being a stubbing of `get_instance_type`:

With TestCase: Ran 47 tests in 4.736s
With UnitTestCase: Ran 47 tests in 1.320s

Change-Id: Ic34c4c39d7f680ac501efb459fdeaa51331ffe1c
"}, {'created': '2013-05-25 16:28:18.000000000', 'message': "Speeding up scheduler tests

Database access is costly in tests and many tests don't actually need it. This
patch provides a simple way we can speed up the Nova tests by providing a new
base class, `UnitTestCase` which allows us to white-list tests not needing
database access.

The following speedup was observed against `test_scheduler.py` with the only
change needed being a stubbing of `get_instance_type`:

With TestCase: Ran 265 tests in 9.478s
Without UnitTestCase: Ran 265 tests in 17.080s

Further optimizaton could be done by fixing `test_host_filters` to not hit the
database. This will require some effort though in order to maintain the
quality of test coverage since part of what's doing is testing the code in the
DB layer.

Change-Id: Ic34c4c39d7f680ac501efb459fdeaa51331ffe1c

    With NoDBTestCase: Ran 265 tests in  9.478s

Further optimizaton could be done by fixing
`test_host_filters` to not hit the database. This
will require some effort though in order to
maintain the quality of test coverage since part
of what's doing is testing the code in the DB
layer.

Change-Id: Ic34c4c39d7f680ac501efb459fdeaa51331ffe1c
"}]
commit_message:
Speeding up scheduler tests

Database access is costly in tests and many tests
don't actually need it. This patch provides a
simple way we can speed up the Nova tests by
providing a new base class, `NoDBTestCase` which
allows us to white-list tests not needing database
access.

The following speedups were observed:

    With TestCase:     Ran 265 tests in 17.080s
    With NoDBTestCase: Ran 265 tests in  9.478s

Further optimizaton could be done by fixing
`test_host_filters` to not hit the database. This
will require some effort though in order to
maintain the quality of test coverage since part
of what's doing is testing the code in the DB
layer.

Change-Id: Ic34c4c39d7f680ac501efb459fdeaa51331ffe1c

commit_message:
Improve Keypair error messages in osapi

The KeypairAPI code provides useful error messages that weren't being
percolated back through the OpenStack API. This patch addresses this by using
the original `message` when crafting the HTTPException objects.

References bug 1187952

Change-Id: I786a225010d912d7bfea5c01838ddcf43fd90d53

`InvalidKeyPair` exceptions weren't raising the
proper error message. The reason was that the
error message was passed in as an `explanation`

EC2 APIs.

commit_message:
Fix Keypair exception messages

`InvalidKeyPair` exceptions weren't raising the
proper error message. The reason was that the
error message was passed in as an `explanation`
keyword which isn't understood by `NovaException`,
and so is thrown away.

This is part of a patch set to improve keypair
error message reporting in both the Openstack and
EC2 APIs.

References bug 1187952
Change-Id: Ide319cb126955927d623972dffd573cd4c4314df

commit_message:
Delete a quota through admin api.

Exposes the quota-delete api implemented as part of
blueprint admin-api-for-delete-quota
Change-Id: Iab358f0fcf2dfb41bcd9a3a5b73d590d3f55cd6c

Change-Id: I86e4f8316f3cdc27303bfd039a78c0d6202ce321

commit_message:
Don't install pep8 from packages

We have migrated to flake8 and most distros don't have the version of
pep8 that flake8 (and hacking) use.  Instead of installing pep8 from
packages it should be installed from pip

Change-Id: I86e4f8316f3cdc27303bfd039a78c0d6202ce321

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-06-10 15:31:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

1) Please note that we like to keep commentary associated with a review in the review.  If you don't know how to comment on a review, all you need to do is click the "Review" button, enter your comments in the text field, then "Publish Comments".  (Yeah, it's counterintuitive *shrug*.)

2) I noticed what appeared to be an issue in the 'metadata' argument you added to the new shell command.  In my own coding, I discovered that, when you use "nargs='+'" or "nargs='*'", it is not desirable to use "action='append'", as you end up with a one-element list wrapping the list you actually want.  I started to comment on it, but then I noticed that the _extract_metadata() function you use from shell.py is already coded with that assumption, meaning that other consumers of that interface make the same mistake.  In the long run, we need to fix all the shell commands that use "nargs='+'" or "nargs='*'" to use "action='store'" (which is the correct incantation) and modify _extract_metadata() to expect a straight-up list, but that doesn't actually matter for this patch; the problem isn't your fault, and I'm not going to hold this up any longer just because of someone else's mistake :)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-10 16:46:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

commit_message:
Set/Delete metadata on all instances of a host.

Adding a wrapper for all instances of a host, to be able to set/delete
metadata for all instances at once.

Implements blueprint tag-instances-of-host
Change-Id: I3d1a9ab54aad60bfccd0ece2285d145031fb5e15

commit_message:
Update analyze_opts to work with new nova.conf sample format

analyze_opts is a tool to help clean out a nova.conf file by checking
for unused and default values set in your nova.conf

Change-Id: I01fff134f8906bff929c55bea8c152653d3e9760

commit_message:
Refactor hooks file.

It was long and rambly. It's also in need of unittesting. So split
it into some classes so that we can test the inputs and outputs
more sensibly.

Change-Id: I3d28f5771e38b819f98a9af06aeb06529be7b302

Add local-check test

is only used inside of this repo

Fixes bug 1186415

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-06 16:37:56.000000000', 'message': 'Enable all checks during integration test

When testing trunk hacking against projects we want to see the results
for all checks. To make the output easier to understand, also enable
statistics output at the end, so one can quickly see if there is any
change in the numbers

Change-Id: Ic80083a5605a988aae75c20df924eced8674ef1f
'}]
commit_message:
Enable all checks during integration test

When testing trunk hacking against projects we want to see the results
for all checks. To make the output easier to understand, also enable
statistics output at the end, so one can quickly see if there is any
change in the numbers

Change-Id: Ic80083a5605a988aae75c20df924eced8674ef1f

commit_message:
Bug # 1189296 - Add links to official Red Hat cloud images.

Add links to the "KVM Guest Image" and boot.iso image provided by Red
Hat for use in cloud environments.

Change-Id: Ia68aa26a276c0c529fcd420bda666714cfe24578
